headline: Story of wolf and scared boys reaches Christiansborg Palace. But it's a cat, experts say
summary: 1. Two schoolboys from Esbjerg had to sit scared in a tree for an hour and a half, hiding from a wolf that was circling below them. 2. JydskeVestkysten writes this in an article, where they also include the boys' own video recording of the animal.3. The incident has sparked a lot of debate on social media and among politicians. But according to experts, it wasn't a wolf at all that the boys encountered, but a big cat.
text: Two boys aged 11 and 12 from Esbjerg had an experience on Thursday last week that made them really scared. While they were killing time climbing trees near their school, they suddenly saw a wolf approaching. The boys climbed four meters up the tree, where they had to wait for an hour and a half while the wolf circled below them.  This is reported by JydskeVestkysten , which also publishes a video of the roaming predator that the boys have recorded.  The article is being widely shared on social media, where it is overflowing with comments from people who are angry and outraged that the wolf is getting so close to children. The story has even reached Christiansborg Palace.  The Danish People's Party shares the story on X with the message of regaining security, and Liberal Party member of parliament Anni Matthiesen reports on Facebook about the boys' experience.  The same is done by the Social Democratic member of parliament Anders Kronborg on Facebook, where he writes that “HUMANS come before WOLF”. Anders Kronborg is also a former city council member in Esbjerg Municipality, an open advocate for regulating wolves, and one of the two boys is his nephew. But it seems that it was not a wolf at all that the boys sought refuge from and filmed. JydskeVestkysten has also clarified their article and, among other things, changed the headline.  A Facebook user shares the video and points out that doubts have been raised about whether it is actually a wolf.Not a wolf, but a catTjekDet has been in contact with two of Denmark's leading wolf experts, who assess that it is not a wolf that appears in the boys' video recording of the incident. They both assess that it is another animal that the boys have seen. It is certainly not a wolf seen in the film. Judging from the animal's size and movements, it is a cat. Probably a long-haired one, says Peter Sunde, professor and wolf expert at the Department of Ecoscience at Aarhus University. Kent Olsen, wolf expert and scientific director of senior researchers at the Natural History Museum, makes the same assessment. I have seen the recording and read the article. The recording shows that it is a cat and not a wolf, writes Kent Olsen in an email to TjekDet. In addition to the video that the experts have reviewed and which, according to them, does not show a wolf, JydskeVestkysten also includes a picture in the article that allegedly comes from the video. The picture shows an animal that may well resemble a wolf. The caption states that the picture is a screenshot from the video recording that the boys took from the tree, and that the boys had no doubt that it was a wolf. Sign up for the CheckIt newsletter Louise Lauritsen, editor-in-chief and local editor of JydskeVestkysten in Esbjerg, informs TjekDet that the editorial staff did not take the screenshot from the boys' video themselves. The image was sent by the boys.  JydskeVestkysten has not wanted to release the boys' full-length recording to TjekDet, but says that they are in possession of it.  Following TjekDet's inquiry, JydskeVestkysten has provided a clarification in their article. “The headline of the article was changed on April 14th at 1:30 p.m. after several experts, whom JydskeVestkysten has spoken to, cast doubt on whether it was a wolf that scared the boys,” the media outlet now writes. They have also changed the headline from “Two boys sat up in a tree for an hour and a half while a wolf circled below them” to “Two boys sat up in a tree for an hour and a half out of fear of a wolf” . In an email to TjekDet, Louise Lauritsen acknowledges that JydskeVestkysten should have made more linguistic reservations in the article and not concluded that it was a wolf. She does not answer directly whether they still believe that it is most likely that the boys saw a wolf. Instead, she writes: “We have conveyed the boys' experience of being scared by a wolf. We perceive the children and their parents as credible sources and without alternative motive.” CheckedIs the wasp really more dangerous than the wolf? The original article also reports that the janitor at the nearby school also saw a wolf in the area the day after the two boys. JydskeVestkysten also clarifies this in the updated version. “The school janitor informs JydskeVestkysten that he has seen a dog-like animal in the area,” it now reads. They have also changed the caption to what is allegedly a screenshot from the two boys' video recording. They (the boys, ed.) had no doubt that this was a wolf, but experts do not agree, JydskeVestkysten has now added to the description. TjekDet has tried unsuccessfully to get in touch with the boys and their parents. CheckedViral appeal is good enough: A fallen sheep can die if it is not helped upWolves on Danish soilAlthough it is in all likelihood not a wolf that the boys have videotaped, wolves have been seen before to come close to people - even in cities.This happened earlier in April, when JydskeVestkysten reported a story about a wolf that had visited Tistrup and Ansager in Varde Municipality on a Saturday. Shortly before, Oksbøl, which is also located in Varde Municipality, had also had a wolf visit.If you like TjekDet's articles and want to make sure you don't miss the latest, follow us on Facebook by clicking here . You can also sign up for TjekDet's free newsletter, where we'll tell you about our latest fact checks - directly in your email inbox. Sign up for the newsletter here .

They later updated the article, adjusting the headline and clarifying expert doubts.  Expert Assessment: Leading Danish wolf experts from Aarhus University and the Natural History Museum reviewed the video and agreed it was not a wolf, citing the animal's size and movement as consistent with a long-haired cat.

headline: Story of wolf and scared boys reaches Christiansborg Palace. But it's a cat, experts say
summary: 1. Two schoolboys from Esbjerg had to sit scared in a tree for an hour and a half, hiding from a wolf that was circling below them. 2. JydskeVestkysten writes this in an article, where they also include the boys' own video recording of the animal.3. The incident has sparked a lot of debate on social media and among politicians. But according to experts, it wasn't a wolf at all that the boys encountered, but a big cat.
text: Two boys aged 11 and 12 from Esbjerg had an experience on Thursday last week that made them really scared. While they were killing time climbing trees near their school, they suddenly saw a wolf approaching. The boys climbed four meters up the tree, where they had to wait for an hour and a half while the wolf circled below them.  This is reported by JydskeVestkysten , which also publishes a video of the roaming predator that the boys have recorded.  The article is being widely shared on social media, where it is overflowing with comments from people who are angry and outraged that the wolf is getting so close to children. The story has even reached Christiansborg Palace.  The Danish People's Party shares the story on X with the message of regaining security, and Liberal Party member of parliament Anni Matthiesen reports on Facebook about the boys' experience.  The same is done by the Social Democratic member of parliament Anders Kronborg on Facebook, where he writes that “HUMANS come before WOLF”. Anders Kronborg is also a former city council member in Esbjerg Municipality, an open advocate for regulating wolves, and one of the two boys is his nephew. But it seems that it was not a wolf at all that the boys sought refuge from and filmed. JydskeVestkysten has also clarified their article and, among other things, changed the headline.  A Facebook user shares the video and points out that doubts have been raised about whether it is actually a wolf.Not a wolf, but a catTjekDet has been in contact with two of Denmark's leading wolf experts, who assess that it is not a wolf that appears in the boys' video recording of the incident. They both assess that it is another animal that the boys have seen. It is certainly not a wolf seen in the film. Judging from the animal's size and movements, it is a cat. Probably a long-haired one, says Peter Sunde, professor and wolf expert at the Department of Ecoscience at Aarhus University. Kent Olsen, wolf expert and scientific director of senior researchers at the Natural History Museum, makes the same assessment. I have seen the recording and read the article. The recording shows that it is a cat and not a wolf, writes Kent Olsen in an email to TjekDet. In addition to the video that the experts have reviewed and which, according to them, does not show a wolf, JydskeVestkysten also includes a picture in the article that allegedly comes from the video. The picture shows an animal that may well resemble a wolf. The caption states that the picture is a screenshot from the video recording that the boys took from the tree, and that the boys had no doubt that it was a wolf. Sign up for the CheckIt newsletter Louise Lauritsen, editor-in-chief and local editor of JydskeVestkysten in Esbjerg, informs TjekDet that the editorial staff did not take the screenshot from the boys' video themselves. The image was sent by the boys.  JydskeVestkysten has not wanted to release the boys' full-length recording to TjekDet, but says that they are in possession of it.  Following TjekDet's inquiry, JydskeVestkysten has provided a clarification in their article. “The headline of the article was changed on April 14th at 1:30 p.m. after several experts, whom JydskeVestkysten has spoken to, cast doubt on whether it was a wolf that scared the boys,” the media outlet now writes. They have also changed the headline from “Two boys sat up in a tree for an hour and a half while a wolf circled below them” to “Two boys sat up in a tree for an hour and a half out of fear of a wolf” . In an email to TjekDet, Louise Lauritsen acknowledges that JydskeVestkysten should have made more linguistic reservations in the article and not concluded that it was a wolf. She does not answer directly whether they still believe that it is most likely that the boys saw a wolf. Instead, she writes: “We have conveyed the boys' experience of being scared by a wolf. We perceive the children and their parents as credible sources and without alternative motive.” CheckedIs the wasp really more dangerous than the wolf? The original article also reports that the janitor at the nearby school also saw a wolf in the area the day after the two boys. JydskeVestkysten also clarifies this in the updated version. “The school janitor informs JydskeVestkysten that he has seen a dog-like animal in the area,” it now reads. They have also changed the caption to what is allegedly a screenshot from the two boys' video recording. They (the boys, ed.) had no doubt that this was a wolf, but experts do not agree, JydskeVestkysten has now added to the description. TjekDet has tried unsuccessfully to get in touch with the boys and their parents. CheckedViral appeal is good enough: A fallen sheep can die if it is not helped upWolves on Danish soilAlthough it is in all likelihood not a wolf that the boys have videotaped, wolves have been seen before to come close to people - even in cities.This happened earlier in April, when JydskeVestkysten reported a story about a wolf that had visited Tistrup and Ansager in Varde Municipality on a Saturday. Shortly before, Oksbøl, which is also located in Varde Municipality, had also had a wolf visit.If you like TjekDet's articles and want to make sure you don't miss the latest, follow us on Facebook by clicking here . You can also sign up for TjekDet's free newsletter, where we'll tell you about our latest fact checks - directly in your email inbox. Sign up for the newsletter here .

Claim: Two boys in Esbjerg were trapped in a tree for an hour and a half while a wolf circled below them, as reported by JydskeVestkysten. Summary: The fact-check investigates the claim that two boys in Esbjerg were trapped in a tree for an hour and a half due to a wolf circling below them, as initially reported by JydskeVestkysten. The key evidence refuting this claim comes from two wolf experts, Peter Sunde and Kent Olsen, who analyzed the boys’ video and determined the animal was a cat, likely a long-haired one, based on its size and movements. Additionally, the school janitor’s reported sighting of a wolf was later clarified as a “dog-like animal,” and the screenshot resembling a wolf was provided by the boys, not verified by the editorial staff. Following these findings, JydskeVestkysten updated their article, changing the headline to reflect expert doubts and acknowledging they should have used more cautious language. Despite the boys’ and their parents’ belief that they saw a wolf, the expert analysis and lack of corroborating evidence lead to the verdict that the claim is false; the animal was not a wolf but a cat.

JydskeVestkysten’s clarifications, including a revised headline and updated description of the janitor’s sighting as a “dog-like animal,” further support this conclusion, as does their admission of insufficient caution in the original reporting.

headline: Story of wolf and scared boys reaches Christiansborg Palace. But it's a cat, experts say
summary: 1. Two schoolboys from Esbjerg had to sit scared in a tree for an hour and a half, hiding from a wolf that was circling below them. 2. JydskeVestkysten writes this in an article, where they also include the boys' own video recording of the animal.3. The incident has sparked a lot of debate on social media and among politicians. But according to experts, it wasn't a wolf at all that the boys encountered, but a big cat.
text: Two boys aged 11 and 12 from Esbjerg had an experience on Thursday last week that made them really scared. While they were killing time climbing trees near their school, they suddenly saw a wolf approaching. The boys climbed four meters up the tree, where they had to wait for an hour and a half while the wolf circled below them.  This is reported by JydskeVestkysten , which also publishes a video of the roaming predator that the boys have recorded.  The article is being widely shared on social media, where it is overflowing with comments from people who are angry and outraged that the wolf is getting so close to children. The story has even reached Christiansborg Palace.  The Danish People's Party shares the story on X with the message of regaining security, and Liberal Party member of parliament Anni Matthiesen reports on Facebook about the boys' experience.  The same is done by the Social Democratic member of parliament Anders Kronborg on Facebook, where he writes that “HUMANS come before WOLF”. Anders Kronborg is also a former city council member in Esbjerg Municipality, an open advocate for regulating wolves, and one of the two boys is his nephew. But it seems that it was not a wolf at all that the boys sought refuge from and filmed. JydskeVestkysten has also clarified their article and, among other things, changed the headline.  A Facebook user shares the video and points out that doubts have been raised about whether it is actually a wolf.Not a wolf, but a catTjekDet has been in contact with two of Denmark's leading wolf experts, who assess that it is not a wolf that appears in the boys' video recording of the incident. They both assess that it is another animal that the boys have seen. It is certainly not a wolf seen in the film. Judging from the animal's size and movements, it is a cat. Probably a long-haired one, says Peter Sunde, professor and wolf expert at the Department of Ecoscience at Aarhus University. Kent Olsen, wolf expert and scientific director of senior researchers at the Natural History Museum, makes the same assessment. I have seen the recording and read the article. The recording shows that it is a cat and not a wolf, writes Kent Olsen in an email to TjekDet. In addition to the video that the experts have reviewed and which, according to them, does not show a wolf, JydskeVestkysten also includes a picture in the article that allegedly comes from the video. The picture shows an animal that may well resemble a wolf. The caption states that the picture is a screenshot from the video recording that the boys took from the tree, and that the boys had no doubt that it was a wolf. Sign up for the CheckIt newsletter Louise Lauritsen, editor-in-chief and local editor of JydskeVestkysten in Esbjerg, informs TjekDet that the editorial staff did not take the screenshot from the boys' video themselves. The image was sent by the boys.  JydskeVestkysten has not wanted to release the boys' full-length recording to TjekDet, but says that they are in possession of it.  Following TjekDet's inquiry, JydskeVestkysten has provided a clarification in their article. “The headline of the article was changed on April 14th at 1:30 p.m. after several experts, whom JydskeVestkysten has spoken to, cast doubt on whether it was a wolf that scared the boys,” the media outlet now writes. They have also changed the headline from “Two boys sat up in a tree for an hour and a half while a wolf circled below them” to “Two boys sat up in a tree for an hour and a half out of fear of a wolf” . In an email to TjekDet, Louise Lauritsen acknowledges that JydskeVestkysten should have made more linguistic reservations in the article and not concluded that it was a wolf. She does not answer directly whether they still believe that it is most likely that the boys saw a wolf. Instead, she writes: “We have conveyed the boys' experience of being scared by a wolf. We perceive the children and their parents as credible sources and without alternative motive.” CheckedIs the wasp really more dangerous than the wolf? The original article also reports that the janitor at the nearby school also saw a wolf in the area the day after the two boys. JydskeVestkysten also clarifies this in the updated version. “The school janitor informs JydskeVestkysten that he has seen a dog-like animal in the area,” it now reads. They have also changed the caption to what is allegedly a screenshot from the two boys' video recording. They (the boys, ed.) had no doubt that this was a wolf, but experts do not agree, JydskeVestkysten has now added to the description. TjekDet has tried unsuccessfully to get in touch with the boys and their parents. CheckedViral appeal is good enough: A fallen sheep can die if it is not helped upWolves on Danish soilAlthough it is in all likelihood not a wolf that the boys have videotaped, wolves have been seen before to come close to people - even in cities.This happened earlier in April, when JydskeVestkysten reported a story about a wolf that had visited Tistrup and Ansager in Varde Municipality on a Saturday. Shortly before, Oksbøl, which is also located in Varde Municipality, had also had a wolf visit.If you like TjekDet's articles and want to make sure you don't miss the latest, follow us on Facebook by clicking here . You can also sign up for TjekDet's free newsletter, where we'll tell you about our latest fact checks - directly in your email inbox. Sign up for the newsletter here .
chatgpt_generation: Boys’ Video of ‘Wolf’ Near School in Esbjerg Is Actually a Cat, Experts Confirm
chatgpt_condensation: Claim: Two boys aged 11 and 12 from Esbjerg were scared by a wolf that approached them while they were climbing a tree near their school, and they recorded the wolf circling below them for an hour and a half. Evidence:  The boys and their parents reported the incident and provided a video and a screenshot of the animal.  The local newspaper JydskeVestkysten initially published the story with a headline stating the boys sat in a tree while a wolf circled below.  Two leading Danish wolf experts reviewed the video and concluded that the animal is not a wolf but most likely a long-haired cat based on size and movement.  JydskeVestkysten clarified their article by changing the headline to reflect that the boys feared a wolf rather than confirming a wolf’s presence.  Additional eyewitness reports, such as a school janitor’s sighting, were revised to state the animal resembled a dog rather than a wolf.  The media outlet acknowledged they should have been more cautious in labeling the animal a wolf and emphasized the boys’ experience of fear without confirming the animal’s identity. Verdict: The claim that the boys were approached and scared by a wolf is false. Although the boys genuinely believed they saw a wolf, expert analysis of the video strongly indicates the animal was a cat. The original report was corrected to avoid misidentifying the animal, and there is no verified evidence confirming the presence of a wolf in this specific incident.

Explanation: Experts reviewed the video footage and determined the animal in question is not a wolf but most likely a long-haired cat, based on its size and movements. The newspaper that reported the story revised their headline and clarified the situation after expert input cast doubt on the wolf identification. No verified evidence confirms that a wolf was present during the incident, so the claim that the boys were scared by a wolf is false.
gemini_generation: Esbjerg Boys' 'Wolf Encounter' Was Actually a Cat, Experts Confirm
gemini_condensation: A widely shared story claimed that two boys, aged 11 and 12, were terrorized by a wolf for 90 minutes while climbing trees near their school in Esbjerg, Denmark, with a video supposedly showing the wolf. The claim gained significant traction, especially on social media, sparking outrage and even reaching politicians. However, a fact-check by TjekDet, contacting leading Danish wolf experts, disputed this claim. Both Peter Sunde, professor and wolf expert at Aarhus University, and Kent Olsen, wolf expert and scientific director at the Natural History Museum, independently assessed the video and concluded it was not a wolf but a cat, likely a long-haired one, based on the animal's size and movements. JydskeVestkysten, the original publisher of the story, has since clarified their article, changing the headline to reflect that the boys were fearful of a wolf rather than explicitly stating it was a wolf. They also updated their description of a school janitor's sighting, changing wolf to dog-like animal. While JydskeVestkysten maintained that the boys and their parents were credible sources regarding their experience of fear, they admitted to TjekDet that they should have used more linguistic reservations in their initial reporting. The image initially presented as a screenshot from the video and resembling a wolf was provided by the boys, not taken by the editorial staff, and its caption has now been updated to reflect expert doubt. Verdict: The claim that the boys were circled by a wolf is false. Expert analysis of the video indicates the animal was a cat, not a wolf.
gemini_evaluation: Claim: Two boys from Esbjerg were circled by a wolf for an hour and a half while climbing trees near their school, and they filmed the wolf. Verdict: False. Explanation: Two leading Danish wolf experts independently reviewed the boys' video recording of the incident and unequivocally stated that the animal shown is a cat, likely a long-haired one, not a wolf. The original news outlet that published the story has since corrected its article and headline to reflect the experts' doubt and acknowledge that the image they published, which resembled a wolf, was provided by the boys and not a screenshot taken by their editorial team. While the boys genuinely experienced fear, the animal they feared was misidentified.

headline: The Trump circle again makes the false claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States
summary: American Trump supporters continue to claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States.  But there is nothing to indicate that this is the wish of the Greenlanders.   According to a researcher, the Trump administration is trying to convince a skeptical American public that annexing Greenland is a good idea.  But we do not know the Greenlanders' position on negotiating a cooperation agreement with the United States, and such an option is still on the table.
text: This is the fact-check :While US Vice President JD Vance was visiting American soldiers at Pituffik Space Base in northwestern Greenland at the end of March, Republican Congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna was on live air on Fox News .Here she said that not only is Greenland a strategically good place for the United States, but the Greenlandic population is a big supporter of potentially becoming an American territory.It is far from the first time that President Donald Trump himself or his circle of supporters have said that Greenlanders would like to be part of the United States. Back in January, the president claimed, in connection with his desire to take over Greenland, for example , that “the Greenlandic people will be with us.”So is there really anything to talk about? Do Greenlanders want to belong to the United States, since the Trump circle keeps repeating it?Live on Fox News, Republican Congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna reiterates that Greenlanders want to be American territory.Wants American supportNo, there is nothing to suggest that at all, says Jon Rahbek-Clemmensen , an associate professor at the Danish Defence Academy's Centre for Arctic Security Studies, referring to a poll by the research institute Verian .The same poll was also used back in January to refute Donald Trump's claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States. Verian's poll found that only six percent of Greenlanders want to leave the Commonwealth and instead become part of the United States. A full 85 percent answered no to the same question. Yet Trump supporters seem to be sticking to the claim. The reason for this must be found within American borders, believes Jon Rahbek-Clemmensen.In the US, the idea of taking over Greenland is also unpopular. The Trump administration is trying to influence public opinion so that it will appear as a good idea. It requires a narrative that the US can really get a lot out of it, and that the Greenlanders are on board with it, he says.A new poll from the Pew Research Center shows that there is low support among Americans for Trump's plan to take over Greenland. 54 percent do not believe that the United States should take over Greenland, while 23 percent are in favor.Fraudulent measurementHowever, there is one opinion poll that supports the Trump circle's interpretation of the Greenlanders' position. Back in January, the organization Patriot Polling presented startling figures shortly after Donald Trump Jr.'s visit to Nuuk. A full 57 percent of Greenlanders reportedly supported the idea of Greenland joining the United States.The Trump-loyal podcaster Charlie Kirk, who was with Donald Trump Jr. in Nuuk, circulated the poll and said that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States . However, experts have since denied that the numbers say anything precise about Greenlanders' attitudes.Either the numbers have been tampered with, or they are freely invented , says Ulrik Pram Gad, a senior researcher at the Danish Institute for International Studies (DIIS).“I'm not sure they've even spoken to anyone in Greenland. According to the methodology description, Patriot Polling calls landlines. But there are no landlines in Greenland at all,” he says.  The Verian poll is not perfect either, says Ulrik Pram Gad, because it is difficult to conduct polls in Greenland. Verian's Greenlandic respondents were not selected representatively, just as in the aforementioned question they are asked two things at once. headline: The Trump circle again makes the false claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States
summary: American Trump supporters continue to claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States.  But there is nothing to indicate that this is the wish of the Greenlanders.   According to a researcher, the Trump administration is trying to convince a skeptical American public that annexing Greenland is a good idea.  But we do not know the Greenlanders' position on negotiating a cooperation agreement with the United States, and such an option is still on the table.
text: This is the fact-check :While US Vice President JD Vance was visiting American soldiers at Pituffik Space Base in northwestern Greenland at the end of March, Republican Congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna was on live air on Fox News .Here she said that not only is Greenland a strategically good place for the United States, but the Greenlandic population is a big supporter of potentially becoming an American territory.It is far from the first time that President Donald Trump himself or his circle of supporters have said that Greenlanders would like to be part of the United States. Back in January, the president claimed, in connection with his desire to take over Greenland, for example , that “the Greenlandic people will be with us.”So is there really anything to talk about? Do Greenlanders want to belong to the United States, since the Trump circle keeps repeating it?Live on Fox News, Republican Congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna reiterates that Greenlanders want to be American territory.Wants American supportNo, there is nothing to suggest that at all, says Jon Rahbek-Clemmensen , an associate professor at the Danish Defence Academy's Centre for Arctic Security Studies, referring to a poll by the research institute Verian .The same poll was also used back in January to refute Donald Trump's claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States. Verian's poll found that only six percent of Greenlanders want to leave the Commonwealth and instead become part of the United States. A full 85 percent answered no to the same question. Yet Trump supporters seem to be sticking to the claim. The reason for this must be found within American borders, believes Jon Rahbek-Clemmensen.In the US, the idea of taking over Greenland is also unpopular. The Trump administration is trying to influence public opinion so that it will appear as a good idea. It requires a narrative that the US can really get a lot out of it, and that the Greenlanders are on board with it, he says.A new poll from the Pew Research Center shows that there is low support among Americans for Trump's plan to take over Greenland. 54 percent do not believe that the United States should take over Greenland, while 23 percent are in favor.Fraudulent measurementHowever, there is one opinion poll that supports the Trump circle's interpretation of the Greenlanders' position. Back in January, the organization Patriot Polling presented startling figures shortly after Donald Trump Jr.'s visit to Nuuk. A full 57 percent of Greenlanders reportedly supported the idea of Greenland joining the United States.The Trump-loyal podcaster Charlie Kirk, who was with Donald Trump Jr. in Nuuk, circulated the poll and said that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States . However, experts have since denied that the numbers say anything precise about Greenlanders' attitudes.Either the numbers have been tampered with, or they are freely invented , says Ulrik Pram Gad, a senior researcher at the Danish Institute for International Studies (DIIS).“I'm not sure they've even spoken to anyone in Greenland. According to the methodology description, Patriot Polling calls landlines. But there are no landlines in Greenland at all,” he says.  The Verian poll is not perfect either, says Ulrik Pram Gad, because it is difficult to conduct polls in Greenland. Verian's Greenlandic respondents were not selected representatively, just as in the aforementioned question they are asked two things at once. That is, both whether they want to leave the Commonwealth and whether they want to join the USA.“It is methodologically fragile, but the answers are so overwhelming that you can take it as a strong indication that Greenlanders do not want to be part of the USA,” says Ulrik Pram Gad.The people of Greenland want to join America! https:

A contradictory poll by Patriot Polling claimed 57% support but was widely discredited due to methodological flaws—such as using landlines, which do not exist in Greenland.  Greenland’s recent election results and statements from politicians indicate skepticism and rejection of U.S. annexation.  Verdict: False — There is no credible evidence that Greenlanders want to become a U.S. territory. The dominant sentiment in Greenland is against such a move, and claims to the contrary are unsupported or based on dubious data.

headline: The Trump circle again makes the false claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States
summary: American Trump supporters continue to claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States.  But there is nothing to indicate that this is the wish of the Greenlanders.   According to a researcher, the Trump administration is trying to convince a skeptical American public that annexing Greenland is a good idea.  But we do not know the Greenlanders' position on negotiating a cooperation agreement with the United States, and such an option is still on the table.
text: This is the fact-check :While US Vice President JD Vance was visiting American soldiers at Pituffik Space Base in northwestern Greenland at the end of March, Republican Congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna was on live air on Fox News .Here she said that not only is Greenland a strategically good place for the United States, but the Greenlandic population is a big supporter of potentially becoming an American territory.It is far from the first time that President Donald Trump himself or his circle of supporters have said that Greenlanders would like to be part of the United States. Back in January, the president claimed, in connection with his desire to take over Greenland, for example , that “the Greenlandic people will be with us.”So is there really anything to talk about? Do Greenlanders want to belong to the United States, since the Trump circle keeps repeating it?Live on Fox News, Republican Congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna reiterates that Greenlanders want to be American territory.Wants American supportNo, there is nothing to suggest that at all, says Jon Rahbek-Clemmensen , an associate professor at the Danish Defence Academy's Centre for Arctic Security Studies, referring to a poll by the research institute Verian .The same poll was also used back in January to refute Donald Trump's claim that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States. Verian's poll found that only six percent of Greenlanders want to leave the Commonwealth and instead become part of the United States. A full 85 percent answered no to the same question. Yet Trump supporters seem to be sticking to the claim. The reason for this must be found within American borders, believes Jon Rahbek-Clemmensen.In the US, the idea of taking over Greenland is also unpopular. The Trump administration is trying to influence public opinion so that it will appear as a good idea. It requires a narrative that the US can really get a lot out of it, and that the Greenlanders are on board with it, he says.A new poll from the Pew Research Center shows that there is low support among Americans for Trump's plan to take over Greenland. 54 percent do not believe that the United States should take over Greenland, while 23 percent are in favor.Fraudulent measurementHowever, there is one opinion poll that supports the Trump circle's interpretation of the Greenlanders' position. Back in January, the organization Patriot Polling presented startling figures shortly after Donald Trump Jr.'s visit to Nuuk. A full 57 percent of Greenlanders reportedly supported the idea of Greenland joining the United States.The Trump-loyal podcaster Charlie Kirk, who was with Donald Trump Jr. in Nuuk, circulated the poll and said that Greenlanders want to be part of the United States . However, experts have since denied that the numbers say anything precise about Greenlanders' attitudes.Either the numbers have been tampered with, or they are freely invented , says Ulrik Pram Gad, a senior researcher at the Danish Institute for International Studies (DIIS).“I'm not sure they've even spoken to anyone in Greenland. According to the methodology description, Patriot Polling calls landlines. But there are no landlines in Greenland at all,” he says.  The Verian poll is not perfect either, says Ulrik Pram Gad, because it is difficult to conduct polls in Greenland. Verian's Greenlandic respondents were not selected representatively, just as in the aforementioned question they are asked two things at once. That is, both whether they want to leave the Commonwealth and whether they want to join the USA.“It is methodologically fragile, but the answers are so overwhelming that you can take it as a strong indication that Greenlanders do not want to be part of the USA,” says Ulrik Pram Gad.The people of Greenland want to join America! https:

headline: Has Zelensky bought Hitler's old summer residence?
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has purchased Adolf Hitler's former summer home, according to several posts on social media.  But the story is fabricated and is in all likelihood an example of Russian disinformation.  According to researchers, false allegations about the Ukrainian president have flared up after Donald Trump called the Ukrainian president a dictator.
text: This is the fact-checkUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has purchased Adolf Hitler's old summer house, Kehlsteinhaus, also known as the Eagle's Nest, for more than 100 million kroner.This is the claim in several posts on both X and Facebook , which also link the summer house purchase with the aid that Ukraine receives from the United States to wage war on Russia. The posts have been viewed hundreds of thousands of times.The posts include photos of alleged purchase contracts and a video detailing the building's history as Adolf Hitler's summer residence, while explaining that the house has now been sold to an Italian company owned by the Ukrainian president.According to the posts, the story about the summer house purchase comes from German media, but the only German media outlet that TjekDet has been able to find the story from is the unknown Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland .It turns out that the German media is actually a Russian propaganda outlet. And Zelenskyy did not buy Hitler's summer house.Hitler's summer residenceKehlsteinhaus was given to Hitler in 1939 as a 50th birthday present by German Nazi politician Martin Bormann. The building gets its name because it is located on the top of the Kehlstein mountain, a whopping 1,834 meters above sea level.Hitler's visits to the house were few and far between, however , because he disliked the heights and the elevator that had to be used to reach the house at the time. The risk of lightning strikes was also not a weather forecast that the German dictator liked.The video, now being shared on social media, shows that President Zelenskyy has purchased the building from the state-owned Bavarian company Immobilien Freistaat Bayern (IMBY), whose director, Gerhard Reichel , according to the video, comments on the sale as follows:“Such transactions with historic sites are very rare. However, in this case, due to the high state subsidy required to ensure the ongoing operation (of the building, ed.), it was only a matter of time before a sale would take place,” it says.But the statement and the sale of Kehlsteinhaus are, according to IMBY, pure fabrication.“The Kehlsteinhaus remains in the ownership of the Free State of Bavaria. A sale has not taken place and is not planned. The alleged purchase contract shown in the video is false, as is the alleged quote from the IMBY management,” IMBY states on their website .They also state that they will take legal action against those who spread the false information on the internet.Volodymyr Zelenskyj bought the Kehlsteinhaus, which previously belonged to Hitler, writes the media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, which is apparently German. But the website hides a secret. Photo: Screenshot.The arrow points towards RussiaAs mentioned, the false story was published by the “German” media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, and it is most likely a website created for the purpose of spreading Russian disinformation.CheckDet has not been able to find any traces of the media website from before December 14, 2024. According to various services that monitor changes to websites, the first activity on the website was seen on that very day. It was also on December 14 that the website was first archived through the Wayback Machine service.If you search for the website on Google, there are no results from before December 2024.The website also appears on the list of 100 fake websites that, among others, the German fact-checking media Correctiv has identified as being created with the aim of spreading Russian disinformation ahead of the German elections on February 23, 2025.Correctiv has dubbed the influence operation Storm-1516, and according to the media outlet, the operation has links to the Russian troll factory Internet Research Agency (IRA) and the Russian military intelligence service GRU.The false story also ties in with many other stories about Volodymyr Zelenskyj, which TjekDet has previously fact-checked. Among other things, the president's wife is said to have acquired a Bugatti , and Zelenskyj himself is said to have bought a hotel casino in Cyprus .And the strategy seems to be the same.The Bugatti story was also published on a newly created website that, like Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, imitates a real news site, where a few fake ones are planted among a sea of true stories - typically with an angle on Russia. Probably to strengthen credibility.Reaction to Trump's dictator accusationThe news outlet AFP writes that false allegations about Volodymyr Zelensky have flared up after US President Donald Trump, among other things, called the Ukrainian president a dictator.We have observed a significant resurgence of anti-Ukrainian disinformation on US social media, much of which appears to be recycled content from previous Russian influence campaigns, McKenzie Sadeghi, an analyst at disinformation watchdog NewsGuard, told AFP .Trump's comments appear to have sparked renewed interest in anti-Ukrainian narratives that had previously faded, Sadeghi further told AFP .Joseph Bodnar, a researcher at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue, explains to AFP that the Russian influence attempts focus on creating animosity between the Trump and Zelenskyy administrations.Russia wants to convince American negotiators that Ukraine is their enemy, not their ally. It is a means for the Kremlin to obtain favorable terms in any peace agreement that may come.

And Zelenskyy did not buy Hitler's summer house.Hitler's summer residenceKehlsteinhaus was given to Hitler in 1939 as a 50th birthday present by German Nazi politician Martin Bormann. The building gets its name because it is located on the top of the Kehlstein mountain, a whopping 1,834 meters above sea level.Hitler's visits to the house were few and far between, however , because he disliked the heights and the elevator that had to be used to reach the house at the time. The risk of lightning strikes was also not a weather forecast that the German dictator liked.The video, now being shared on social media, shows that President Zelenskyy has purchased the building from the state-owned Bavarian company Immobilien Freistaat Bayern (IMBY), whose director, Gerhard Reichel , according to the video, comments on the sale as follows:“Such transactions with historic sites are very rare. However, in this case, due to the high state subsidy required to ensure the ongoing operation (of the building, ed.), it was only a matter of time before a sale would take place,” it says.But the statement and the sale of Kehlsteinhaus are, according to IMBY, pure fabrication.“The Kehlsteinhaus remains in the ownership of the Free State of Bavaria. A sale has not taken place and is not planned. The alleged purchase contract shown in the video is false, as is the alleged quote from the IMBY management,” IMBY states on their website .They also state that they will take legal action against those who spread the false information on the internet.Volodymyr Zelenskyj bought the Kehlsteinhaus, which previously belonged to Hitler, writes the media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, which is apparently German. But the website hides a secret. Photo: Screenshot.The arrow points towards RussiaAs mentioned, the false story was published by the “German” media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, and it is most likely a website created for the purpose of spreading Russian disinformation.CheckDet has not been able to find any traces of the media website from before December 14, 2024. According to various services that monitor changes to websites, the first activity on the website was seen on that very day. It was also on December 14 that the website was first archived through the Wayback Machine service.If you search for the website on Google, there are no results from before December 2024.The website also appears on the list of 100 fake websites that, among others, the German fact-checking media Correctiv has identified as being created with the aim of spreading Russian disinformation ahead of the German elections on February 23, 2025.Correctiv has dubbed the influence operation Storm-1516, and according to the media outlet, the operation has links to the Russian troll factory Internet Research Agency (IRA) and the Russian military intelligence service GRU.The false story also ties in with many other stories about Volodymyr Zelenskyj, which TjekDet has previously fact-checked. Among other things, the president's wife is said to have acquired a Bugatti , and Zelenskyj himself is said to have bought a hotel casino in Cyprus .And the strategy seems to be the same.The Bugatti story was also published on a newly created website that, like Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, imitates a real news site, where a few fake ones are planted among a sea of true stories - typically with an angle on Russia. Probably to strengthen credibility.Reaction to Trump's dictator accusationThe news outlet AFP writes that false allegations about Volodymyr Zelensky have flared up after US President Donald Trump, among other things, called the Ukrainian president a dictator.We have observed a significant resurgence of anti-Ukrainian disinformation on US social media, much of which appears to be recycled content from previous Russian influence campaigns, McKenzie Sadeghi, an analyst at disinformation watchdog NewsGuard, told AFP .Trump's comments appear to have sparked renewed interest in anti-Ukrainian narratives that had previously faded, Sadeghi further told AFP .Joseph Bodnar, a researcher at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue, explains to AFP that the Russian influence attempts focus on creating animosity between the Trump and Zelenskyy administrations.Russia wants to convince American negotiators that Ukraine is their enemy, not their ally. It is a means for the Kremlin to obtain favorable terms in any peace agreement that may come.

headline: Has Zelensky bought Hitler's old summer residence?
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has purchased Adolf Hitler's former summer home, according to several posts on social media.  But the story is fabricated and is in all likelihood an example of Russian disinformation.  According to researchers, false allegations about the Ukrainian president have flared up after Donald Trump called the Ukrainian president a dictator.
text: This is the fact-checkUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has purchased Adolf Hitler's old summer house, Kehlsteinhaus, also known as the Eagle's Nest, for more than 100 million kroner.This is the claim in several posts on both X and Facebook , which also link the summer house purchase with the aid that Ukraine receives from the United States to wage war on Russia. The posts have been viewed hundreds of thousands of times.The posts include photos of alleged purchase contracts and a video detailing the building's history as Adolf Hitler's summer residence, while explaining that the house has now been sold to an Italian company owned by the Ukrainian president.According to the posts, the story about the summer house purchase comes from German media, but the only German media outlet that TjekDet has been able to find the story from is the unknown Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland .It turns out that the German media is actually a Russian propaganda outlet. And Zelenskyy did not buy Hitler's summer house.Hitler's summer residenceKehlsteinhaus was given to Hitler in 1939 as a 50th birthday present by German Nazi politician Martin Bormann. The building gets its name because it is located on the top of the Kehlstein mountain, a whopping 1,834 meters above sea level.Hitler's visits to the house were few and far between, however , because he disliked the heights and the elevator that had to be used to reach the house at the time. The risk of lightning strikes was also not a weather forecast that the German dictator liked.The video, now being shared on social media, shows that President Zelenskyy has purchased the building from the state-owned Bavarian company Immobilien Freistaat Bayern (IMBY), whose director, Gerhard Reichel , according to the video, comments on the sale as follows:“Such transactions with historic sites are very rare. However, in this case, due to the high state subsidy required to ensure the ongoing operation (of the building, ed.), it was only a matter of time before a sale would take place,” it says.But the statement and the sale of Kehlsteinhaus are, according to IMBY, pure fabrication.“The Kehlsteinhaus remains in the ownership of the Free State of Bavaria. A sale has not taken place and is not planned. The alleged purchase contract shown in the video is false, as is the alleged quote from the IMBY management,” IMBY states on their website .They also state that they will take legal action against those who spread the false information on the internet.Volodymyr Zelenskyj bought the Kehlsteinhaus, which previously belonged to Hitler, writes the media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, which is apparently German. But the website hides a secret. Photo: Screenshot.The arrow points towards RussiaAs mentioned, the false story was published by the “German” media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, and it is most likely a website created for the purpose of spreading Russian disinformation.CheckDet has not been able to find any traces of the media website from before December 14, 2024. According to various services that monitor changes to websites, the first activity on the website was seen on that very day. It was also on December 14 that the website was first archived through the Wayback Machine service.If you search for the website on Google, there are no results from before December 2024.The website also appears on the list of 100 fake websites that, among others, the German fact-checking media Correctiv has identified as being created with the aim of spreading Russian disinformation ahead of the German elections on February 23, 2025.Correctiv has dubbed the influence operation Storm-1516, and according to the media outlet, the operation has links to the Russian troll factory Internet Research Agency (IRA) and the Russian military intelligence service GRU.The false story also ties in with many other stories about Volodymyr Zelenskyj, which TjekDet has previously fact-checked. Among other things, the president's wife is said to have acquired a Bugatti , and Zelenskyj himself is said to have bought a hotel casino in Cyprus .And the strategy seems to be the same.The Bugatti story was also published on a newly created website that, like Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, imitates a real news site, where a few fake ones are planted among a sea of true stories - typically with an angle on Russia. Probably to strengthen credibility.Reaction to Trump's dictator accusationThe news outlet AFP writes that false allegations about Volodymyr Zelensky have flared up after US President Donald Trump, among other things, called the Ukrainian president a dictator.We have observed a significant resurgence of anti-Ukrainian disinformation on US social media, much of which appears to be recycled content from previous Russian influence campaigns, McKenzie Sadeghi, an analyst at disinformation watchdog NewsGuard, told AFP .Trump's comments appear to have sparked renewed interest in anti-Ukrainian narratives that had previously faded, Sadeghi further told AFP .Joseph Bodnar, a researcher at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue, explains to AFP that the Russian influence attempts focus on creating animosity between the Trump and Zelenskyy administrations.Russia wants to convince American negotiators that Ukraine is their enemy, not their ally. It is a means for the Kremlin to obtain favorable terms in any peace agreement that may come.

The posts have been viewed hundreds of thousands of times.The posts include photos of alleged purchase contracts and a video detailing the building's history as Adolf Hitler's summer residence, while explaining that the house has now been sold to an Italian company owned by the Ukrainian president.According to the posts, the story about the summer house purchase comes from German media, but the only German media outlet that TjekDet has been able to find the story from is the unknown Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland .It turns out that the German media is actually a Russian propaganda outlet. And Zelenskyy did not buy Hitler's summer house.Hitler's summer residenceKehlsteinhaus was given to Hitler in 1939 as a 50th birthday present by German Nazi politician Martin Bormann. The building gets its name because it is located on the top of the Kehlstein mountain, a whopping 1,834 meters above sea level.Hitler's visits to the house were few and far between, however , because he disliked the heights and the elevator that had to be used to reach the house at the time. The risk of lightning strikes was also not a weather forecast that the German dictator liked.The video, now being shared on social media, shows that President Zelenskyy has purchased the building from the state-owned Bavarian company Immobilien Freistaat Bayern (IMBY), whose director, Gerhard Reichel , according to the video, comments on the sale as follows:“Such transactions with historic sites are very rare. However, in this case, due to the high state subsidy required to ensure the ongoing operation (of the building, ed.), it was only a matter of time before a sale would take place,” it says.But the statement and the sale of Kehlsteinhaus are, according to IMBY, pure fabrication.“The Kehlsteinhaus remains in the ownership of the Free State of Bavaria. A sale has not taken place and is not planned. The alleged purchase contract shown in the video is false, as is the alleged quote from the IMBY management,” IMBY states on their website .They also state that they will take legal action against those who spread the false information on the internet.Volodymyr Zelenskyj bought the Kehlsteinhaus, which previously belonged to Hitler, writes the media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, which is apparently German. But the website hides a secret. Photo: Screenshot.The arrow points towards RussiaAs mentioned, the false story was published by the “German” media outlet Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, and it is most likely a website created for the purpose of spreading Russian disinformation.CheckDet has not been able to find any traces of the media website from before December 14, 2024. According to various services that monitor changes to websites, the first activity on the website was seen on that very day. It was also on December 14 that the website was first archived through the Wayback Machine service.If you search for the website on Google, there are no results from before December 2024.The website also appears on the list of 100 fake websites that, among others, the German fact-checking media Correctiv has identified as being created with the aim of spreading Russian disinformation ahead of the German elections on February 23, 2025.Correctiv has dubbed the influence operation Storm-1516, and according to the media outlet, the operation has links to the Russian troll factory Internet Research Agency (IRA) and the Russian military intelligence service GRU.The false story also ties in with many other stories about Volodymyr Zelenskyj, which TjekDet has previously fact-checked. Among other things, the president's wife is said to have acquired a Bugatti , and Zelenskyj himself is said to have bought a hotel casino in Cyprus .And the strategy seems to be the same.The Bugatti story was also published on a newly created website that, like Aktuelle Nachrichten in Deutschland, imitates a real news site, where a few fake ones are planted among a sea of true stories - typically with an angle on Russia. Probably to strengthen credibility.Reaction to Trump's dictator accusationThe news outlet AFP writes that false allegations about Volodymyr Zelensky have flared up after US President Donald Trump, among other things, called the Ukrainian president a dictator.We have observed a significant resurgence of anti-Ukrainian disinformation on US social media, much of which appears to be recycled content from previous Russian influence campaigns, McKenzie Sadeghi, an analyst at disinformation watchdog NewsGuard, told AFP .Trump's comments appear to have sparked renewed interest in anti-Ukrainian narratives that had previously faded, Sadeghi further told AFP .Joseph Bodnar, a researcher at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue, explains to AFP that the Russian influence attempts focus on creating animosity between the Trump and Zelenskyy administrations.Russia wants to convince American negotiators that Ukraine is their enemy, not their ally. It is a means for the Kremlin to obtain favorable terms in any peace agreement that may come.

headline: Green trees in February 1722 not proof of climate change
summary: An old newspaper clipping about green trees in the spring of 1722 is making the rounds on social media, but the content doesn't mean what the spreaders seem to think. And the source turns out to be suspiciously similar to another text - which is about Germany.
text: This is the fact-check :For several years, a newspaper clipping with the headline “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green” has been circulating among climate skeptics on social media. The Source Criticism Agency is investigating the origin of the image – and the truth behind its content.It turns out that the anecdotal article doesn't actually say anything about the climate. And when we dig deeper into the archives, it turns out that large parts of the text aren't even about Swedish conditions – but about the weather in Germany.Post on Facebook with the image April 23, 2024.This is the text in what appears to be a photocopied newspaper article:  In February 1722, all the trees were completely green  . There have certainly been mild winters in the past. Gunnar Carlberg, who is also SMHI's precipitation monitor in Finspång, has looked through old scrapbooks and found the following interesting statistics:  In 1172, the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January. The birds built their nests and molted in February.  In 1241, the trees were fully leafed out in March.  In 1269, there was no winter at all.  In 1421, the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.  In 1538, the trees in the gardens were in full bloom already in December!  In 1585, the corn was in ear at Easter time.  In 1588, the trees turned green in February.  In 1538, 1607, 1617, 1650 and 1659, there was neither snow nor frost.  In 1722, all the trees were green in February.  In 1863, in Skåne, you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February.  NT Wednesday, February 15, 1989 The source criticism agency begins by examining the context in which the image was shared. The first post we find is from 2015 on the blog Klimatupplysningen, which is run by Klimatrealisterna, formerly the Stockholm Initiative. In 2010, the lobby group Stockholm Initiative was named Misleader of the Year by the public education association Vetenskap och Folkbildning . In the book “Upphettning: demokratin i klimatkrisens tid” (published in 2020 by the publisher Fri tanke), the Climate Realists are identified as “the hub of the Swedish denial movement”.  It was on Christmas Eve 2015 that Klimatupplysningen posted the image, stating that it came from a reader. The blog post has 112 comments.Commentary on Klimatupplysningen's blog post 2015.However, it will take five years for the image to truly go viral. Most of the shares we find are from 2020. The newspaper clipping appears on Twitter/X, Facebook and blogs that are skeptical of climate research. The fact that the picture is gaining momentum in the spring of 2020 is probably due to the fact that the spring was warmer and drier than normal that year, according to SMHI's measurements. In the cities of Gothenburg, Nordkoster, Visby and Hoburg, records were broken in the number of hours of sunshine. Weather and climate were on people's lips.But now it's spring again and the latest sharing we can find of the picture is from last week. A man writes on Facebook:It's time to let go of the lies that people's way of life affects the climate... The climate has always varied and this depends, among other things, on the activities of the sun...The post has over 500 interactions on Facebook. “This is something for all our almost religious climate activists to read,” writes one person in the comments section.But is what the post writer claims really true?No, the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) writes in its latest report that “human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system”. It is also “unequivocal that human influence has warmed the atmosphere, the ocean and the land”. “The global average temperature has increased faster since 1970 than during any other 50-year period for at least the last 2,000 years.”– According to the UN's climate panel IPCC, the global warming that has occurred since 1980 is mainly caused by anthropogenic greenhouse gases, i.e. the greenhouse gases that humans have added to the atmosphere. The title is so unusual that the only results we get when we google “precipitation monitor” are back to the NT article from 1989.There are also no notes at SMHI about a Gunnar Carlberg who worked for the authority. However, there is an Inez Carlberg who was a precipitation observer in Finspång in the 80s.– You can imagine that Gunnar was Inez's husband and that they ran the weather station together, muses Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.According to the article, Gunnar is said to have “looked through old music albums and found the following interesting statistics.” It may sound like Gunnar did this in his capacity as a member of some role at SMHI, but that is not the case, states Sverker Hellström.Post on Facebook with the newspaper article 2020.A precipitation monitor checks the rain gauge once a day, but the job does not involve any further analysis of the weather and wind – and certainly not going back in time. Gunnar (or someone else) would have collected his clips as a private person, not as an employee of SMHI.– You might get the feeling that the information in the article comes from SMHI, but that is not the case, says Sverker Hellström to Källkritikbyrån.Which clip albums Gunnar Carlberg would have looked at is also not clear from the NT article. But in 1172 no weather measurements were made in Sweden.Comment on Facebook March 13.It was also only in the 17th and 18th centuries that humans invented measuring tools for temperature and climate. And the oldest Swedish weather observations in Sweden date back to 1722. They were made at the weather station in Uppsala.– The measurement series began in 1722 and it was professors Anders Celsius and Eric Burman who initiated them, says Erik Sahlée, senior lecturer in meteorology at Uppsala University and responsible for Uppsala University's weather observations.Are these the oldest weather observations in Sweden?– Yes, that's it.But the information that appears in the NT article, can't it be true anyway?– It may be that they are correct. But this is just a snapshot, scattered years. Even if they were correct as individual weather observations, they say nothing about what it looks like over time. Landsbygden has collected the following rather unusual statistics about mild winters:In 1172 the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January and the birds built their nests and moulted in February.In 1241 the trees were fully leafed out in March, i.e. six weeks earlier than usual.In 1269 there was no winter at all, the temperature was so warm that the girls in the Rhine region could adorn themselves with violet wreaths at Christmas time.In 1289 there was no winter either and the temperature was as mild as the latter year at the same time. In1421 the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.In 1538 the gardens were in full bloom in December.In 1572 the trees already bore leaves in February, just like in 1172.In 1588 the trees were green in February.In 1538, 1607 and 1659 there was neither snow nor frost.In 1601 and 1609 there was no winter in southern Germany.In 1662 the winter was so mild that even in northern Germany people did not light fires in tiled stoves and the trees bloomed in February.In 1722 all the trees were green in February.In 1807 Bore did not come to visit at all.In 1834 the winter was as mild as the last mentioned.In 1863 in Skåne you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February. headline: Green trees in February 1722 not proof of climate change
summary: An old newspaper clipping about green trees in the spring of 1722 is making the rounds on social media, but the content doesn't mean what the spreaders seem to think. And the source turns out to be suspiciously similar to another text - which is about Germany.
text: This is the fact-check :For several years, a newspaper clipping with the headline “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green” has been circulating among climate skeptics on social media. And when we dig deeper into the archives, it turns out that large parts of the text aren't even about Swedish conditions – but about the weather in Germany.Post on Facebook with the image April 23, 2024.This is the text in what appears to be a photocopied newspaper article:  In February 1722, all the trees were completely green  . There have certainly been mild winters in the past. Gunnar Carlberg, who is also SMHI's precipitation monitor in Finspång, has looked through old scrapbooks and found the following interesting statistics:  In 1172, the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January. The birds built their nests and molted in February.  In 1241, the trees were fully leafed out in March.  In 1269, there was no winter at all.  In 1421, the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.  In 1538, the trees in the gardens were in full bloom already in December!  In 1585, the corn was in ear at Easter time.  In 1588, the trees turned green in February.  In 1538, 1607, 1617, 1650 and 1659, there was neither snow nor frost.  In 1722, all the trees were green in February.  In 1863, in Skåne, you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February. chatgpt_generation: No, Trees Weren’t Green in February 1722—Viral Clipping Misrepresents Historical Weather and Climate Science
chatgpt_condensation: A viral newspaper clipping often cited by climate skeptics claims that Swedish trees were fully green in February 1722—proof, they say, that extreme weather is nothing new. But a closer look reveals the story is based on anecdotal and misattributed sources—mainly old reports from Germany—making the claim misleading and irrelevant to today’s climate science.
chatgpt_evaluation: 1. What is the claim being verified? That a newspaper clipping stating “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green” is credible evidence that extreme weather events—such as unusually warm winters—occurred long before modern climate change, thereby casting doubt on the role of human activity in today’s global warming. 2. What is the final verdict? False. 3. What evidence or reasoning supports this verdict?  The clipping originated from a local Swedish newspaper in 1989 (NT – Norrköpings Tidningar), but the content appears to be a reworked version of a 1944 article from the U.S.-based Swedish-language paper Vestkusten, which mostly referred to historical weather anecdotes from Germany—not Sweden.  The article attributes the information to a “precipitation monitor” at SMHI, but no such official role existed, and there is no record of the named person working for the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute.  Many of the weather claims predate any formal weather observation systems in Sweden, which only began in 1722, making them unverifiable.  The claims are isolated anecdotes rather than part of a consistent, scientific climate record and therefore cannot be used to make conclusions about historical climate trends.  Experts confirm that while natural climate variation exists, the current trend of global warming—especially since 1980—is clearly linked to human-caused greenhouse gas emissions, as shown by long-term scientific measurements and consensus among climate researchers.
gemini_generation: False: Viral Green Trees in February 1722 Clipping Misleads on Climate History
gemini_condensation: A circulating newspaper clipping, claiming that In February 1722, all the trees were completely green and presenting a list of historical mild winters, has been used by climate skeptics to argue against human-caused climate change. This claim is false. The article's content is largely an unreliable anecdote, with significant portions referring to German weather, not Swedish conditions, and the original source has been misrepresented to appear as an official Swedish meteorological report.
gemini_evaluation: Here's the verdict of the fact-check: 1. What is the claim being verified? The claim being verified is that a newspaper clipping stating In February 1722, all the trees were completely green and listing other historical mild winters proves that the climate has always varied significantly due to natural factors, thereby contradicting the idea that human activity is causing current global warming. 2. What is the final verdict? False. 3. What evidence or reasoning supports this verdict?  Misleading Origin and Attribution: The newspaper clipping from Norrköpings Tidningar (NT) in 1989, which is widely circulated, is largely a re-edited version of an older article from a 1944 Swedish-American newspaper called Vestkusten. The Vestkusten article itself sourced its information from another publication, likely Svenska Landsbygden.  Fabricated Source (in NT article): The NT article attributes the statistics to a Gunnar Carlberg, described as an SMHI's precipitation monitor. However, SMHI (the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute) has no record of a Gunnar Carlberg working in that capacity, and the job of a precipitation monitor does not involve historical climate analysis. This suggests a deliberate misrepresentation of the source to lend authority to the claims.  Irrelevant to Climate Change: The historical anecdotes, even if individually accurate, are isolated weather observations, not long-term climate data. Climate science requires continuous, longer time series and broader geographical areas to describe changes. These isolated snapshots do not provide evidence about long-term climate trends or variations.  Geographical Misdirection: A significant portion of the original 1944 text (and by extension, the 1989 NT article) refers to weather conditions in Germany, not Sweden. The 1989 NT article omits these geographical references, making it appear as if the information pertains entirely to Sweden, which is misleading.  Scientific Consensus on Human Influence: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) unequivocally states that human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system. Global average temperatures have increased faster since 1970 than in any other 50-year period for at least the last 2,000 years, and this warming is primarily attributed to anthropogenic greenhouse gases. While natural climate variations exist, they do not explain the rapid warming observed since 1980.  Lack of Early Measurement Data: Many of the historical dates cited (e.g., 1172, 1241) predate the invention of modern weather measuring tools and the oldest systematic weather observations in Sweden, which began in Uppsala in 1722. This further undermines the scientific validity of the statistics.
