headline: Green trees in February 1722 not proof of climate change
summary: An old newspaper clipping about green trees in the spring of 1722 is making the rounds on social media, but the content doesn't mean what the spreaders seem to think. And the source turns out to be suspiciously similar to another text - which is about Germany.
text: This is the fact-check :For several years, a newspaper clipping with the headline “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green” has been circulating among climate skeptics on social media. The Source Criticism Agency is investigating the origin of the image – and the truth behind its content.It turns out that the anecdotal article doesn't actually say anything about the climate. And when we dig deeper into the archives, it turns out that large parts of the text aren't even about Swedish conditions – but about the weather in Germany.Post on Facebook with the image April 23, 2024.This is the text in what appears to be a photocopied newspaper article:  In February 1722, all the trees were completely green  . There have certainly been mild winters in the past. Gunnar Carlberg, who is also SMHI's precipitation monitor in Finspång, has looked through old scrapbooks and found the following interesting statistics:  In 1172, the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January. The birds built their nests and molted in February.  In 1241, the trees were fully leafed out in March.  In 1269, there was no winter at all.  In 1421, the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.  In 1538, the trees in the gardens were in full bloom already in December!  In 1585, the corn was in ear at Easter time.  In 1588, the trees turned green in February.  In 1538, 1607, 1617, 1650 and 1659, there was neither snow nor frost.  In 1722, all the trees were green in February.  In 1863, in Skåne, you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February.  NT Wednesday, February 15, 1989 The source criticism agency begins by examining the context in which the image was shared. The first post we find is from 2015 on the blog Klimatupplysningen, which is run by Klimatrealisterna, formerly the Stockholm Initiative. In 2010, the lobby group Stockholm Initiative was named Misleader of the Year by the public education association Vetenskap och Folkbildning . In the book “Upphettning: demokratin i klimatkrisens tid” (published in 2020 by the publisher Fri tanke), the Climate Realists are identified as “the hub of the Swedish denial movement”.  It was on Christmas Eve 2015 that Klimatupplysningen posted the image, stating that it came from a reader. The blog post has 112 comments.Commentary on Klimatupplysningen's blog post 2015.However, it will take five years for the image to truly go viral. Most of the shares we find are from 2020. The newspaper clipping appears on Twitter/X, Facebook and blogs that are skeptical of climate research. The fact that the picture is gaining momentum in the spring of 2020 is probably due to the fact that the spring was warmer and drier than normal that year, according to SMHI's measurements. In the cities of Gothenburg, Nordkoster, Visby and Hoburg, records were broken in the number of hours of sunshine. Weather and climate were on people's lips.But now it's spring again and the latest sharing we can find of the picture is from last week. A man writes on Facebook:It's time to let go of the lies that people's way of life affects the climate... The climate has always varied and this depends, among other things, on the activities of the sun...The post has over 500 interactions on Facebook. “This is something for all our almost religious climate activists to read,” writes one person in the comments section.But is what the post writer claims really true?No, the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) writes in its latest report that “human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system”. It is also “unequivocal that human influence has warmed the atmosphere, the ocean and the land”. “The global average temperature has increased faster since 1970 than during any other 50-year period for at least the last 2,000 years.”– According to the UN's climate panel IPCC, the global warming that has occurred since 1980 is mainly caused by anthropogenic greenhouse gases, i.e. the greenhouse gases that humans have added to the atmosphere. But that does not mean that there are also other natural climate variations, explains Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.We will return to the science later in the article.The newspaper article from 1989The content of the NT article itself has been quoted by climate skeptics in several editorial media. For example, in articles in the Länstidningen (LT) in Östersund and on the debate page of the newspaper Norra Skånes .But what does the image of the article actually prove? Our review is not going to show much at all.We start with the authenticity of the material. With the naked eye, you can see that the image appears to have been scanned and appears to consist of two parts cut together. A date from the newspaper, “NT Wednesday 5 February 1989” and the news text itself. NT is short for Norrköpings Tidningar, a newspaper founded in 1758 and now Sweden’s oldest daily newspaper still in publication.A number of larger libraries in Sweden have old Swedish newspapers preserved on microfilm.Carolina Rediviva. Photo: Dr. Mirko Junge/Wikimedia commonsAt the Carolina Rediviva University Library in Uppsala, we check to see if an article with the headline In February 1722 all the trees were completely green was published in the NT on February 15, 1989. And yes, it was.On the local pages for Finspång in NT there is the article, also not signed with a name, just like in the viral image. It is therefore some kind of local news article, but the text has an unusually slangy form for newspaper prose. No quotes, just lists of different years.SMHI's “precipitation monitor”The only source reference in the article is to a Gunnar Carlberg who is stated to be a so-called precipitation monitor for SMHI in Finspång. The title is so unusual that the only results we get when we google “precipitation monitor” are back to the NT article from 1989.There are also no notes at SMHI about a Gunnar Carlberg who worked for the authority. However, there is an Inez Carlberg who was a precipitation observer in Finspång in the 80s.– You can imagine that Gunnar was Inez's husband and that they ran the weather station together, muses Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.According to the article, Gunnar is said to have “looked through old music albums and found the following interesting statistics.” It may sound like Gunnar did this in his capacity as a member of some role at SMHI, but that is not the case, states Sverker Hellström.Post on Facebook with the newspaper article 2020.A precipitation monitor checks the rain gauge once a day, but the job does not involve any further analysis of the weather and wind – and certainly not going back in time. Gunnar (or someone else) would have collected his clips as a private person, not as an employee of SMHI.– You might get the feeling that the information in the article comes from SMHI, but that is not the case, says Sverker Hellström to Källkritikbyrån.Which clip albums Gunnar Carlberg would have looked at is also not clear from the NT article. The source reference itself is weak to say the least. Clip albums often refer to newspaper clippings, but the oldest Swedish newspaper, Post- och Inrikestidningar, was founded in 1645 – that is, long after several of the years mentioned in the article.Weather measurements started in 1722The NT article itself basically consists of just a list of mild seasons from different seasons. The first weather note dates back to 1172. But in 1172 no weather measurements were made in Sweden.Comment on Facebook March 13.It was also only in the 17th and 18th centuries that humans invented measuring tools for temperature and climate. And the oldest Swedish weather observations in Sweden date back to 1722. They were made at the weather station in Uppsala.– The measurement series began in 1722 and it was professors Anders Celsius and Eric Burman who initiated them, says Erik Sahlée, senior lecturer in meteorology at Uppsala University and responsible for Uppsala University's weather observations.Are these the oldest weather observations in Sweden?– Yes, that's it.But the information that appears in the NT article, can't it be true anyway?– It may be that they are correct. But this is just a snapshot, scattered years. Even if they were correct as individual weather observations, they say nothing about what it looks like over time. A weather station's data for a certain year says nothing about what the climate was like. Here, you jump from year to year and do not describe any longer measurement series, says Erik Sahlée.Search result on Pettersson's blog 2018.The weather notes in the text actually say nothing about the climate, but describe local weather at a certain time. And the question is, are they even about Swedish conditions?From a magazine for American SwedesA private individual conducted his own viral review of the image in January 2020 in a local Facebook group. He believes that the article text comes from a clip from March 2, 1944, from the newspaper Vestkusten, a weekly newspaper for Swedes on the Pacific coast.Comment on Facebook January 5, 2020.According to Wikipedia, Vestkusten is actually a newspaper that existed. It was originally a Swedish-language newspaper that was published in California from 1887 to 2007. The newspaper is preserved in digital form at the California Digital Newspaper Collection .Peace talks, bombing raids and ration cards are some of the topics covered on the newspaper's front page on March 2, 1944. There is still full-scale war in Europe and between the USA and Japan.Vestkusten front page March 2, 1944We search through article by article in the digitized newspaper – and a few pages in we actually find a text that is confusingly similar to that published in the NT.This is what Vestkusten writes:Speaking of the mild winter, Sv. Landsbygden has collected the following rather unusual statistics about mild winters:In 1172 the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January and the birds built their nests and moulted in February.In 1241 the trees were fully leafed out in March, i.e. six weeks earlier than usual.In 1269 there was no winter at all, the temperature was so warm that the girls in the Rhine region could adorn themselves with violet wreaths at Christmas time.In 1289 there was no winter either and the temperature was as mild as the latter year at the same time. In1421 the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.In 1538 the gardens were in full bloom in December.In 1572 the trees already bore leaves in February, just like in 1172.In 1588 the trees were green in February.In 1538, 1607 and 1659 there was neither snow nor frost.In 1601 and 1609 there was no winter in southern Germany.In 1662 the winter was so mild that even in northern Germany people did not light fires in tiled stoves and the trees bloomed in February.In 1722 all the trees were green in February.In 1807 Bore did not come to visit at all.In 1834 the winter was as mild as the last mentioned.In 1863 in Skåne you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February. In 1870 New Year's Day was celebrated in Petersburg at a temperature of eight degrees.From the newspaper Vestkusten, March 2, 1944It is largely the same text that was published in NT 45 years later. But here the reference is to Sv. Landsbygden and not to any rainfall monitor in Finspång. Sv. Landsbygden is probably short for the newspaper Svenska Landsbygden. We have received confirmation from the Royal Library (KB) that the newspaper existed at this time.About German weatherFurthermore, the text in the West Coast is somewhat longer than that in the NT, and several of the dates refer to conditions in Germany.– It is not clear in the NT article that the notes come from any particular place. In 1863 it says about Skåne itself and then we had started our own measurements. But otherwise it does not say where it took place, so it could be in Germany, says Sverker Hellström at SMHI.According to SMHI's records, the average temperature in Skåne in January and February 1863 was plus degrees.– It was certainly experienced as warm then. But if you compare it to today, for example, the average temperature in Lund in 2020 was three degrees warmer than it was in 1863.The information in the form of a submission in Folkbladet 2022 .We cannot say for sure if it is the same text that is reused in the NT, but there is much evidence to suggest so. Both we ourselves and the Google AI service NootbookLM have difficulty finding differences between the texts.It seems as if someone has taken the original text and edited out certain years, as well as all information about Germany. And suddenly a new story about Swedish springs and winters has been created. A story that is not entirely true – and which is now being used to mislead on the internet.Climate change and weatherSo what was it like now, is there a difference between climate and weather?– Yes, there is a difference between climate and weather. I usually make the following analogy: the climate tells you what clothes to bring and the weather tells you what clothes to wear. The climate is what you expect and the weather is what you get. A climate has a natural weather variation and the variations become larger if we look at a smaller area, says Erik Sahlée at Uppsala University.Comment on Facebook March 13.To describe changes in the climate, weather observations from continuous, longer time series and larger geographical areas are needed. These also exist.– If you look up and compile what we have seen across Europe and the world, the warming global trend is not something to discuss. That it is happening as a result of human influence is also not something to discuss. Now we need to start talking about what we should do about climate change instead – and how we can adapt.How do we know that climate change is due to human influence?– Physics shows that. When you just look at how natural factors affect global temperature, you don't get as strong a warming as we have. We humans have created that amplification.Overall: Many have used the image to contradict the idea that humans are behind the global warming that is currently taking place. But according to research, it is people's way of life that has affected the climate.And as for the photographed article itself, it turned out to have made a remarkable journey across media of different times. An article about German weather from the 1940s was remade in the Swedish local press in the 1980s into something that appears to apply to Sweden and that appears to come from a representative of SMHI – to finally spin around as a screenshot on Facebook in the 2020s.

Isolated warm winters do not negate the overall trend of global warming. With the naked eye, you can see that the image appears to have been scanned and appears to consist of two parts cut together. A date from the newspaper, “NT Wednesday 5 February 1989” and the news text itself. NT is short for Norrköpings Tidningar, a newspaper founded in 1758 and now Sweden’s oldest daily newspaper still in publication.A number of larger libraries in Sweden have old Swedish newspapers preserved on microfilm.Carolina Rediviva. Photo: Dr. Mirko Junge/Wikimedia commonsAt the Carolina Rediviva University Library in Uppsala, we check to see if an article with the headline In February 1722 all the trees were completely green was published in the NT on February 15, 1989. And yes, it was.On the local pages for Finspång in NT there is the article, also not signed with a name, just like in the viral image. It is therefore some kind of local news article, but the text has an unusually slangy form for newspaper prose. No quotes, just lists of different years.SMHI's “precipitation monitor”The only source reference in the article is to a Gunnar Carlberg who is stated to be a so-called precipitation monitor for SMHI in Finspång. The title is so unusual that the only results we get when we google “precipitation monitor” are back to the NT article from 1989.There are also no notes at SMHI about a Gunnar Carlberg who worked for the authority. However, there is an Inez Carlberg who was a precipitation observer in Finspång in the 80s.– You can imagine that Gunnar was Inez's husband and that they ran the weather station together, muses Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.According to the article, Gunnar is said to have “looked through old music albums and found the following interesting statistics.” It may sound like Gunnar did this in his capacity as a member of some role at SMHI, but that is not the case, states Sverker Hellström.Post on Facebook with the newspaper article 2020.A precipitation monitor checks the rain gauge once a day, but the job does not involve any further analysis of the weather and wind – and certainly not going back in time. Gunnar (or someone else) would have collected his clips as a private person, not as an employee of SMHI.– You might get the feeling that the information in the article comes from SMHI, but that is not the case, says Sverker Hellström to Källkritikbyrån.Which clip albums Gunnar Carlberg would have looked at is also not clear from the NT article. The source reference itself is weak to say the least. Clip albums often refer to newspaper clippings, but the oldest Swedish newspaper, Post- och Inrikestidningar, was founded in 1645 – that is, long after several of the years mentioned in the article.Weather measurements started in 1722The NT article itself basically consists of just a list of mild seasons from different seasons. The first weather note dates back to 1172. But in 1172 no weather measurements were made in Sweden.Comment on Facebook March 13.It was also only in the 17th and 18th centuries that humans invented measuring tools for temperature and climate. And the oldest Swedish weather observations in Sweden date back to 1722. They were made at the weather station in Uppsala.– The measurement series began in 1722 and it was professors Anders Celsius and Eric Burman who initiated them, says Erik Sahlée, senior lecturer in meteorology at Uppsala University and responsible for Uppsala University's weather observations.Are these the oldest weather observations in Sweden?– Yes, that's it.But the information that appears in the NT article, can't it be true anyway?– It may be that they are correct. But this is just a snapshot, scattered years. Even if they were correct as individual weather observations, they say nothing about what it looks like over time. A weather station's data for a certain year says nothing about what the climate was like. Here, you jump from year to year and do not describe any longer measurement series, says Erik Sahlée.Search result on Pettersson's blog 2018.The weather notes in the text actually say nothing about the climate, but describe local weather at a certain time. And the question is, are they even about Swedish conditions?From a magazine for American SwedesA private individual conducted his own viral review of the image in January 2020 in a local Facebook group. He believes that the article text comes from a clip from March 2, 1944, from the newspaper Vestkusten, a weekly newspaper for Swedes on the Pacific coast.Comment on Facebook January 5, 2020.According to Wikipedia, Vestkusten is actually a newspaper that existed. It was originally a Swedish-language newspaper that was published in California from 1887 to 2007. The newspaper is preserved in digital form at the California Digital Newspaper Collection .Peace talks, bombing raids and ration cards are some of the topics covered on the newspaper's front page on March 2, 1944. There is still full-scale war in Europe and between the USA and Japan.Vestkusten front page March 2, 1944We search through article by article in the digitized newspaper – and a few pages in we actually find a text that is confusingly similar to that published in the NT.This is what Vestkusten writes:Speaking of the mild winter, Sv. Landsbygden has collected the following rather unusual statistics about mild winters:In 1172 the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January and the birds built their nests and moulted in February.In 1241 the trees were fully leafed out in March, i.e. six weeks earlier than usual.In 1269 there was no winter at all, the temperature was so warm that the girls in the Rhine region could adorn themselves with violet wreaths at Christmas time.In 1289 there was no winter either and the temperature was as mild as the latter year at the same time. In1421 the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.In 1538 the gardens were in full bloom in December.In 1572 the trees already bore leaves in February, just like in 1172.In 1588 the trees were green in February.In 1538, 1607 and 1659 there was neither snow nor frost.In 1601 and 1609 there was no winter in southern Germany.In 1662 the winter was so mild that even in northern Germany people did not light fires in tiled stoves and the trees bloomed in February.In 1722 all the trees were green in February.In 1807 Bore did not come to visit at all.In 1834 the winter was as mild as the last mentioned.In 1863 in Skåne you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February. In 1870 New Year's Day was celebrated in Petersburg at a temperature of eight degrees.From the newspaper Vestkusten, March 2, 1944It is largely the same text that was published in NT 45 years later. But here the reference is to Sv. Landsbygden and not to any rainfall monitor in Finspång. Sv. Landsbygden is probably short for the newspaper Svenska Landsbygden. We have received confirmation from the Royal Library (KB) that the newspaper existed at this time.About German weatherFurthermore, the text in the West Coast is somewhat longer than that in the NT, and several of the dates refer to conditions in Germany.– It is not clear in the NT article that the notes come from any particular place. In 1863 it says about Skåne itself and then we had started our own measurements. But otherwise it does not say where it took place, so it could be in Germany, says Sverker Hellström at SMHI.According to SMHI's records, the average temperature in Skåne in January and February 1863 was plus degrees.– It was certainly experienced as warm then. But if you compare it to today, for example, the average temperature in Lund in 2020 was three degrees warmer than it was in 1863.The information in the form of a submission in Folkbladet 2022 .We cannot say for sure if it is the same text that is reused in the NT, but there is much evidence to suggest so. Both we ourselves and the Google AI service NootbookLM have difficulty finding differences between the texts.It seems as if someone has taken the original text and edited out certain years, as well as all information about Germany. And suddenly a new story about Swedish springs and winters has been created. A story that is not entirely true – and which is now being used to mislead on the internet.Climate change and weatherSo what was it like now, is there a difference between climate and weather?– Yes, there is a difference between climate and weather. I usually make the following analogy: the climate tells you what clothes to bring and the weather tells you what clothes to wear. The climate is what you expect and the weather is what you get. A climate has a natural weather variation and the variations become larger if we look at a smaller area, says Erik Sahlée at Uppsala University.Comment on Facebook March 13.To describe changes in the climate, weather observations from continuous, longer time series and larger geographical areas are needed. These also exist.– If you look up and compile what we have seen across Europe and the world, the warming global trend is not something to discuss. That it is happening as a result of human influence is also not something to discuss. Now we need to start talking about what we should do about climate change instead – and how we can adapt.How do we know that climate change is due to human influence?– Physics shows that. When you just look at how natural factors affect global temperature, you don't get as strong a warming as we have. We humans have created that amplification.Overall: Many have used the image to contradict the idea that humans are behind the global warming that is currently taking place. But according to research, it is people's way of life that has affected the climate.And as for the photographed article itself, it turned out to have made a remarkable journey across media of different times. An article about German weather from the 1940s was remade in the Swedish local press in the 1980s into something that appears to apply to Sweden and that appears to come from a representative of SMHI – to finally spin around as a screenshot on Facebook in the 2020s.

grok_condensation: A viral newspaper clipping claiming mild winters in Sweden, dating back to 1172, has been used by climate skeptics to argue that climate change is natural, but the article is misleading, primarily referencing German weather and lacking credible climate data. grok_evaluation: 1. Claim Being Assessed: The claim, circulated by climate skeptics on social media, is that a newspaper clipping from 1989, listing mild winters in various years (e.g., 1172, 1722), demonstrates that significant climate variations, such as trees turning green in February, have occurred naturally in Sweden for centuries, implying that current global warming is not primarily caused by human activity but is instead part of natural climate variability driven by factors like solar activity. 2. Verdict: False. 3. Reasoning and Evidence Supporting the Conclusion: - Misleading Origin and Context: The newspaper clipping, published in Norrköpings Tidningar (NT) on February 15, 1989, is authentic but misleading. It was found to be largely derived from a 1944 article in Vestkusten, a Swedish-American newspaper, which primarily described weather conditions in Germany, not Sweden. The NT article omits references to Germany, creating a false impression that the listed weather events occurred in Sweden. - Lack of Credible Source: The NT article attributes the information to Gunnar Carlberg, described as an SMHI precipitation monitor in Finspång. However, SMHI has no record of a Gunnar Carlberg, and the role of a precipitation monitor does not involve historical weather analysis. The cited clip albums are vague and unreliable, as no Swedish weather records exist for many of the years mentioned (e.g., 1172), and systematic weather measurements in Sweden only began in 1722 in Uppsala. - Weather vs. Climate Misrepresentation: The article lists isolated weather events (e.g., mild winters or early blooming) without providing continuous data or context, which is insufficient to draw conclusions about climate trends. Climate requires long-term, systematic data over large areas, whereas the clipping describes sporadic, local weather anomalies, some of which pertain to Germany. - Scientific Consensus Contradicted: The claim that natural factors like solar activity drive current climate variations is refuted by the IPCC’s latest report, which states that human-induced greenhouse gas emissions have “unequivocally warmed the climate system” and that global warming since 1970 is unprecedented in at least 2,000 years. Natural factors alone cannot account for the observed warming trend, as confirmed by physics-based climate models. - Viral Misuse: The clipping has been shared on platforms like Klimatupplysningen (2015) and Facebook (2020, 2024) by climate skeptic groups, such as Klimatrealisterna, to misleadingly argue against human-driven climate change. The selective editing of the original text and its misrepresentation as Swedish weather data further undermines its credibility. In summary, the claim is false because the article misrepresents German weather anecdotes as Swedish, lacks credible sourcing, and does not provide evidence to challenge the scientific consensus that human activities are the primary driver of current global warming.

headline: Green trees in February 1722 not proof of climate change
summary: An old newspaper clipping about green trees in the spring of 1722 is making the rounds on social media, but the content doesn't mean what the spreaders seem to think. And the source turns out to be suspiciously similar to another text - which is about Germany.
text: This is the fact-check :For several years, a newspaper clipping with the headline “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green” has been circulating among climate skeptics on social media. The Source Criticism Agency is investigating the origin of the image – and the truth behind its content.It turns out that the anecdotal article doesn't actually say anything about the climate. And when we dig deeper into the archives, it turns out that large parts of the text aren't even about Swedish conditions – but about the weather in Germany.Post on Facebook with the image April 23, 2024.This is the text in what appears to be a photocopied newspaper article:  In February 1722, all the trees were completely green  . There have certainly been mild winters in the past. Gunnar Carlberg, who is also SMHI's precipitation monitor in Finspång, has looked through old scrapbooks and found the following interesting statistics:  In 1172, the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January. The birds built their nests and molted in February.  In 1241, the trees were fully leafed out in March.  In 1269, there was no winter at all.  In 1421, the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.  In 1538, the trees in the gardens were in full bloom already in December!  In 1585, the corn was in ear at Easter time.  In 1588, the trees turned green in February.  In 1538, 1607, 1617, 1650 and 1659, there was neither snow nor frost.  In 1722, all the trees were green in February.  In 1863, in Skåne, you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February.  NT Wednesday, February 15, 1989 The source criticism agency begins by examining the context in which the image was shared. The first post we find is from 2015 on the blog Klimatupplysningen, which is run by Klimatrealisterna, formerly the Stockholm Initiative. In 2010, the lobby group Stockholm Initiative was named Misleader of the Year by the public education association Vetenskap och Folkbildning . In the book “Upphettning: demokratin i klimatkrisens tid” (published in 2020 by the publisher Fri tanke), the Climate Realists are identified as “the hub of the Swedish denial movement”.  It was on Christmas Eve 2015 that Klimatupplysningen posted the image, stating that it came from a reader. The blog post has 112 comments.Commentary on Klimatupplysningen's blog post 2015.However, it will take five years for the image to truly go viral. Most of the shares we find are from 2020. The newspaper clipping appears on Twitter/X, Facebook and blogs that are skeptical of climate research. The fact that the picture is gaining momentum in the spring of 2020 is probably due to the fact that the spring was warmer and drier than normal that year, according to SMHI's measurements. In the cities of Gothenburg, Nordkoster, Visby and Hoburg, records were broken in the number of hours of sunshine. Weather and climate were on people's lips.But now it's spring again and the latest sharing we can find of the picture is from last week. A man writes on Facebook:It's time to let go of the lies that people's way of life affects the climate... The climate has always varied and this depends, among other things, on the activities of the sun...The post has over 500 interactions on Facebook. “This is something for all our almost religious climate activists to read,” writes one person in the comments section.But is what the post writer claims really true?No, the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) writes in its latest report that “human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system”. It is also “unequivocal that human influence has warmed the atmosphere, the ocean and the land”. “The global average temperature has increased faster since 1970 than during any other 50-year period for at least the last 2,000 years.”– According to the UN's climate panel IPCC, the global warming that has occurred since 1980 is mainly caused by anthropogenic greenhouse gases, i.e. the greenhouse gases that humans have added to the atmosphere. But that does not mean that there are also other natural climate variations, explains Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.We will return to the science later in the article.The newspaper article from 1989The content of the NT article itself has been quoted by climate skeptics in several editorial media. For example, in articles in the Länstidningen (LT) in Östersund and on the debate page of the newspaper Norra Skånes .But what does the image of the article actually prove? Our review is not going to show much at all.We start with the authenticity of the material. gemini_generation: Green Trees in February 1722 Claim About Past Winters Is False, Misleading Climate Skeptics
gemini_condensation: A newspaper clipping claiming In February 1722, all the trees were completely green has been circulating among climate skeptics as evidence against human-caused climate change. This claim is largely false and misleading. The original article, published in 1989, was a re-edited version of a 1944 article from a Swedish-American newspaper, primarily discussing weather conditions in Germany, not Sweden, and presenting anecdotal observations rather than scientific climate data.
gemini_evaluation: Here's the verdict for the fact-check: 1. What is the claim? The claim, circulated by climate skeptics, is based on a newspaper clipping stating In February 1722, all the trees were completely green, implying that historical mild winters negate the idea of human-caused climate change and that the climate has always varied due to natural factors. 2. What is the final verdict? False and Misleading. 3. What evidence supports this verdict?  Misleading Origin and Content: The widely circulated image is of an article from Norrköpings Tidningar (NT) published on February 15, 1989. However, this NT article is largely a re-edited and abridged version of a much older article from Vestkusten, a Swedish-language newspaper published in California, dated March 2, 1944.  Geographical Misrepresentation: The original Vestkusten article, from which the NT article derived, explicitly refers to weather conditions in Germany for several of the historical dates (e.g., the girls in the Rhine region, no winter in southern Germany, even in northern Germany). The NT article removed these geographical references, making it appear as if all the observations were about Swedish conditions, which is not true for most of the early entries.  Unreliable Sourcing in NT: The NT article ambiguously attributes the information to a Gunnar Carlberg, stated to be an SMHI's precipitation monitor in Finspång, who supposedly looked through old scrapbooks. SMHI (Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute) confirms no record of a Gunnar Carlberg in that role, and that the job of a precipitation monitor does not involve historical climate analysis. Any collection of such data would have been done as a private person, not as an SMHI employee, and SMHI disavows the information originating from them.  Lack of Scientific Basis for Early Dates: The article lists weather observations from as early as 1172. However, organized weather measurements in Sweden (starting in Uppsala) only began in 1722. Therefore, information prior to 1722 cannot be based on systematic scientific measurements in Sweden, and the earlier notes are anecdotal.  Misinterpretation of Weather vs. Climate: The listed observations are isolated snapshots of local weather events, not continuous, long-term climate data. Meteorologists and climate scientists emphasize that individual weather events, even unusually warm ones, do not define climate trends. Climate refers to long-term patterns and averages over larger geographical areas.  Scientific Consensus on Human Influence: The article's use by climate skeptics to deny human-caused warming directly contradicts the overwhelming scientific consensus, as stated by the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The IPCC unequivocally states that human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system and that the global average temperature increase since 1970 is the fastest in at least 2,000 years, primarily due to anthropogenic greenhouse gases. Physics supports that natural factors alone cannot explain the observed warming trend; human influence creates the amplification.

Claim The claim is that a 1989 newspaper article proves Sweden experienced unusually mild winters in the past, specifically with trees being green in February 1722, implying this contradicts human influence on climate change. 2. Evidence Supporting the Verdict Origin of the Article: The article's text likely originated from a 1944 article about German weather, not Swedish conditions. Lack of Swedish Context: The article lacks clear references to Swedish weather measurements or climate data, making it inapplicable to Sweden's climate. What evidence supports this verdict? - Origin of the article: The 1989 Norrköpings Tidningar (NT) article was found to be authentic but derived from a 1944 article in Vestkusten, a Swedish-American newspaper, which discussed mild winters primarily in Germany, not Sweden. References to Germany were omitted in the NT version, creating a misleading impression of Swedish conditions. - Lack of credible sourcing: The NT article cites Gunnar Carlberg, described as an SMHI precipitation monitor, but SMHI has no record of him, and the role does not involve historical weather analysis. The source of the historical data (clip albums) is vague and unverifiable, especially for claims predating systematic weather records (e.g., 1172). - Historical weather data limitations: Systematic weather measurements in Sweden began in 1722, making claims about earlier years (e.g., 1172, 1241) unreliable. The article’s listed years are anecdotal, describing isolated weather events, not climate trends. - Scientific consensus: The IPCC’s reports confirm that human-induced greenhouse gas emissions are the primary driver of global warming since 1970, with a faster temperature increase than any 50-year period in the last 2,000 years. Natural climate variations exist but do not negate human impact. - Misuse by skeptics: The article has been shared on platforms like Klimatupplysningen (2015) and social media (2020, 2024) to argue against human-driven climate change, ignoring the distinction between weather (short-term, local) and climate (long-term, global). The text’s German origin and lack of context further undermine its relevance to the claim.

headline: Green trees in February 1722 not proof of climate change
summary: An old newspaper clipping about green trees in the spring of 1722 is making the rounds on social media, but the content doesn't mean what the spreaders seem to think. And the source turns out to be suspiciously similar to another text - which is about Germany.
text: This is the fact-check :For several years, a newspaper clipping with the headline “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green” has been circulating among climate skeptics on social media. The Source Criticism Agency is investigating the origin of the image – and the truth behind its content.It turns out that the anecdotal article doesn't actually say anything about the climate. And when we dig deeper into the archives, it turns out that large parts of the text aren't even about Swedish conditions – but about the weather in Germany.Post on Facebook with the image April 23, 2024.This is the text in what appears to be a photocopied newspaper article:  In February 1722, all the trees were completely green  . There have certainly been mild winters in the past. Gunnar Carlberg, who is also SMHI's precipitation monitor in Finspång, has looked through old scrapbooks and found the following interesting statistics:  In 1172, the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January. The birds built their nests and molted in February.  In 1241, the trees were fully leafed out in March.  In 1269, there was no winter at all.  In 1421, the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.  In 1538, the trees in the gardens were in full bloom already in December!  In 1585, the corn was in ear at Easter time.  In 1588, the trees turned green in February.  In 1538, 1607, 1617, 1650 and 1659, there was neither snow nor frost.  In 1722, all the trees were green in February.  In 1863, in Skåne, you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February.  NT Wednesday, February 15, 1989 The source criticism agency begins by examining the context in which the image was shared. The first post we find is from 2015 on the blog Klimatupplysningen, which is run by Klimatrealisterna, formerly the Stockholm Initiative. In 2010, the lobby group Stockholm Initiative was named Misleader of the Year by the public education association Vetenskap och Folkbildning . In the book “Upphettning: demokratin i klimatkrisens tid” (published in 2020 by the publisher Fri tanke), the Climate Realists are identified as “the hub of the Swedish denial movement”.  It was on Christmas Eve 2015 that Klimatupplysningen posted the image, stating that it came from a reader. The blog post has 112 comments.Commentary on Klimatupplysningen's blog post 2015.However, it will take five years for the image to truly go viral. Most of the shares we find are from 2020. The newspaper clipping appears on Twitter/X, Facebook and blogs that are skeptical of climate research. The fact that the picture is gaining momentum in the spring of 2020 is probably due to the fact that the spring was warmer and drier than normal that year, according to SMHI's measurements. In the cities of Gothenburg, Nordkoster, Visby and Hoburg, records were broken in the number of hours of sunshine. Weather and climate were on people's lips.But now it's spring again and the latest sharing we can find of the picture is from last week. A man writes on Facebook:It's time to let go of the lies that people's way of life affects the climate... The climate has always varied and this depends, among other things, on the activities of the sun...The post has over 500 interactions on Facebook. “This is something for all our almost religious climate activists to read,” writes one person in the comments section.But is what the post writer claims really true?No, the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) writes in its latest report that “human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system”. It is also “unequivocal that human influence has warmed the atmosphere, the ocean and the land”. “The global average temperature has increased faster since 1970 than during any other 50-year period for at least the last 2,000 years.”– According to the UN's climate panel IPCC, the global warming that has occurred since 1980 is mainly caused by anthropogenic greenhouse gases, i.e. the greenhouse gases that humans have added to the atmosphere. But that does not mean that there are also other natural climate variations, explains Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.We will return to the science later in the article.The newspaper article from 1989The content of the NT article itself has been quoted by climate skeptics in several editorial media. For example, in articles in the Länstidningen (LT) in Östersund and on the debate page of the newspaper Norra Skånes .But what does the image of the article actually prove? Our review is not going to show much at all.We start with the authenticity of the material. With the naked eye, you can see that the image appears to have been scanned and appears to consist of two parts cut together. A date from the newspaper, “NT Wednesday 5 February 1989” and the news text itself. NT is short for Norrköpings Tidningar, a newspaper founded in 1758 and now Sweden’s oldest daily newspaper still in publication.A number of larger libraries in Sweden have old Swedish newspapers preserved on microfilm.Carolina Rediviva. Photo: Dr. Mirko Junge/Wikimedia commonsAt the Carolina Rediviva University Library in Uppsala, we check to see if an article with the headline In February 1722 all the trees were completely green was published in the NT on February 15, 1989. And yes, it was.On the local pages for Finspång in NT there is the article, also not signed with a name, just like in the viral image. It is therefore some kind of local news article, but the text has an unusually slangy form for newspaper prose. No quotes, just lists of different years.SMHI's “precipitation monitor”The only source reference in the article is to a Gunnar Carlberg who is stated to be a so-called precipitation monitor for SMHI in Finspång. The title is so unusual that the only results we get when we google “precipitation monitor” are back to the NT article from 1989.There are also no notes at SMHI about a Gunnar Carlberg who worked for the authority. However, there is an Inez Carlberg who was a precipitation observer in Finspång in the 80s.– You can imagine that Gunnar was Inez's husband and that they ran the weather station together, muses Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.According to the article, Gunnar is said to have “looked through old music albums and found the following interesting statistics.” It may sound like Gunnar did this in his capacity as a member of some role at SMHI, but that is not the case, states Sverker Hellström.Post on Facebook with the newspaper article 2020.A precipitation monitor checks the rain gauge once a day, but the job does not involve any further analysis of the weather and wind – and certainly not going back in time. Gunnar (or someone else) would have collected his clips as a private person, not as an employee of SMHI.– You might get the feeling that the information in the article comes from SMHI, but that is not the case, says Sverker Hellström to Källkritikbyrån.Which clip albums Gunnar Carlberg would have looked at is also not clear from the NT article. The source reference itself is weak to say the least. Clip albums often refer to newspaper clippings, but the oldest Swedish newspaper, Post- och Inrikestidningar, was founded in 1645 – that is, long after several of the years mentioned in the article.Weather measurements started in 1722The NT article itself basically consists of just a list of mild seasons from different seasons. The first weather note dates back to 1172. But in 1172 no weather measurements were made in Sweden.Comment on Facebook March 13.It was also only in the 17th and 18th centuries that humans invented measuring tools for temperature and climate. And the oldest Swedish weather observations in Sweden date back to 1722. They were made at the weather station in Uppsala.– The measurement series began in 1722 and it was professors Anders Celsius and Eric Burman who initiated them, says Erik Sahlée, senior lecturer in meteorology at Uppsala University and responsible for Uppsala University's weather observations.Are these the oldest weather observations in Sweden?– Yes, that's it.But the information that appears in the NT article, can't it be true anyway?– It may be that they are correct. But this is just a snapshot, scattered years. Even if they were correct as individual weather observations, they say nothing about what it looks like over time. A weather station's data for a certain year says nothing about what the climate was like. Here, you jump from year to year and do not describe any longer measurement series, says Erik Sahlée.Search result on Pettersson's blog 2018.The weather notes in the text actually say nothing about the climate, but describe local weather at a certain time. And the question is, are they even about Swedish conditions?From a magazine for American SwedesA private individual conducted his own viral review of the image in January 2020 in a local Facebook group. He believes that the article text comes from a clip from March 2, 1944, from the newspaper Vestkusten, a weekly newspaper for Swedes on the Pacific coast.Comment on Facebook January 5, 2020.According to Wikipedia, Vestkusten is actually a newspaper that existed. It was originally a Swedish-language newspaper that was published in California from 1887 to 2007. The newspaper is preserved in digital form at the California Digital Newspaper Collection .Peace talks, bombing raids and ration cards are some of the topics covered on the newspaper's front page on March 2, 1944. There is still full-scale war in Europe and between the USA and Japan.Vestkusten front page March 2, 1944We search through article by article in the digitized newspaper – and a few pages in we actually find a text that is confusingly similar to that published in the NT.This is what Vestkusten writes:Speaking of the mild winter, Sv. Landsbygden has collected the following rather unusual statistics about mild winters:In 1172 the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January and the birds built their nests and moulted in February.In 1241 the trees were fully leafed out in March, i.e. six weeks earlier than usual.In 1269 there was no winter at all, the temperature was so warm that the girls in the Rhine region could adorn themselves with violet wreaths at Christmas time.In 1289 there was no winter either and the temperature was as mild as the latter year at the same time. In1421 the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.In 1538 the gardens were in full bloom in December.In 1572 the trees already bore leaves in February, just like in 1172.In 1588 the trees were green in February.In 1538, 1607 and 1659 there was neither snow nor frost.In 1601 and 1609 there was no winter in southern Germany.In 1662 the winter was so mild that even in northern Germany people did not light fires in tiled stoves and the trees bloomed in February.In 1722 all the trees were green in February.In 1807 Bore did not come to visit at all.In 1834 the winter was as mild as the last mentioned.In 1863 in Skåne you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February. In 1870 New Year's Day was celebrated in Petersburg at a temperature of eight degrees.From the newspaper Vestkusten, March 2, 1944It is largely the same text that was published in NT 45 years later. But here the reference is to Sv. Landsbygden and not to any rainfall monitor in Finspång. Sv. Landsbygden is probably short for the newspaper Svenska Landsbygden. We have received confirmation from the Royal Library (KB) that the newspaper existed at this time.About German weatherFurthermore, the text in the West Coast is somewhat longer than that in the NT, and several of the dates refer to conditions in Germany.– It is not clear in the NT article that the notes come from any particular place. In 1863 it says about Skåne itself and then we had started our own measurements. But otherwise it does not say where it took place, so it could be in Germany, says Sverker Hellström at SMHI.According to SMHI's records, the average temperature in Skåne in January and February 1863 was plus degrees.– It was certainly experienced as warm then. But if you compare it to today, for example, the average temperature in Lund in 2020 was three degrees warmer than it was in 1863.The information in the form of a submission in Folkbladet 2022 .We cannot say for sure if it is the same text that is reused in the NT, but there is much evidence to suggest so. Both we ourselves and the Google AI service NootbookLM have difficulty finding differences between the texts.It seems as if someone has taken the original text and edited out certain years, as well as all information about Germany. And suddenly a new story about Swedish springs and winters has been created. A story that is not entirely true – and which is now being used to mislead on the internet.Climate change and weatherSo what was it like now, is there a difference between climate and weather?– Yes, there is a difference between climate and weather. I usually make the following analogy: the climate tells you what clothes to bring and the weather tells you what clothes to wear. The climate is what you expect and the weather is what you get. A climate has a natural weather variation and the variations become larger if we look at a smaller area, says Erik Sahlée at Uppsala University.Comment on Facebook March 13.To describe changes in the climate, weather observations from continuous, longer time series and larger geographical areas are needed. These also exist.– If you look up and compile what we have seen across Europe and the world, the warming global trend is not something to discuss. That it is happening as a result of human influence is also not something to discuss. Now we need to start talking about what we should do about climate change instead – and how we can adapt.How do we know that climate change is due to human influence?– Physics shows that. When you just look at how natural factors affect global temperature, you don't get as strong a warming as we have. We humans have created that amplification.Overall: Many have used the image to contradict the idea that humans are behind the global warming that is currently taking place. But according to research, it is people's way of life that has affected the climate.And as for the photographed article itself, it turned out to have made a remarkable journey across media of different times. An article about German weather from the 1940s was remade in the Swedish local press in the 1980s into something that appears to apply to Sweden and that appears to come from a representative of SMHI – to finally spin around as a screenshot on Facebook in the 2020s.

headline: Green trees in February 1722 not proof of climate change
summary: An old newspaper clipping about green trees in the spring of 1722 is making the rounds on social media, but the content doesn't mean what the spreaders seem to think. And the source turns out to be suspiciously similar to another text - which is about Germany.
text: This is the fact-check :For several years, a newspaper clipping with the headline “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green” has been circulating among climate skeptics on social media. The Source Criticism Agency is investigating the origin of the image – and the truth behind its content.It turns out that the anecdotal article doesn't actually say anything about the climate. And when we dig deeper into the archives, it turns out that large parts of the text aren't even about Swedish conditions – but about the weather in Germany.Post on Facebook with the image April 23, 2024.This is the text in what appears to be a photocopied newspaper article:  In February 1722, all the trees were completely green  . There have certainly been mild winters in the past. Gunnar Carlberg, who is also SMHI's precipitation monitor in Finspång, has looked through old scrapbooks and found the following interesting statistics:  In 1172, the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January. The birds built their nests and molted in February.  In 1241, the trees were fully leafed out in March.  In 1269, there was no winter at all.  In 1421, the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.  In 1538, the trees in the gardens were in full bloom already in December!  In 1585, the corn was in ear at Easter time.  In 1588, the trees turned green in February.  In 1538, 1607, 1617, 1650 and 1659, there was neither snow nor frost.  In 1722, all the trees were green in February.  In 1863, in Skåne, you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February.  NT Wednesday, February 15, 1989 The source criticism agency begins by examining the context in which the image was shared. The first post we find is from 2015 on the blog Klimatupplysningen, which is run by Klimatrealisterna, formerly the Stockholm Initiative. In 2010, the lobby group Stockholm Initiative was named Misleader of the Year by the public education association Vetenskap och Folkbildning . In the book “Upphettning: demokratin i klimatkrisens tid” (published in 2020 by the publisher Fri tanke), the Climate Realists are identified as “the hub of the Swedish denial movement”.  It was on Christmas Eve 2015 that Klimatupplysningen posted the image, stating that it came from a reader. The blog post has 112 comments.Commentary on Klimatupplysningen's blog post 2015.However, it will take five years for the image to truly go viral. Most of the shares we find are from 2020. The newspaper clipping appears on Twitter/X, Facebook and blogs that are skeptical of climate research. The fact that the picture is gaining momentum in the spring of 2020 is probably due to the fact that the spring was warmer and drier than normal that year, according to SMHI's measurements. In the cities of Gothenburg, Nordkoster, Visby and Hoburg, records were broken in the number of hours of sunshine. Weather and climate were on people's lips.But now it's spring again and the latest sharing we can find of the picture is from last week. A man writes on Facebook:It's time to let go of the lies that people's way of life affects the climate... The climate has always varied and this depends, among other things, on the activities of the sun...The post has over 500 interactions on Facebook. “This is something for all our almost religious climate activists to read,” writes one person in the comments section.But is what the post writer claims really true?No, the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) writes in its latest report that “human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system”. It is also “unequivocal that human influence has warmed the atmosphere, the ocean and the land”. “The global average temperature has increased faster since 1970 than during any other 50-year period for at least the last 2,000 years.”– According to the UN's climate panel IPCC, the global warming that has occurred since 1980 is mainly caused by anthropogenic greenhouse gases, i.e. the greenhouse gases that humans have added to the atmosphere. But that does not mean that there are also other natural climate variations, explains Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.We will return to the science later in the article.The newspaper article from 1989The content of the NT article itself has been quoted by climate skeptics in several editorial media. For example, in articles in the Länstidningen (LT) in Östersund and on the debate page of the newspaper Norra Skånes .But what does the image of the article actually prove? Our review is not going to show much at all.We start with the authenticity of the material. With the naked eye, you can see that the image appears to have been scanned and appears to consist of two parts cut together. A date from the newspaper, “NT Wednesday 5 February 1989” and the news text itself. NT is short for Norrköpings Tidningar, a newspaper founded in 1758 and now Sweden’s oldest daily newspaper still in publication.A number of larger libraries in Sweden have old Swedish newspapers preserved on microfilm.Carolina Rediviva. Photo: Dr. Mirko Junge/Wikimedia commonsAt the Carolina Rediviva University Library in Uppsala, we check to see if an article with the headline In February 1722 all the trees were completely green was published in the NT on February 15, 1989. And yes, it was.On the local pages for Finspång in NT there is the article, also not signed with a name, just like in the viral image. It is therefore some kind of local news article, but the text has an unusually slangy form for newspaper prose. No quotes, just lists of different years.SMHI's “precipitation monitor”The only source reference in the article is to a Gunnar Carlberg who is stated to be a so-called precipitation monitor for SMHI in Finspång. The title is so unusual that the only results we get when we google “precipitation monitor” are back to the NT article from 1989.There are also no notes at SMHI about a Gunnar Carlberg who worked for the authority. However, there is an Inez Carlberg who was a precipitation observer in Finspång in the 80s.– You can imagine that Gunnar was Inez's husband and that they ran the weather station together, muses Sverker Hellström, meteorologist at SMHI.According to the article, Gunnar is said to have “looked through old music albums and found the following interesting statistics.” It may sound like Gunnar did this in his capacity as a member of some role at SMHI, but that is not the case, states Sverker Hellström.Post on Facebook with the newspaper article 2020.A precipitation monitor checks the rain gauge once a day, but the job does not involve any further analysis of the weather and wind – and certainly not going back in time. Gunnar (or someone else) would have collected his clips as a private person, not as an employee of SMHI.– You might get the feeling that the information in the article comes from SMHI, but that is not the case, says Sverker Hellström to Källkritikbyrån.Which clip albums Gunnar Carlberg would have looked at is also not clear from the NT article. The source reference itself is weak to say the least. Clip albums often refer to newspaper clippings, but the oldest Swedish newspaper, Post- och Inrikestidningar, was founded in 1645 – that is, long after several of the years mentioned in the article.Weather measurements started in 1722The NT article itself basically consists of just a list of mild seasons from different seasons. The first weather note dates back to 1172. But in 1172 no weather measurements were made in Sweden.Comment on Facebook March 13.It was also only in the 17th and 18th centuries that humans invented measuring tools for temperature and climate. And the oldest Swedish weather observations in Sweden date back to 1722. They were made at the weather station in Uppsala.– The measurement series began in 1722 and it was professors Anders Celsius and Eric Burman who initiated them, says Erik Sahlée, senior lecturer in meteorology at Uppsala University and responsible for Uppsala University's weather observations.Are these the oldest weather observations in Sweden?– Yes, that's it.But the information that appears in the NT article, can't it be true anyway?– It may be that they are correct. But this is just a snapshot, scattered years. Even if they were correct as individual weather observations, they say nothing about what it looks like over time. A weather station's data for a certain year says nothing about what the climate was like. Here, you jump from year to year and do not describe any longer measurement series, says Erik Sahlée.Search result on Pettersson's blog 2018.The weather notes in the text actually say nothing about the climate, but describe local weather at a certain time. And the question is, are they even about Swedish conditions?From a magazine for American SwedesA private individual conducted his own viral review of the image in January 2020 in a local Facebook group. He believes that the article text comes from a clip from March 2, 1944, from the newspaper Vestkusten, a weekly newspaper for Swedes on the Pacific coast.Comment on Facebook January 5, 2020.According to Wikipedia, Vestkusten is actually a newspaper that existed. It was originally a Swedish-language newspaper that was published in California from 1887 to 2007. The newspaper is preserved in digital form at the California Digital Newspaper Collection .Peace talks, bombing raids and ration cards are some of the topics covered on the newspaper's front page on March 2, 1944. There is still full-scale war in Europe and between the USA and Japan.Vestkusten front page March 2, 1944We search through article by article in the digitized newspaper – and a few pages in we actually find a text that is confusingly similar to that published in the NT.This is what Vestkusten writes:Speaking of the mild winter, Sv. Landsbygden has collected the following rather unusual statistics about mild winters:In 1172 the winter was so mild that the trees turned green at the end of January and the birds built their nests and moulted in February.In 1241 the trees were fully leafed out in March, i.e. six weeks earlier than usual.In 1269 there was no winter at all, the temperature was so warm that the girls in the Rhine region could adorn themselves with violet wreaths at Christmas time.In 1289 there was no winter either and the temperature was as mild as the latter year at the same time. In1421 the trees bloomed in March and the vines in April, when there were also ripe gooseberries.In 1538 the gardens were in full bloom in December.In 1572 the trees already bore leaves in February, just like in 1172.In 1588 the trees were green in February.In 1538, 1607 and 1659 there was neither snow nor frost.In 1601 and 1609 there was no winter in southern Germany.In 1662 the winter was so mild that even in northern Germany people did not light fires in tiled stoves and the trees bloomed in February.In 1722 all the trees were green in February.In 1807 Bore did not come to visit at all.In 1834 the winter was as mild as the last mentioned.In 1863 in Skåne you could pick fully bloomed daisies in February. In 1870 New Year's Day was celebrated in Petersburg at a temperature of eight degrees.From the newspaper Vestkusten, March 2, 1944It is largely the same text that was published in NT 45 years later. But here the reference is to Sv. Landsbygden and not to any rainfall monitor in Finspång. Sv. Landsbygden is probably short for the newspaper Svenska Landsbygden. We have received confirmation from the Royal Library (KB) that the newspaper existed at this time.About German weatherFurthermore, the text in the West Coast is somewhat longer than that in the NT, and several of the dates refer to conditions in Germany.– It is not clear in the NT article that the notes come from any particular place. In 1863 it says about Skåne itself and then we had started our own measurements. But otherwise it does not say where it took place, so it could be in Germany, says Sverker Hellström at SMHI.According to SMHI's records, the average temperature in Skåne in January and February 1863 was plus degrees.– It was certainly experienced as warm then. But if you compare it to today, for example, the average temperature in Lund in 2020 was three degrees warmer than it was in 1863.The information in the form of a submission in Folkbladet 2022 .We cannot say for sure if it is the same text that is reused in the NT, but there is much evidence to suggest so. Both we ourselves and the Google AI service NootbookLM have difficulty finding differences between the texts.It seems as if someone has taken the original text and edited out certain years, as well as all information about Germany. And suddenly a new story about Swedish springs and winters has been created. A story that is not entirely true – and which is now being used to mislead on the internet.Climate change and weatherSo what was it like now, is there a difference between climate and weather?– Yes, there is a difference between climate and weather. I usually make the following analogy: the climate tells you what clothes to bring and the weather tells you what clothes to wear. The climate is what you expect and the weather is what you get. A climate has a natural weather variation and the variations become larger if we look at a smaller area, says Erik Sahlée at Uppsala University.Comment on Facebook March 13.To describe changes in the climate, weather observations from continuous, longer time series and larger geographical areas are needed. These also exist.– If you look up and compile what we have seen across Europe and the world, the warming global trend is not something to discuss. That it is happening as a result of human influence is also not something to discuss. Now we need to start talking about what we should do about climate change instead – and how we can adapt.How do we know that climate change is due to human influence?– Physics shows that. When you just look at how natural factors affect global temperature, you don't get as strong a warming as we have. We humans have created that amplification.Overall: Many have used the image to contradict the idea that humans are behind the global warming that is currently taking place. But according to research, it is people's way of life that has affected the climate.And as for the photographed article itself, it turned out to have made a remarkable journey across media of different times. An article about German weather from the 1940s was remade in the Swedish local press in the 1980s into something that appears to apply to Sweden and that appears to come from a representative of SMHI – to finally spin around as a screenshot on Facebook in the 2020s.
chatgpt_generation: “Viral Claim That Trees Were Green in February 1722 Misrepresents Historical Weather — Fact-Check Finds It False”
chatgpt_condensation: A viral newspaper clipping claims that in February 1722, all the trees were completely green, suggesting historically mild winters that challenge current climate change science. However, this claim is misleading: the original article mixes weather anecdotes from different regions and centuries, and does not reflect reliable climate data. The fact-check finds the claim false, confirming that the evidence cited does not disprove human-driven global warming.
chatgpt_evaluation: 1. The claim: That historical records show extremely mild winters—such as all trees being green in February 1722—proving that climate variations are natural and that current global warming is not caused by human activities. 2. The final verdict: False. 3. Reasoning:  The newspaper clipping circulating online is based on an article that mixes anecdotal weather observations from different centuries and regions, including Germany, not just Sweden.  The original data lacks scientific rigor, with no continuous or systematic climate measurements before 1722, and the “statistics” cited come from vague sources like old newspaper clippings or “clip albums.”  Modern climate science, including reports from the UN IPCC and meteorological experts, shows unequivocal evidence that recent global warming is mainly caused by human greenhouse gas emissions.  Isolated weather events or short-term mild seasons do not represent long-term climate trends, which require consistent, long-term data over wide areas.  The article’s apparent connection to official meteorological authorities (SMHI) is misleading, as the referenced individual was not an official analyst and the data was collected privately.  The viral image distorts historical context, omitting references to other regions and turning localized weather anecdotes into a misleading narrative about Sweden’s climate history.
gemini_generation: Green Trees in February 1722? Viral Climate Skeptic Post Debunked as False and Misleading
gemini_condensation: A newspaper clipping circulating among climate skeptics on social media, claiming that In February 1722, all the trees were completely green and presenting a list of historical mild winters, does not accurately reflect climate information or Swedish conditions. The claim is largely false. The article is an anecdotal piece, not scientific data, and originated from a 1944 American-Swedish newspaper, largely referring to weather in Germany, not Sweden, and has been misleadingly presented to suggest natural climate variability negates human-caused climate change.
gemini_evaluation: Here's the verdict for the fact-check: 1. What is the claim? The circulating newspaper clipping, with the headline “In February 1722, all the trees were completely green,” claims to provide historical evidence of naturally mild winters and varied climate conditions, implying that current climate change is not primarily human-caused. 2. What is the final verdict? False. 3. What reasoning supports this decision? The reasoning supporting this False verdict is multifaceted:  Misleading Content: The article presents anecdotal weather observations, not long-term climate data. Weather and climate are distinct; individual weather events, even historical ones, do not indicate climate trends.  Irrelevant to Climate Change: Even if the historical weather observations were accurate (which many are not, given the lack of measurement tools at the time), they do not disprove human-caused climate change. The UN IPCC unequivocally states that human influence, primarily through greenhouse gas emissions, has warmed the climate system, with the global average temperature increasing faster since 1970 than in the last 2,000 years. Natural variations still exist but do not account for the current warming trend.  Dubious Sourcing and Context: The article in question, published in a Swedish local newspaper in 1989, falsely attributes its content to an SMHI precipitation monitor. SMHI has no record of such a person in that capacity, and the job does not involve historical climate analysis. Furthermore, the article's content was found to be largely plagiarized and edited from a 1944 American-Swedish newspaper, Vestkusten, which itself was referencing an older Swedish rural newspaper. Crucially, much of the original Vestkusten text referred to weather conditions in Germany, not Sweden, and this information was removed in the 1989 version to make it appear applicable to Sweden.  Lack of Scientific Basis for Early Dates: Many of the years cited (e.g., 1172, 1241) predate the invention of weather measurement tools (17th and 18th centuries) and systematic weather observations in Sweden (which began in Uppsala in 1722). Therefore, the data for these early years cannot be considered scientifically valid weather measurements.  Intent to Mislead: The image has been widely shared by climate skeptic groups and individuals with explicit statements aiming to dismiss the reality of human-caused climate change, making its dissemination a clear attempt to misinform.
llama_generation: No, 1722 Trees Turning Green in February Doesn't Prove Climate Change is Natural
llama_condensation: Here's a short lead for the fact-check article: Claim: A newspaper clipping claims that in February 1722, all trees were completely green, suggesting mild winters in the past. Verdict: False The viral newspaper clipping, which originated from a 1944 article about German weather, has been misused on social media to contradict human-induced climate change. Despite its widespread sharing, the article doesn't prove anything about climate change, and its claims about Swedish weather conditions are unfounded. Human activities, particularly greenhouse gas emissions, are significantly contributing to global warming, as supported by the IPCC's latest report ¹ ².
llama_evaluation: The claim being evaluated is that a newspaper clipping from 1989 proves mild winters in the past, specifically citing instances like February 1722 when all trees were completely green. This claim has been shared on social media to contradict human-induced climate change. Verdict: False Reasoning: Origin of the Article: The article originated from a 1944 newspaper called Vestkusten, which discussed German weather, not Swedish conditions as implied by the viral image. The text was later modified and published in a Swedish local newspaper in 1989. Lack of Scientific Basis: The article's content lacks scientific basis, listing scattered years with mild winters without providing a comprehensive view of climate patterns. Weather measurements in Sweden didn't start until 1722, making claims about earlier years unreliable. Misrepresentation of SMHI: The article falsely attributes the information to Gunnar Carlberg, a supposed precipitation monitor for SMHI (Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute). There's no record of such a person working in this capacity at SMHI. Climate vs. Weather: The article confuses climate with weather, failing to provide evidence for long-term climate trends. Climate scientists emphasize that weather observations from specific years don't prove anything about climate change ¹. Scientific Consensus: The UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) concludes that human influence, mainly through greenhouse gas emissions, has unequivocally warmed the climate system. Natural climate variations exist, but human activities are significantly contributing to global warming.
