grok_evaluation: 1. Claim Being Evaluated: The claim being evaluated is that AI-generated deepfake videos on Facebook allege that Swedish cardiologist Lars Wallentin was murdered in his car and that TV doctor Mikael Sandström’s apartment was burned down by a pharmaceutical mafia, with both individuals supposedly promoting miracle cures (a pill to clear blood vessels and a cream to relieve joint pain) that led to these alleged attacks. Justification Based on Key Supporting Evidence: - Deepfake Fabrication: The Source Criticism Agency confirmed that the videos use AI to create deepfake versions of real individuals, including Lars Wallentin, Mikael Sandström, and SVT news anchor Lisbeth Åkerman, who have no connection to the events or claims depicted. The real Lars Wallentin commented that a previous hoax video about him was “total fake,” and the new video alleging his murder is similarly fabricated. - False Medical Claims: Medical expert Jakob Johansson, a chief physician at Aleris, stated that the claims about a pill clearing blood vessels or a cream instantly relieving joint inflammation are physiologically implausible. Similarly, Lars Wallentin has been contacted and is aware of the misuse of his identity, further debunking the videos’ narratives. - Misleading Prevalence Claims: The videos’ assertions that everyone will inevitably suffer from stroke, heart attack, or paralysis, and that blood vessels are universally damaged by age 50, are false. Johansson clarified that while atherosclerosis is common, it does not universally cause severe symptoms, and most people’s circulation is not significantly impacted by age 50.

headline: Bluff pills surround AI-generated videos of murder and bombing
summary: The sun doctor's apartment in flames and a Swedish heart doctor who allegedly revealed shocking information and was then murdered - that's what it sounds like in videos circulating online. But they are deepfakes made by scammers to sell a fake drug.
text: This is the fact-check : The Source Criticism Agency has previously noted that Lars Wallentin, a senior professor of cardiology in Uppsala, was exploited in a hoax video in which he allegedly made revelations about the Covid-19 vaccine. – Total fake, completely out of touch with reality, the real Lars Wallentin commented on the video in May. That video has since been taken down, but another video is also being spread in which Wallentin is alleged to have been murdered, shot in his car. From deepfake hoax video on Facebook April 22. The new video has been viewed nearly 9,000 times so far, according to Facebook's counter.The fraudsters behind the videos have used AI to make it look like real people are acting in front of the camera, so-called deepfakes . What appears to be SVT news anchor Lisbeth Åkerman is seen in the video reporting on a news event.This is what the AI clone of Åkerman says:A terrible tragedy occurred in Stockholm this morning. The well-known cardiologist Lars Wallentin was shot dead in his car at a busy intersection. The police have found empty shells from a firearm. Everything indicates that it was a carefully planned attack. An eyewitness, a young woman, tearfully described how the doctor was hit by three shots and fell over the steering wheel. The day before his death, Lars Wallentin revealed shocking information about the Swedish healthcare system to our reporter – information that cost him his life. What was it about? Listen on.From deepfaked video on Facebook April 22 Then, an AI-generated copy of Lars Wallentin begins to tell us how he created a pill that can clean the vessels and prevent premature death, but also more common health problems such as headaches, fatigue, swelling and varicose veins. From deepfake hoax video on Facebook April 22. The AI clone says he has received threats, but that he “will not remain silent,” and describes the pharmaceutical industry as a “mafia.” “Lars Wallentin” says this:It's your choice. It's your pain. It's your death. I'm not bought by anyone. I'm a scientist who has finally given people something they've never had before. A real way to survive. At my age, I've cleared my vessels and feel amazing. You can do it too if you dare to take the step.From deepfaked video on Facebook April 22 Differences from the previous videoIn the previous video, a connection was made to the Covid-19 vaccine and various incorrect claims about it, but these have been completely removed this time.The video is being shared by a different account than the previous one, but it looks almost exactly the same, with the same images and descriptions. The account claims to be an American advertising agency. The account on Facebook. The video refers to where you can read more, but this time there is no link. It did when the second video was spread – anyone who clicked on it then came to a fake SVT page. Fake SVT site. There, the reader was given a tip, again by “Lars Wallentin”, about a kind of capsule with dietary supplements, “Frank & Frey CBD Capsules”. The tablets were supposed to clear your blood vessels, give you enormous strength and perfect vision. Källkritikbyrån has been in contact with Lars Wallentin after he was allegedly murdered.The “Sun Doctor” also affectedMikael Sandström, a doctor and TV personality known as the “sun doctor,” has also been exploited by scammers in a similar video.In what appears to be a news broadcast from SVT, it is alleged that Sandström had his apartment in Stockholm burned down by the pharmaceutical mafia. From deepfake hoax video on Facebook April 28. AI has then been used to make it appear as if Sandström is being interviewed and then says that the bombing was an attempt to silence him by pharmaceutical companies. “Sandström” then begins to advocate a miracle cure.We have developed a new unique cream formula made exclusively from natural ingredients. This cream instantly relieves inflammation and in just a few weeks completely restores joints and promotes cartilage regeneration. You will forget about arthritis, osteoarthritis, back and joint pain forever.Excerpt from hoax video April 28  From deepfake hoax video on Facebook April 28. Mikael Sandström has previously been interviewed in Aftonbladet and said in January that he was then contacted daily by elderly people who had been scammed by various online fraudsters in his name.– It is incredibly sad and I feel desperate, he told Aftonbladet . The Source Criticism Agency has contacted Sandström.The claims in the videoIn addition to the fact that the fraudsters AI-generated Lars Wallentin and Mikael Sandström, the claims made about cardiovascular diseases themselves are false, according to doctors that Källkritikbyrån spoke to. Taking a tablet to clear the vessels is physiologically a very stupid idea, states Jakob Johansson, chief physician at the healthcare company Aleris. – Hypothetically, if this agent were to cause these plaques, which are a coating on the vessel wall, to loosen, it would lead to a lot of clots going all over the body. But if they mean that this would clear it up so that it just magically disappears, well, then it would be useful. Are there any such pills that “clear the vessels”?– No, that sounds completely unlikely. There is a huge amount of research done on atherosclerosis and there is good treatment for it, but no single “magic bullet” that solves everything, in this way, says Jakob Johansson at Aleris. The Facebook page has been blocked from posting ads. The video claims that the miracle cure would start working after three days. – Sure, an Alvdeon starts working after twenty minutes, but that this would have an effect on something as complex as atherosclerosis is, in my opinion, completely impossible. This is what the voice in the video says:Everyone has it. Stroke, heart attack, paralysis. It's just a matter of time.From deepfake hoax video on Facebook April 22. – No, not everyone is affected by it. It is common in many cultures to get atherosclerosis to a greater or lesser degree, but it does not cause symptoms such as a heart attack or stroke in the majority, no. From Facebook's ad library. The video claims that by the age of 50, the blood vessels are already damaged. How accurate is that?– No, of course that's not true. The vascular tree is exposed to stress, but the majority of the population is not affected, especially not with an impact on circulation. What do you think about this kind of claim being spread like this?– As with all forms of quackery, it's sad because it can lead to people not taking the medical treatment and making the lifestyle changes that we know can reduce atherosclerosis. So it's sad if just one person goes through this, says Johansson.How the films are distributedThe video is still up on Facebook at the time of writing. The account spreading the video has posted 45 ads since March, all of which have been taken down for violating Meta’s rules. The page also appears to have been blocked from posting ads. Ads with the false claims about “sun doctor” Mikael Sandström have not led to any action being taken against one of the pages that spread them: the Facebook page “Hälsosam lässig” (Healthy Lifestyle), which is trying to target Swedish users. Post on Facebook March 26. Overall:  The videos are made with AI and neither the news anchors nor the doctors in the stories are real. They are real, but they have nothing to do with the story. The claims about the remedy that the scammers are trying to sell are false – it is a scam.

What is the final verdict? False. 3. What reasoning supports this decision? The reasoning for this verdict is multi-faceted and thoroughly detailed in the provided fact-check:  Deepfake Technology: The videos are explicitly stated to be created using AI to generate deepfakes, making it appear as though real people are acting and speaking. The fact-check confirms that neither the news anchors nor the doctors in the videos are genuinely involved; they are real individuals whose likenesses have been digitally manipulated.  Direct Denials from Impersonated Individuals: Lars Wallentin himself commented on a previous hoax video, calling it Total fake, completely out of touch with reality. The Source Criticism Agency also confirmed contact with Wallentin after the murder video, further solidifying that he is alive and the claims are false. Mikael Sandström has also publicly stated he is contacted daily by elderly people scammed in his name and has expressed feeling desperate about the situation.  Medical Implausibility: Medical professionals consulted by Källkritikbyrån unequivocally state that the miracle cures promoted in the videos are physiologically unsound and impossible. For example, a pill to clear vessels is described as a very stupid idea that could cause dangerous clots, and there is no magic bullet for atherosclerosis. Claims of instant relief and complete regeneration are also dismissed as unrealistic.  Conspiracy Theories and Misinformation: The videos employ common scam tactics, such as promoting conspiracy theories about a pharmaceutical industry acting as a mafia to silence those with real cures. This is a common tactic to undermine trust in legitimate medicine and push unproven remedies.  Behavior of the Disseminating Accounts: The accounts sharing these videos have a history of violating platform rules, with numerous ads being taken down. This pattern is indicative of fraudulent activity.  Absence of Legitimate Information: While a previous video linked to a fake SVT page, the newer video promoting Wallentin's cure has no link, which is a red flag for scams that aim to sell products without providing verifiable information. In conclusion, the claims are fabricated using advanced AI technology to exploit the credibility of public figures and spread dangerous medical misinformation for financial gain.

headline: False claim about the death of 14,000 infants in Gaza spread in media worldwide - including in Danish
summary: 14,000 infants in Gaza are at risk of dying from malnutrition within two days, UN humanitarian chief Tom Fletcher said on Tuesday. But the information is not correct, TjekDet's research shows, and the UN itself acknowledges that Tom Fletcher should have phrased it differently. However, the UN emphasizes that the situation in Gaza is critical and that thousands of children are at risk of dying from malnutrition over the next year
text: This is the fact-check:This was reported  in several media outlets  both at home  and abroad on Tuesday , and  politicians and  social media users are reporting the startling figure. The information about the 14,000 infants also found its way into the closing debate of the Folketing on Wednesday.The figure comes from the head of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Tom Fletcher, who appeared on  the BBC's Radio 4 Today programme on Tuesday morning , where he advocated for the need for UN trucks to be allowed to deliver emergency aid to Gaza.Let me explain what's on those trucks. It's baby food. Baby nutrition. 14,000 babies will die in the next 48 hours if we can't get to them, says Tom Fletcher on the BBC program.But it is not correct that 14,000 infants in Gaza are in acute danger of dying within 48 hours. Tom Fletcher's wording was unclear, explains Jens Lærke, spokesperson for OCHA, to TjekDet.“He should have said that 14,000 babies are very likely to suffer from severe acute malnutrition. This means that they are in danger of death and urgently need our help,” says Jens Lærke.Already on Tuesday, the BBC asked where Tom Fletcher got the startling figure.“We point to the urgent need to get supplies in to save the estimated 14,000 infants suffering from severe acute malnutrition in Gaza, as the IPC partnership has warned. We need to get the supplies in as quickly as possible, preferably within the next 48 hours,”  OCHA responded, according to the BBC .Jens Lærke confirms to TjekDet that the figure comes from the IPC, which assesses food security worldwide and with which the UN cooperates.  On May 12, the IPC issued a statement about acute food insecurity in Gaza.It states regarding emergency aid to Gaza that “immediate action is essential to prevent further deaths, hunger and acute malnutrition, and a move towards famine.”However, it does not say that 14,000 infants will die within two days.To TjekDet, the IPC explains that OCHA's interpretation is inaccurate. Instead, the IPC estimates that 14,100 children in Gaza under the age of five will be at risk of severe acute malnutrition. According to the IPC, this means that they risk dying from malnutrition within the next year if they do not receive treatment, but not within 48 hours, as Tom Fletcher said.Aid agencies have long reported widespread famine in Gaza. And although the UN now acknowledges that Tom Fletcher should have expressed himself differently, they emphasize that the situation in Gaza is critical and that thousands of children are at risk of dying from malnutrition over the next year.CheckDet has asked OCHA why Tom Fletcher sets 48 hours as the limit for emergency aid to arrive on time, when the IPC in their report mentions a period from April 2025 to March 2026. It is a  figure of speech , says Jens Lærke from OCHA.This is to emphasize that it has to be done quickly. We have been told by Israel that the current window for sending aid into Gaza is temporary. It is not necessarily 48 hours, because they have not set a time frame, but it is urgent, he says.Jens Lærke says that, to his knowledge, there is no official denial coming from the UN, but that it cannot be ruled out that one will come. He adds that OCHA has explained itself to many media outlets and in doing so has attempted to correct Tom Fletcher's statement.On Tuesday, a number of Danish media outlets published an article from Ritzau claiming that 14,000 infants in Gaza could die within two days.On Wednesday morning, Ritzau published a new article stating that the IPC's projection concerns children under five years of age, and that it concerns a period of one year and not two days.
chatgpt_generation: Claim That 14,000 Infants in Gaza Could Die Within 48 Hours Is False, Says UN and IPC
chatgpt_condensation: Misstatement by UN Official: Tom Fletcher from OCHA incorrectly stated on BBC Radio that 14,000 babies in Gaza could die within 48 hours without aid. The figure was meant to refer to children at risk of severe acute malnutrition, not imminent death. Clarification from UN and IPC: OCHA and the IPC clarified that 14,100 children under five in Gaza are at risk of dying from malnutrition over the next year, not within two days. The 48-hour time frame was a rhetorical expression to stress urgency, not a literal deadline. Media Correction: After the initial report, several outlets including Danish media corrected their coverage, aligning with the IPC’s and OCHA’s clarified information. The UN has acknowledged the miscommunication but stands by the urgency of the situation.
chatgpt_evaluation: Verdict: False The claim that 14,000 infants in Gaza could die within 48 hours is false. The actual data from the IPC indicates that 14,100 children under five are at risk of severe acute malnutrition over the next year, not within two days. The 48-hour statement by Tom Fletcher was a rhetorical exaggeration, not supported by official data.

headline: False claim about the death of 14,000 infants in Gaza spread in media worldwide - including in Danish
summary: 14,000 infants in Gaza are at risk of dying from malnutrition within two days, UN humanitarian chief Tom Fletcher said on Tuesday. But the information is not correct, TjekDet's research shows, and the UN itself acknowledges that Tom Fletcher should have phrased it differently. However, the UN emphasizes that the situation in Gaza is critical and that thousands of children are at risk of dying from malnutrition over the next year
text: This is the fact-check:This was reported  in several media outlets  both at home  and abroad on Tuesday , and  politicians and  social media users are reporting the startling figure. The information about the 14,000 infants also found its way into the closing debate of the Folketing on Wednesday.The figure comes from the head of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Tom Fletcher, who appeared on  the BBC's Radio 4 Today programme on Tuesday morning , where he advocated for the need for UN trucks to be allowed to deliver emergency aid to Gaza.Let me explain what's on those trucks. It's baby food. Baby nutrition. 14,000 babies will die in the next 48 hours if we can't get to them, says Tom Fletcher on the BBC program.But it is not correct that 14,000 infants in Gaza are in acute danger of dying within 48 hours. Tom Fletcher's wording was unclear, explains Jens Lærke, spokesperson for OCHA, to TjekDet.“He should have said that 14,000 babies are very likely to suffer from severe acute malnutrition. This means that they are in danger of death and urgently need our help,” says Jens Lærke.Already on Tuesday, the BBC asked where Tom Fletcher got the startling figure.“We point to the urgent need to get supplies in to save the estimated 14,000 infants suffering from severe acute malnutrition in Gaza, as the IPC partnership has warned. We need to get the supplies in as quickly as possible, preferably within the next 48 hours,”  OCHA responded, according to the BBC .Jens Lærke confirms to TjekDet that the figure comes from the IPC, which assesses food security worldwide and with which the UN cooperates.  On May 12, the IPC issued a statement about acute food insecurity in Gaza.It states regarding emergency aid to Gaza that “immediate action is essential to prevent further deaths, hunger and acute malnutrition, and a move towards famine.”However, it does not say that 14,000 infants will die within two days.To TjekDet, the IPC explains that OCHA's interpretation is inaccurate. Instead, the IPC estimates that 14,100 children in Gaza under the age of five will be at risk of severe acute malnutrition. According to the IPC, this means that they risk dying from malnutrition within the next year if they do not receive treatment, but not within 48 hours, as Tom Fletcher said.Aid agencies have long reported widespread famine in Gaza. And although the UN now acknowledges that Tom Fletcher should have expressed himself differently, they emphasize that the situation in Gaza is critical and that thousands of children are at risk of dying from malnutrition over the next year.CheckDet has asked OCHA why Tom Fletcher sets 48 hours as the limit for emergency aid to arrive on time, when the IPC in their report mentions a period from April 2025 to March 2026. It is a  figure of speech , says Jens Lærke from OCHA.This is to emphasize that it has to be done quickly. We have been told by Israel that the current window for sending aid into Gaza is temporary. It is not necessarily 48 hours, because they have not set a time frame, but it is urgent, he says.Jens Lærke says that, to his knowledge, there is no official denial coming from the UN, but that it cannot be ruled out that one will come. He adds that OCHA has explained itself to many media outlets and in doing so has attempted to correct Tom Fletcher's statement.On Tuesday, a number of Danish media outlets published an article from Ritzau claiming that 14,000 infants in Gaza could die within two days.On Wednesday morning, Ritzau published a new article stating that the IPC's projection concerns children under five years of age, and that it concerns a period of one year and not two days.

UN spokesperson Jens Lærke clarified that Fletcher’s statement was a misrepresentation meant to stress urgency, not a literal prediction.  The Verdict: The claim is inaccurate. UN OCHA acknowledged Fletcher's statement was misleading and has attempted to correct it in the media, while still emphasizing the urgency of aid delivery.

Evidence: - Tom Fletcher, head of OCHA, stated on BBC Radio 4 that 14,000 babies will die in the next 48 hours if aid does not reach Gaza, which was widely reported. - Jens Lærke, OCHA spokesperson, clarified to TjekDet that Fletcher's statement was inaccurate; he meant 14,000 babies are at risk of severe acute malnutrition, which could lead to death without urgent aid, but not within 48 hours. - The IPC, which assesses food security, estimates 14,100 children under five in Gaza are at risk of severe acute malnutrition over the next year (April 2025 to March 2026), not within 48 hours. - The IPC called OCHA's interpretation inaccurate regarding the 48-hour timeframe. - Lærke explained the 48-hour reference was a figure of speech to emphasize urgency, not a literal deadline. 3. Claim: The claim is that 14,000 infants in Gaza will die within 48 hours if emergency aid is not delivered. Summary: The fact-check investigates the claim that 14,000 infants in Gaza will die within 48 hours without emergency aid, as stated by Tom Fletcher, head of OCHA, on BBC Radio 4. This claim was widely reported by media outlets and discussed in political forums. However, the evidence shows the claim is false. Jens Lærke, an OCHA spokesperson, clarified to TjekDet that Fletcher's statement was misleading; he intended to highlight that 14,000 babies are at risk of severe acute malnutrition, which could lead to death without urgent aid, but not specifically within 48 hours. The IPC, a key source for the figure, estimates that 14,100 children under five in Gaza face this risk over the next year (April 2025 to March 2026), not within two days, and labeled OCHA's 48-hour interpretation as inaccurate. Lærke noted the 48-hour timeframe was a rhetorical device to stress urgency, not a literal deadline. Thus, the claim is false because it inaccurately suggests an imminent 48-hour deadline for the deaths of 14,000 infants, whereas the actual risk is severe malnutrition over a longer period.

Based on the evidence provided, is the claim true, false, mixed, or another verdict category? The claim is false. 3. What evidence or reasoning supports this verdict? The evidence shows that Tom Fletcher's statement was inaccurate. Jens Lærke, OCHA spokesperson, clarified to TjekDet that Fletcher meant 14,000 babies are at risk of severe acute malnutrition, which could lead to death without urgent aid, but not specifically within 48 hours. The IPC, the source of the figure, estimates that 14,100 children under five in Gaza are at risk of severe acute malnutrition over the next year (April 2025 to March 2026), not within 48 hours, and called OCHA's 48-hour interpretation inaccurate. Lærke explained the 48-hour timeframe was a rhetorical device to emphasize urgency, not a literal deadline. Final Verdict: The claim that 14,000 infants in Gaza will die within 48 hours without emergency aid is false. Evidence from OCHA and the IPC confirms that the figure refers to 14,100 children under five at risk of severe acute malnutrition over a year, not imminent death within 48 hours. The 48-hour timeframe was a rhetorical exaggeration, not supported by the IPC's data, leading to the false verdict.

headline: False claim about the death of 14,000 infants in Gaza spread in media worldwide - including in Danish
summary: 14,000 infants in Gaza are at risk of dying from malnutrition within two days, UN humanitarian chief Tom Fletcher said on Tuesday. But the information is not correct, TjekDet's research shows, and the UN itself acknowledges that Tom Fletcher should have phrased it differently. However, the UN emphasizes that the situation in Gaza is critical and that thousands of children are at risk of dying from malnutrition over the next year
text: This is the fact-check:This was reported  in several media outlets  both at home  and abroad on Tuesday , and  politicians and  social media users are reporting the startling figure. The information about the 14,000 infants also found its way into the closing debate of the Folketing on Wednesday.The figure comes from the head of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Tom Fletcher, who appeared on  the BBC's Radio 4 Today programme on Tuesday morning , where he advocated for the need for UN trucks to be allowed to deliver emergency aid to Gaza.Let me explain what's on those trucks. It's baby food. Baby nutrition. 14,000 babies will die in the next 48 hours if we can't get to them, says Tom Fletcher on the BBC program.But it is not correct that 14,000 infants in Gaza are in acute danger of dying within 48 hours. Tom Fletcher's wording was unclear, explains Jens Lærke, spokesperson for OCHA, to TjekDet.“He should have said that 14,000 babies are very likely to suffer from severe acute malnutrition. This means that they are in danger of death and urgently need our help,” says Jens Lærke.Already on Tuesday, the BBC asked where Tom Fletcher got the startling figure.“We point to the urgent need to get supplies in to save the estimated 14,000 infants suffering from severe acute malnutrition in Gaza, as the IPC partnership has warned. We need to get the supplies in as quickly as possible, preferably within the next 48 hours,”  OCHA responded, according to the BBC .Jens Lærke confirms to TjekDet that the figure comes from the IPC, which assesses food security worldwide and with which the UN cooperates.  On May 12, the IPC issued a statement about acute food insecurity in Gaza.It states regarding emergency aid to Gaza that “immediate action is essential to prevent further deaths, hunger and acute malnutrition, and a move towards famine.”However, it does not say that 14,000 infants will die within two days.To TjekDet, the IPC explains that OCHA's interpretation is inaccurate. Instead, the IPC estimates that 14,100 children in Gaza under the age of five will be at risk of severe acute malnutrition. According to the IPC, this means that they risk dying from malnutrition within the next year if they do not receive treatment, but not within 48 hours, as Tom Fletcher said.Aid agencies have long reported widespread famine in Gaza. And although the UN now acknowledges that Tom Fletcher should have expressed himself differently, they emphasize that the situation in Gaza is critical and that thousands of children are at risk of dying from malnutrition over the next year.CheckDet has asked OCHA why Tom Fletcher sets 48 hours as the limit for emergency aid to arrive on time, when the IPC in their report mentions a period from April 2025 to March 2026. It is a  figure of speech , says Jens Lærke from OCHA.This is to emphasize that it has to be done quickly. We have been told by Israel that the current window for sending aid into Gaza is temporary. It is not necessarily 48 hours, because they have not set a time frame, but it is urgent, he says.Jens Lærke says that, to his knowledge, there is no official denial coming from the UN, but that it cannot be ruled out that one will come. He adds that OCHA has explained itself to many media outlets and in doing so has attempted to correct Tom Fletcher's statement.On Tuesday, a number of Danish media outlets published an article from Ritzau claiming that 14,000 infants in Gaza could die within two days.On Wednesday morning, Ritzau published a new article stating that the IPC's projection concerns children under five years of age, and that it concerns a period of one year and not two days.

chatgpt_condensation: Claim: The claim evaluated is that 14,000 infants in Gaza will die within 48 hours if emergency aid is not delivered. Evidence:  Tom Fletcher, head of the UN OCHA, stated on BBC Radio 4 that 14,000 babies would die in 48 hours without aid.  OCHA later clarified Fletcher’s wording was misleading; the figure refers to infants at risk of severe acute malnutrition who urgently need help, not guaranteed deaths within two days.  The figure originates from the IPC, which estimates about 14,100 children under five in Gaza are at risk of severe malnutrition that could lead to death within the next year if untreated—not within 48 hours.  The IPC’s report covers a one-year period (April 2025 to March 2026), not an immediate two-day window.  OCHA emphasized urgency but explained the 48-hour timeframe was figurative, reflecting limited aid delivery windows rather than a strict deadline for survival.  Media initially reported the claim as imminent deaths but later corrected their coverage to align with IPC’s assessment. Verdict: The claim that 14,000 infants will die within 48 hours without aid is false. The number reflects those at risk of severe malnutrition with potential death over a year if untreated, not an immediate fatality count. The original statement was a miscommunication, and the situation, while critical, does not imply such an immediate death toll.

Explanation: The evidence shows that the figure of 14,000 refers to infants at risk of severe acute malnutrition who could die within a year without treatment, not within 48 hours. gemini_generation: No, 14,000 Gaza Infants Are Not Expected to Die Within 48 Hours, But Malnutrition Risk Remains High
gemini_condensation: Claim: 14,000 infants in Gaza will die within the next 48 hours if emergency aid cannot reach them. Evidence:  The claim originated from Tom Fletcher, head of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), during a BBC Radio 4 program. He stated, 14,000 babies will die in the next 48 hours if we can't get to them, to emphasize the urgent need for aid.  OCHA spokesperson Jens Lærke clarified that Fletcher's wording was unclear. He explained that Fletcher should have said that 14,000 babies are very likely to suffer from severe acute malnutrition, meaning they are in danger of death and urgently need help.  The figure of 14,000 (specifically 14,100) comes from the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC), which assesses food security globally. The IPC states that this number of children under five are at risk of severe acute malnutrition.  However, the IPC clarifies that this risk means they could die from malnutrition within the next year if they do not receive treatment, not within 48 hours.  Jens Lærke confirmed that the 48-hour timeframe was a figure of speech to stress urgency, as Israel had indicated a temporary window for aid delivery, though no specific timeframe was set.  Danish media outlet Ritzau initially reported the 48-hour timeframe but later issued a correction, aligning with the IPC's projection of a one-year period for children under five. Verdict: False. While it is true that approximately 14,000 infants (children under five) in Gaza are at risk of severe acute malnutrition and potential death, the timeframe of within 48 hours is incorrect. This was a misstatement by a UN official, clarified by OCHA and the IPC, who indicate the risk of death from malnutrition is over the next year if treatment is not received. The situation in Gaza regarding child malnutrition remains critical.

The evidence clearly shows that the specific timeframe of within 48 hours for the deaths of 14,000 infants is incorrect. While the figure of approximately 14,000 children under five being at risk of severe acute malnutrition is accurate and comes from the IPC (Integrated Food Security Phase Classification), the IPC explicitly states that this risk means they could die from malnutrition over the next year if untreated, not within two days. OCHA spokesperson Jens Lærke clarified that Tom Fletcher's original statement on the BBC was an unclear wording and that the 48-hour period was a figure of speech to emphasize the extreme urgency of the humanitarian situation and the temporary nature of aid access. Therefore, while the severe risk to thousands of children due to malnutrition in Gaza is real and urgent, the immediate death timeline of 48 hours is false.

headline: Images of Danish school classes are misused in international propaganda
summary: Two class photos from Danish schools are going around the world these months. In one class photo, which is of a 9th grader from the school year 2010
text: This is the fact to check: Two class photos from Danish schools, which are seen by millions of users on social media, especially abroad, are being misused as documentation that there is apparently a population replacement in Denmark.  This is how you change a country. See the difference between 2010 and 2025 at a school in Denmark, reads a caption for a post on the social media X.  “Same country, same city, same school, same class, but ten years apart,” reads another post.  The class photos have also been shared by the X-profile Radio Genoa, one of the most well-known voices critical of immigrants on the platform. The profile is followed by more than a million users. Across social media, the photos have been seen by millions of people.  But the pictures cannot be used to document that there is a population change in Denmark. They are neither the same class nor the same school, and there is also a good explanation for the difference in the student composition in the two pictures.  This also suggests that people in Russia are involved in the dissemination of the images. We will return to that part. Zero This is what the post from Radio Genoa looks like on the X platform. The post has been viewed by almost half a million users. CheckIt has chosen to blur the faces in the pictures. Different schools with different students However, it is correct that both images originate from Danish schools.  The first - with the ethnically Danish students - was taken by 9A at Bjerregrav School west of Randers in the school year 2010/2011. The school is a regular elementary school.  The second photo is also taken by a 9th grader, but from an international private school near Copenhagen that has many Muslim students. It was taken in connection with the 2017/2018 school year, according to the school's website - and is therefore not from 2025, as claimed in the posts.  It is therefore not surprising that a primary school in Randers has fewer students with a background other than Danish than an international school near Copenhagen.  Headmaster at Bjerregrav School, Marlene Ankjær, tells TjekDet that she is upset that a picture from her school is being used in misinformation.  It is very unfortunate that we are being used in a context that is intended to create concern and division. Therefore, we have of course also reported the user on Facebook who is making this form of fake news, she says.  It has not been possible for TjekDet to get a comment from the international school near Copenhagen.  But what does the development of the numbers actually look like?  The Ministry of Children and Education calculates the distribution of students in Danish schools based on cultural circles, which include the categories 'Denmark', 'Western' and 'non-Western'.  At Bjerregrav School in the 2010/2011 school year, when the photos of the 9th grade students were taken, non-Western students made up 2.6 percent. In the 2023/2024 school year, the figure is zero percent. Here, the student composition has therefore gone in the opposite direction to what the postings on X claim.  Nationally, there has been a slight increase in the number of non-Western students. In the 2023/2024 school year, students with a non-Western background made up 11.8 percent of students in the country's primary, secondary and private schools. In the 2010/2011 school year, the proportion was 9.1 percent. Checked Who are the non-Western foreigners everyone is talking about? From TikTok to Russian propaganda TjekDet has not been able to trace the first sharing of the misleading comparison between the two class photos with certainty. The earliest we have been able to find dates from April 15 on X and Instagram. On Instagram, the photos were shared by the far-right page “Europe on Top”. The post has more than 32,000 likes.  However, the text on the images reveals that they originally came from TikTok - this can be seen in the distinctive font.  In other similar posts on X, you can see that the pictures of the school classes are taken as screenshots from TikTok. text: This is the fact to check: Two class photos from Danish schools, which are seen by millions of users on social media, especially abroad, are being misused as documentation that there is apparently a population replacement in Denmark.  This is how you change a country. See the difference between 2010 and 2025 at a school in Denmark, reads a caption for a post on the social media X.  “Same country, same city, same school, same class, but ten years apart,” reads another post.  The class photos have also been shared by the X-profile Radio Genoa, one of the most well-known voices critical of immigrants on the platform. The profile is followed by more than a million users. Across social media, the photos have been seen by millions of people.  But the pictures cannot be used to document that there is a population change in Denmark. The first - with the ethnically Danish students - was taken by 9A at Bjerregrav School west of Randers in the school year 2010/2011. The school is a regular elementary school.  The second photo is also taken by a 9th grader, but from an international private school near Copenhagen that has many Muslim students. It was taken in connection with the 2017/2018 school year, according to the school's website - and is therefore not from 2025, as claimed in the posts.  It is therefore not surprising that a primary school in Randers has fewer students with a background other than Danish than an international school near Copenhagen. It is very unfortunate that we are being used in a context that is intended to create concern and division. Therefore, we have of course also reported the user on Facebook who is making this form of fake news, she says. The Ministry of Children and Education calculates the distribution of students in Danish schools based on cultural circles, which include the categories 'Denmark', 'Western' and 'non-Western'.  At Bjerregrav School in the 2010/2011 school year, when the photos of the 9th grade students were taken, non-Western students made up 2.6 percent. headline: Images of Danish school classes are misused in international propaganda
summary: Two class photos from Danish schools are going around the world these months. In one class photo, which is of a 9th grader from the school year 2010
text: This is the fact to check: Two class photos from Danish schools, which are seen by millions of users on social media, especially abroad, are being misused as documentation that there is apparently a population replacement in Denmark.  This is how you change a country. See the difference between 2010 and 2025 at a school in Denmark, reads a caption for a post on the social media X.  “Same country, same city, same school, same class, but ten years apart,” reads another post.  The class photos have also been shared by the X-profile Radio Genoa, one of the most well-known voices critical of immigrants on the platform. The profile is followed by more than a million users. Across social media, the photos have been seen by millions of people.  But the pictures cannot be used to document that there is a population change in Denmark. They are neither the same class nor the same school, and there is also a good explanation for the difference in the student composition in the two pictures.  This also suggests that people in Russia are involved in the dissemination of the images. We will return to that part. Zero This is what the post from Radio Genoa looks like on the X platform. The post has been viewed by almost half a million users. CheckIt has chosen to blur the faces in the pictures. Different schools with different students However, it is correct that both images originate from Danish schools.  The first - with the ethnically Danish students - was taken by 9A at Bjerregrav School west of Randers in the school year 2010/2011. The school is a regular elementary school.  The second photo is also taken by a 9th grader, but from an international private school near Copenhagen that has many Muslim students. It was taken in connection with the 2017/2018 school year, according to the school's website - and is therefore not from 2025, as claimed in the posts.  It is therefore not surprising that a primary school in Randers has fewer students with a background other than Danish than an international school near Copenhagen.  Headmaster at Bjerregrav School, Marlene Ankjær, tells TjekDet that she is upset that a picture from her school is being used in misinformation.  It is very unfortunate that we are being used in a context that is intended to create concern and division. Therefore, we have of course also reported the user on Facebook who is making this form of fake news, she says.  It has not been possible for TjekDet to get a comment from the international school near Copenhagen.  But what does the development of the numbers actually look like?  The Ministry of Children and Education calculates the distribution of students in Danish schools based on cultural circles, which include the categories 'Denmark', 'Western' and 'non-Western'.  At Bjerregrav School in the 2010/2011 school year, when the photos of the 9th grade students were taken, non-Western students made up 2.6 percent. In the 2023/2024 school year, the figure is zero percent. Here, the student composition has therefore gone in the opposite direction to what the postings on X claim.  Nationally, there has been a slight increase in the number of non-Western students. In the 2023/2024 school year, students with a non-Western background made up 11.8 percent of students in the country's primary, secondary and private schools. In the 2010/2011 school year, the proportion was 9.1 percent. Checked Who are the non-Western foreigners everyone is talking about? From TikTok to Russian propaganda TjekDet has not been able to trace the first sharing of the misleading comparison between the two class photos with certainty. The earliest we have been able to find dates from April 15 on X and Instagram. On Instagram, the photos were shared by the far-right page “Europe on Top”. The post has more than 32,000 likes.  However, the text on the images reveals that they originally came from TikTok - this can be seen in the distinctive font.  In other similar posts on X, you can see that the pictures of the school classes are taken as screenshots from TikTok. At the bottom right, you can see that the post on TikTok, where the screenshot was taken, has a whopping 378,000 likes.  TjekDet has not been able to find the images on TikTok.  However, we can see that a few days later the images are being spread as Russian propaganda on Russian websites and by major channels on Telegram.  Among others, by Russian senator Alexey Pushkov, who writes about the photos:  “School class photos in Denmark in 2010 and 2025. The point of no return has been reached.” Checked How five dirty men and a 'Middle Eastern' family ended up in the same photo Another pro-Russian channel on Telegram with more than half a million followers writes about the images:  “A bit of horror. This is how the graduating classes in Denmark have changed over 15 years. If we don't stop the development, we'll soon have the same thing here.”  It is no coincidence that the images have been picked up by pro-Russian actors. The images support a theory of population replacement, which states that Danes will be outnumbered in Denmark in the future in favor of a Muslim majority.  A theory that Russia has often  promoted  because it serves as an example of Western decay for Russia, while at the same time the theory is used to create national cohesion within Russia.  Sign up for the CheckIt newsletter The theory has existed for many years, and is also known internationally as “ The Great Replacement ” - which is perhaps why the posts about schools in Denmark have been shared by so many people on social media.  This is not the first time that Danish schoolchildren have been abused to create a similar false narrative. TjekDet has previously reported how a video of students on a field trip was abused to claim that the students had converted to Islam.

headline: Images of Danish school classes are misused in international propaganda
summary: Two class photos from Danish schools are going around the world these months. In one class photo, which is of a 9th grader from the school year 2010
text: This is the fact to check: Two class photos from Danish schools, which are seen by millions of users on social media, especially abroad, are being misused as documentation that there is apparently a population replacement in Denmark.  This is how you change a country. See the difference between 2010 and 2025 at a school in Denmark, reads a caption for a post on the social media X.  “Same country, same city, same school, same class, but ten years apart,” reads another post.  The class photos have also been shared by the X-profile Radio Genoa, one of the most well-known voices critical of immigrants on the platform. The profile is followed by more than a million users. Across social media, the photos have been seen by millions of people.  But the pictures cannot be used to document that there is a population change in Denmark. They are neither the same class nor the same school, and there is also a good explanation for the difference in the student composition in the two pictures.  This also suggests that people in Russia are involved in the dissemination of the images. We will return to that part. Zero This is what the post from Radio Genoa looks like on the X platform. The post has been viewed by almost half a million users. CheckIt has chosen to blur the faces in the pictures. Different schools with different students However, it is correct that both images originate from Danish schools.  The first - with the ethnically Danish students - was taken by 9A at Bjerregrav School west of Randers in the school year 2010/2011. The school is a regular elementary school.  The second photo is also taken by a 9th grader, but from an international private school near Copenhagen that has many Muslim students. It was taken in connection with the 2017/2018 school year, according to the school's website - and is therefore not from 2025, as claimed in the posts.  It is therefore not surprising that a primary school in Randers has fewer students with a background other than Danish than an international school near Copenhagen.  Headmaster at Bjerregrav School, Marlene Ankjær, tells TjekDet that she is upset that a picture from her school is being used in misinformation.  It is very unfortunate that we are being used in a context that is intended to create concern and division. Therefore, we have of course also reported the user on Facebook who is making this form of fake news, she says.  It has not been possible for TjekDet to get a comment from the international school near Copenhagen.  But what does the development of the numbers actually look like?  The Ministry of Children and Education calculates the distribution of students in Danish schools based on cultural circles, which include the categories 'Denmark', 'Western' and 'non-Western'.  At Bjerregrav School in the 2010/2011 school year, when the photos of the 9th grade students were taken, non-Western students made up 2.6 percent. In the 2023/2024 school year, the figure is zero percent. Here, the student composition has therefore gone in the opposite direction to what the postings on X claim.  Nationally, there has been a slight increase in the number of non-Western students. In the 2023/2024 school year, students with a non-Western background made up 11.8 percent of students in the country's primary, secondary and private schools. In the 2010/2011 school year, the proportion was 9.1 percent. Checked Who are the non-Western foreigners everyone is talking about? From TikTok to Russian propaganda TjekDet has not been able to trace the first sharing of the misleading comparison between the two class photos with certainty. The earliest we have been able to find dates from April 15 on X and Instagram. On Instagram, the photos were shared by the far-right page “Europe on Top”. The post has more than 32,000 likes.  However, the text on the images reveals that they originally came from TikTok - this can be seen in the distinctive font.  In other similar posts on X, you can see that the pictures of the school classes are taken as screenshots from TikTok. At the bottom right, you can see that the post on TikTok, where the screenshot was taken, has a whopping 378,000 likes.  TjekDet has not been able to find the images on TikTok.  However, we can see that a few days later the images are being spread as Russian propaganda on Russian websites and by major channels on Telegram.  Among others, by Russian senator Alexey Pushkov, who writes about the photos:  “School class photos in Denmark in 2010 and 2025. The point of no return has been reached.” Checked How five dirty men and a 'Middle Eastern' family ended up in the same photo Another pro-Russian channel on Telegram with more than half a million followers writes about the images:  “A bit of horror. This is how the graduating classes in Denmark have changed over 15 years. If we don't stop the development, we'll soon have the same thing here.”  It is no coincidence that the images have been picked up by pro-Russian actors. The images support a theory of population replacement, which states that Danes will be outnumbered in Denmark in the future in favor of a Muslim majority.  A theory that Russia has often  promoted  because it serves as an example of Western decay for Russia, while at the same time the theory is used to create national cohesion within Russia.  Sign up for the CheckIt newsletter The theory has existed for many years, and is also known internationally as “ The Great Replacement ” - which is perhaps why the posts about schools in Denmark have been shared by so many people on social media.  This is not the first time that Danish schoolchildren have been abused to create a similar false narrative. TjekDet has previously reported how a video of students on a field trip was abused to claim that the students had converted to Islam.

The first (2010/2011) is from 9A at Bjerregrav School near Randers, a regular elementary school with mostly ethnically Danish students.  The second (2017/2018) is from an international private school near Copenhagen with many Muslim students, not from 2025 as claimed.  At Bjerregrav School, the proportion of non-Western students actually decreased from 2.6% in 2010/11 to 0% in 2023/24, contradicting claims of population replacement at that school.  Nationally, there has been a small increase in students with non-Western backgrounds (from 9.1% in 2010/11 to 11.8% in 2023/24), but this does not support the dramatic claim implied by the photos.  The photos have been used by far-right and pro-Russian actors to promote a misleading narrative of population replacement, exploiting the images out of context. Verdict: The claim is false. Key Evidence: Investigation revealed that the two photos are not from the same school or class. The first photo was taken in 2010/2011 at Bjerregrav School in Randers, while the second photo was taken in 2017/2018 at an international private school near Copenhagen with many Muslim students. The headmaster of Bjerregrav School confirmed the photo's origin and expressed upset over its misuse. Statistics from the Ministry of Children and Education showed that the proportion of non-Western students at Bjerregrav School actually decreased from 2.6% to 0% between 2010/2011 and 2023/2024. Nationally, the proportion of non-Western students increased slightly from 9.1% to 11.8% during the same period. Verdict: False. The claim is based on a misleading comparison of two unrelated photos, and the statistics do not support the narrative of a population replacement in Denmark. The photos have been spread by pro-Russian actors to promote a theory of Western decay.
llama_evaluation: Here's the verdict: Claim: The claim being evaluated is that two class photos from Danish schools, one from 2010 and one from 2025, document a population replacement in Denmark, implying a significant shift in the demographic composition of the country. Verdict: False Explanation: The claim is false because the two photos are not from the same school or class, and the dates and contexts are different. The photo labeled as being from 2025 was actually taken in 2017/2018 at an international private school near Copenhagen with many Muslim students, while the other photo was taken in 2010/2011 at a regular elementary school in Randers. Furthermore, statistics from the Ministry of Children and Education show that the specific school in Randers did not experience an increase in non-Western students, contradicting the narrative of population replacement. The photos have been misused to promote a misleading narrative, likely as part of a larger disinformation campaign.

headline: Has your Big Mac gotten significantly smaller since the 1980s?
summary: Several viral posts on social media claim that the McDonald's Big Mac has shrunk by 40 percent since 1980.      A picture of a Big Mac, supposedly from the 1980s, is used as documentation.      But TjekDets research shows that there is no indication that the popular burger has shrunk in recent decades.
text: This is the fact to chek: A sure winner among hangover-stricken Danes on January 1st is McDonalds - and many probably swear by one of their signature burgers - the Big Mac. But would you have been fuller if you had sunk your teeth into a Big Mac back in the 1980s? At least that's what several posts on Facebook claim, which are currently being seen by thousands of users. The posts claim that the burger has shrunk significantly in size , while at the same time increasing significantly in price . The claim is widespread in both Danish and English Facebook posts . One of the English posts has 29,000 shares , while another has been shared more than 9,000 times . Some of the posts claim that the burger has become 40 percent smaller . As documentation, many of the posts use the same image, which shows two Big Macs. One is supposedly from the 1980s, while the other is from 2024. If the image is to be believed, then there is a significant size difference. This image is repeated in numerous posts, where it is claimed that McDonald's Big Mac has shrunk significantly since the happy 80s (Photo: Screenshot of Facebook). But while it might take two Big Macs to cure your hangover today, it wouldn't have been any different in the 1980s According to TjekDet's research, there is no indication that the Big Mac has shrunk since the 1980s. However, it has increased in price - although not very much if you take inflation into account. The price increase According to an article from the Pennsylvania Center for the Book, the Big Mac was first introduced in the 1960s by Jim Delligatti, who owned a number of McDonald's restaurants in Pittsburgh, USA. In 1968, the Big Mac was added to the menu at all McDonald's restaurants in the United States. And the price? It was 45 cents. If you use an inflation converter to calculate what 45 cents in 1968 is worth today, the answer is just over $4. Today, a Big Mac in the USA costs $5.69 - equivalent to just over 40 Danish kroner, while the normal price in Denmark is 39 kroner for one of the popular burgers. From country to country, there is virtually no difference in what a Big Mac looks like. That is why the media outlet “The Economist” has published  the “Big Mac Index” since 1986 as a way to compare price levels across borders and currencies. In 2024,  “The Economist” has calculated that Switzerland will have the world's most expensive Big Mac with a price of $8.17 - equivalent to about 58 Danish kroner. But what about the size? The price is one thing, but what happened to the size of the Big Mac? Some of the posts on social media claim that the burger has become 40 percent smaller since 1980. If you ask McDonald's press department in Denmark, they flatly deny that the Big Mac has changed size. “The size of Big Mac's has not changed since McDonald's came to Denmark in 1981. We are not allowed to do that at all,” says Mads Jensen, a communications officer at McDonald's. Today, McDonald's Danish website states that a Big Mac contains 510 calories. If you look at the American version , it contains 590 calories. But on neither the Danish nor the American website can you see how much a Big Mac weighs. Therefore, TjekDet bought three Big Mac's at three different McDonald's restaurants in Copenhagen and here the weight was 200 grams, 206 grams and 222 grams. By using the Wayback Machine, which is an internet archiving tool, TjekDet has managed to find the content description for a Big Mac in Denmark back in 2001 . Back then, a Big Mac weighed 209 grams and contained 2137 kJ, which corresponds to 511 calories. In terms of both weight and calories, the Big Mac is basically the same today as it was more than 20 years ago, so you shouldn't feel cheated when you sink your teeth into a Big Mac in 2025. However, the number of calories has varied a little. In 2019, McDonald's website stated that there were 503 calories in a Big Mac, while in 2022 there were 487 calories - and as previously mentioned - today there are 510 calories in one of the popular burgers.  In 2020, McDonald's in Denmark had a turnover of 2.7 billion kroner, McDonald's writes on its own website. Photo: Shutterstock More calories in Everything is bigger in the USA sounds like a cool phrase, but when it comes to Big Macs, there isn't much difference between Denmark and the USA. For Big Macs in the US, there are significantly more content designations to dig up than in recent decades, and there is nothing to suggest that the Big Mac has shrunk in size. The biggest difference from Denmark is the number of calories, which is generally higher in the US than in Denmark. In 1996 we can see that there were 530 calories in an American Big Mac , so there are actually more calories in the burger in 2025 than back then - namely 590 calories. In 2003, we can see that the burger weighed 216 grams, which is roughly consistent with the results that TjekDet obtained. Even though we can't go back any further than 1996 for the USA and 2001 for Denmark, there is no documentation that the popular burger has become smaller.
chatgpt_generation: No, the Big Mac Has Not Shrunk Since the 1980s – Viral Claim Is False
chatgpt_condensation: Big Mac size has not shrunk: Despite viral social media claims and images suggesting otherwise, there is no evidence that the Big Mac has become smaller since the 1980s. Weight and calorie data from both Denmark and the U.S. show consistent size over time.  Price has increased, but inflation-adjusted: While the price of a Big Mac has risen since its introduction, the increase is modest when adjusted for inflation. For example, the 1968 price of 45 cents in the U.S. equates to just over \$4 today, compared to the current price of \$5.69.  Calorie count varies slightly: The Big Mac's calorie content has fluctuated slightly over the years but remains in the same general range, with no major size reduction implied by these changes.
chatgpt_evaluation: Verdict: False The claim that the Big Mac has shrunk significantly in size since the 1980s is not supported by evidence. Research shows that the burger’s weight and calorie content have remained largely consistent over the years. While the price has increased, it aligns reasonably with inflation. Therefore, the claim circulating on social media is false.

grok_evaluation: The claim that the Big Mac has shrunk significantly in size since the 1980s is false. Evidence from TjekDet's investigation, McDonald's Denmark, and historical data (e.g., 209 grams in 2001 vs. 200–222 grams in 2024) shows no significant size reduction. While the price has increased, this is largely consistent with inflation, and calorie counts have slightly varied but do not support claims of a smaller burger.

headline: Has your Big Mac gotten significantly smaller since the 1980s?
summary: Several viral posts on social media claim that the McDonald's Big Mac has shrunk by 40 percent since 1980.      A picture of a Big Mac, supposedly from the 1980s, is used as documentation.      But TjekDets research shows that there is no indication that the popular burger has shrunk in recent decades.
text: This is the fact to chek: A sure winner among hangover-stricken Danes on January 1st is McDonalds - and many probably swear by one of their signature burgers - the Big Mac. But would you have been fuller if you had sunk your teeth into a Big Mac back in the 1980s? At least that's what several posts on Facebook claim, which are currently being seen by thousands of users. The posts claim that the burger has shrunk significantly in size , while at the same time increasing significantly in price . The claim is widespread in both Danish and English Facebook posts . One of the English posts has 29,000 shares , while another has been shared more than 9,000 times . Some of the posts claim that the burger has become 40 percent smaller . As documentation, many of the posts use the same image, which shows two Big Macs. One is supposedly from the 1980s, while the other is from 2024. If the image is to be believed, then there is a significant size difference. This image is repeated in numerous posts, where it is claimed that McDonald's Big Mac has shrunk significantly since the happy 80s (Photo: Screenshot of Facebook). But while it might take two Big Macs to cure your hangover today, it wouldn't have been any different in the 1980s According to TjekDet's research, there is no indication that the Big Mac has shrunk since the 1980s. However, it has increased in price - although not very much if you take inflation into account. The price increase According to an article from the Pennsylvania Center for the Book, the Big Mac was first introduced in the 1960s by Jim Delligatti, who owned a number of McDonald's restaurants in Pittsburgh, USA. In 1968, the Big Mac was added to the menu at all McDonald's restaurants in the United States. And the price? It was 45 cents. If you use an inflation converter to calculate what 45 cents in 1968 is worth today, the answer is just over $4. Today, a Big Mac in the USA costs $5.69 - equivalent to just over 40 Danish kroner, while the normal price in Denmark is 39 kroner for one of the popular burgers. From country to country, there is virtually no difference in what a Big Mac looks like. That is why the media outlet “The Economist” has published  the “Big Mac Index” since 1986 as a way to compare price levels across borders and currencies. In 2024,  “The Economist” has calculated that Switzerland will have the world's most expensive Big Mac with a price of $8.17 - equivalent to about 58 Danish kroner. But what about the size? The price is one thing, but what happened to the size of the Big Mac? Some of the posts on social media claim that the burger has become 40 percent smaller since 1980. If you ask McDonald's press department in Denmark, they flatly deny that the Big Mac has changed size. “The size of Big Mac's has not changed since McDonald's came to Denmark in 1981. We are not allowed to do that at all,” says Mads Jensen, a communications officer at McDonald's. Today, McDonald's Danish website states that a Big Mac contains 510 calories. If you look at the American version , it contains 590 calories. But on neither the Danish nor the American website can you see how much a Big Mac weighs. Therefore, TjekDet bought three Big Mac's at three different McDonald's restaurants in Copenhagen and here the weight was 200 grams, 206 grams and 222 grams. By using the Wayback Machine, which is an internet archiving tool, TjekDet has managed to find the content description for a Big Mac in Denmark back in 2001 . Back then, a Big Mac weighed 209 grams and contained 2137 kJ, which corresponds to 511 calories. In terms of both weight and calories, the Big Mac is basically the same today as it was more than 20 years ago, so you shouldn't feel cheated when you sink your teeth into a Big Mac in 2025. However, the number of calories has varied a little. In 2019, McDonald's website stated that there were 503 calories in a Big Mac, while in 2022 there were 487 calories - and as previously mentioned - today there are 510 calories in one of the popular burgers.  In 2020, McDonald's in Denmark had a turnover of 2.7 billion kroner, McDonald's writes on its own website. Photo: Shutterstock More calories in Everything is bigger in the USA sounds like a cool phrase, but when it comes to Big Macs, there isn't much difference between Denmark and the USA. For Big Macs in the US, there are significantly more content designations to dig up than in recent decades, and there is nothing to suggest that the Big Mac has shrunk in size. The biggest difference from Denmark is the number of calories, which is generally higher in the US than in Denmark. In 1996 we can see that there were 530 calories in an American Big Mac , so there are actually more calories in the burger in 2025 than back then - namely 590 calories. In 2003, we can see that the burger weighed 216 grams, which is roughly consistent with the results that TjekDet obtained. Even though we can't go back any further than 1996 for the USA and 2001 for Denmark, there is no documentation that the popular burger has become smaller.

Calorie counts have remained consistent over time, with slight fluctuations. McDonald's Denmark denies any size changes, and archived data from the US also shows no substantial size reduction since at least 1996.  The verdict: False – There is no credible evidence that the Big Mac has shrunk in size since the 1980s. The burger's weight and caloric content have remained largely consistent, and inflation-adjusted price increases are modest.

headline: Has your Big Mac gotten significantly smaller since the 1980s?
summary: Several viral posts on social media claim that the McDonald's Big Mac has shrunk by 40 percent since 1980.      A picture of a Big Mac, supposedly from the 1980s, is used as documentation.      But TjekDets research shows that there is no indication that the popular burger has shrunk in recent decades.
text: This is the fact to chek: A sure winner among hangover-stricken Danes on January 1st is McDonalds - and many probably swear by one of their signature burgers - the Big Mac. But would you have been fuller if you had sunk your teeth into a Big Mac back in the 1980s? At least that's what several posts on Facebook claim, which are currently being seen by thousands of users. The posts claim that the burger has shrunk significantly in size , while at the same time increasing significantly in price . The claim is widespread in both Danish and English Facebook posts . One of the English posts has 29,000 shares , while another has been shared more than 9,000 times . Some of the posts claim that the burger has become 40 percent smaller . As documentation, many of the posts use the same image, which shows two Big Macs. One is supposedly from the 1980s, while the other is from 2024. If the image is to be believed, then there is a significant size difference. This image is repeated in numerous posts, where it is claimed that McDonald's Big Mac has shrunk significantly since the happy 80s (Photo: Screenshot of Facebook). But while it might take two Big Macs to cure your hangover today, it wouldn't have been any different in the 1980s According to TjekDet's research, there is no indication that the Big Mac has shrunk since the 1980s. However, it has increased in price - although not very much if you take inflation into account. The price increase According to an article from the Pennsylvania Center for the Book, the Big Mac was first introduced in the 1960s by Jim Delligatti, who owned a number of McDonald's restaurants in Pittsburgh, USA. In 1968, the Big Mac was added to the menu at all McDonald's restaurants in the United States. And the price? It was 45 cents. If you use an inflation converter to calculate what 45 cents in 1968 is worth today, the answer is just over $4. Today, a Big Mac in the USA costs $5.69 - equivalent to just over 40 Danish kroner, while the normal price in Denmark is 39 kroner for one of the popular burgers. From country to country, there is virtually no difference in what a Big Mac looks like. That is why the media outlet “The Economist” has published  the “Big Mac Index” since 1986 as a way to compare price levels across borders and currencies. In 2024,  “The Economist” has calculated that Switzerland will have the world's most expensive Big Mac with a price of $8.17 - equivalent to about 58 Danish kroner. But what about the size? The price is one thing, but what happened to the size of the Big Mac? Some of the posts on social media claim that the burger has become 40 percent smaller since 1980. If you ask McDonald's press department in Denmark, they flatly deny that the Big Mac has changed size. “The size of Big Mac's has not changed since McDonald's came to Denmark in 1981. We are not allowed to do that at all,” says Mads Jensen, a communications officer at McDonald's. Today, McDonald's Danish website states that a Big Mac contains 510 calories. If you look at the American version , it contains 590 calories. But on neither the Danish nor the American website can you see how much a Big Mac weighs. Therefore, TjekDet bought three Big Mac's at three different McDonald's restaurants in Copenhagen and here the weight was 200 grams, 206 grams and 222 grams. By using the Wayback Machine, which is an internet archiving tool, TjekDet has managed to find the content description for a Big Mac in Denmark back in 2001 . Back then, a Big Mac weighed 209 grams and contained 2137 kJ, which corresponds to 511 calories. In terms of both weight and calories, the Big Mac is basically the same today as it was more than 20 years ago, so you shouldn't feel cheated when you sink your teeth into a Big Mac in 2025. However, the number of calories has varied a little. In 2019, McDonald's website stated that there were 503 calories in a Big Mac, while in 2022 there were 487 calories - and as previously mentioned - today there are 510 calories in one of the popular burgers.  In 2020, McDonald's in Denmark had a turnover of 2.7 billion kroner, McDonald's writes on its own website. Photo: Shutterstock More calories in Everything is bigger in the USA sounds like a cool phrase, but when it comes to Big Macs, there isn't much difference between Denmark and the USA. For Big Macs in the US, there are significantly more content designations to dig up than in recent decades, and there is nothing to suggest that the Big Mac has shrunk in size. The biggest difference from Denmark is the number of calories, which is generally higher in the US than in Denmark. In 1996 we can see that there were 530 calories in an American Big Mac , so there are actually more calories in the burger in 2025 than back then - namely 590 calories. In 2003, we can see that the burger weighed 216 grams, which is roughly consistent with the results that TjekDet obtained. Even though we can't go back any further than 1996 for the USA and 2001 for Denmark, there is no documentation that the popular burger has become smaller.

chatgpt_condensation: Claim: Social media posts widely claim that McDonald’s Big Mac has significantly shrunk in size—by as much as 40%—since the 1980s, while its price has increased substantially. Evidence:  McDonald’s Denmark denies any change in Big Mac size since 1981, stating it is not allowed to alter it.  Contemporary Big Macs in Denmark weigh around 200–220 grams and contain about 510 calories.  Archived data from 2001 shows a Big Mac weighed 209 grams with 511 calories, almost identical to today’s measurements.  In the US, historical data from 1996 and 2003 shows similar weight and calorie content to current Big Macs.  Price-wise, while the nominal cost of a Big Mac has increased, adjusted for inflation, the price rise is moderate (e.g., 45 cents in 1968 equals about \$4 today; the current US price is around \$5.69).  The “Big Mac Index” confirms price variations across countries but does not indicate size changes. Verdict: False. There is no credible evidence that the Big Mac has shrunk in size since the 1980s. Weight and calorie data from past decades closely match current measurements, and McDonald’s official statements confirm the size has remained consistent. The price has increased, but the increase is moderate when accounting for inflation. Therefore, claims of a significant size reduction are unsubstantiated.

headline: Is it true that over half of Ukrainians would give up land for peace?
summary: Assertion The majority of the Ukrainian population now says, according to Gallup, that they want an end to the war. They want peace negotiations, cede territories, rather than continue this war. Conclusion It is true, according to the 2024 poll, that 52 percent of the population wants peace negotiations to end the war as soon as possible. However, it is not true that half the population wants to cede territories. The survey only asked respondents who already wanted peace negotiations whether they were open to ceding territories. Here again, 52 percent answered yes.
text: This is the fact-check: During NRK's ​​Debatten on May 20, the leader of the Peace and Justice Party (FOR), Marielle Leraand, brought up an opinion poll conducted by the American analysis agency Gallup . The agency regularly conducts surveys in Ukraine as part of its World Poll .Leraand claimed that a majority of Ukrainians want peace negotiations, even if it means giving up parts of the country.We have reviewed the numbers to find out if her claim is true.It is true that over half (52 percent) of those surveyed said they wanted Ukraine to enter peace negotiations as soon as possible.However, it is not true that the majority have said they want to give up land. The survey only asked the question of whether Ukraine should give up land to those who responded that they wanted peace negotiations. It is not surprising that a people at war can imagine peace. The big question is what kind of peace they want, and at what price.
