headline: Is it true that over half of Ukrainians would give up land for peace?
summary: Assertion The majority of the Ukrainian population now says, according to Gallup, that they want an end to the war. They want peace negotiations, cede territories, rather than continue this war. Conclusion It is true, according to the 2024 poll, that 52 percent of the population wants peace negotiations to end the war as soon as possible. However, it is not true that half the population wants to cede territories. The survey only asked respondents who already wanted peace negotiations whether they were open to ceding territories. Here again, 52 percent answered yes.
text: This is the fact-check: During NRK's ​​Debatten on May 20, the leader of the Peace and Justice Party (FOR), Marielle Leraand, brought up an opinion poll conducted by the American analysis agency Gallup . The agency regularly conducts surveys in Ukraine as part of its World Poll .Leraand claimed that a majority of Ukrainians want peace negotiations, even if it means giving up parts of the country.We have reviewed the numbers to find out if her claim is true.It is true that over half (52 percent) of those surveyed said they wanted Ukraine to enter peace negotiations as soon as possible.However, it is not true that the majority have said they want to give up land. The survey only asked the question of whether Ukraine should give up land to those who responded that they wanted peace negotiations. Of these, 52 percent responded that they wanted to give up land in negotiations. 38 percent responded that they did not want this, and nine percent were unsure or refrained from answering.When asked first whether Ukraine should negotiate or continue fighting, 38 percent said the country should continue fighting until it wins the war. This is a decrease from Gallup's previous surveys from 2023 and 2022. In 2022, 73 percent were in favor of continuing to fight, and 63 percent said the same in 2023.Both VG and NRK have investigated several of the allegations that emerged during the Debate.The Gallup poll was conducted in August and October 2024, with the figures published in November of the same year. It is reported that the agency is unable to conduct the surveys in occupied territories due to lack of coverage by Ukrainian telecom operators. This means that approximately 10–12 percent of the population is excluded from the surveys.The agency has regularly conducted surveys in Ukraine. In an article, they explain the challenges involved in conducting surveys in a war zone .Professor at the Department of Political Science at the University of Oslo, Jørgen Bølstad, tells Faktisk.no that even though the surveys were conducted in a country at war, we can read something from them.Bølstad also explains that there is consistency between the surveys from Gallup and other surveys, including those from the Kyiv Institute of Sociology  (KIIS).– Findings from KIIS indicate that around 38 percent are willing to give up land to get a quick peace agreement, while 51 percent are not, says Bølstad.– This also illustrates that the wording of the questions is absolutely crucial. It is not surprising that a people at war can imagine peace. The big question is what kind of peace they want, and at what price. It is unlikely that many people want the West to stop sending aid.He also says that it is important to take into account that the surveys were conducted a few months ago, and that things may have changed in the meantime.– Difficult to explain all the detailsFOR leader Marielle Leraand writes in an email to Faktisk.no that the format of the Debate made it difficult to explain all the details of the survey.– The answer options in the survey were “Ukraine should continue fighting until it wins the war”. 38 percent thought this. The Norwegian public has created the impression that an overwhelming majority of Ukrainians will continue to fight.– But 52 percent thought that: “Ukraine should seek to negotiate an ending to the war as soon as possible”. That is what we in FOR think. We do not have a specific opinion about what the negotiation result should be.

chatgpt_condensation: Assertion: Marielle Leraand, leader of the Peace and Justice Party (FOR), claimed during NRK's Debatten that a majority of Ukrainians want peace negotiations, even if it means giving up parts of the country. Conclusion: Mixed. It is true that a majority (52%) of Ukrainians surveyed by Gallup want peace negotiations as soon as possible. However, it is false that a majority of Ukrainians support giving up territory to achieve peace. Only those who supported negotiations were asked about territorial concessions, and among them, 52% said they would accept giving up land—meaning this view represents only a subset of the total population. Therefore, Leraand's statement misrepresents the broader survey results.

Reasoning/Evidence:  It is true that a majority (52%) of Ukrainians surveyed want to enter peace negotiations as soon as possible.  However, only those who supported negotiations were asked if they would accept giving up land, and among them, 52% agreed to territorial concessions. gemini_condensation: Assertion: Marielle Leraand, leader of the Peace and Justice Party (FOR), claimed during NRK's Debatten on May 20 that a majority of Ukrainians want peace negotiations, even if it means giving up parts of the country, based on a Gallup World Poll conducted in August and October 2024. Conclusion: Mixed. It is true that the Gallup poll found a majority of Ukrainians (52 percent) want Ukraine to enter peace negotiations as soon as possible. This marks a shift from previous Gallup surveys in 2022 (73 percent wanted to continue fighting) and 2023 (63 percent). However, it is false that the majority of all Ukrainians surveyed said they wanted to give up land. The question about giving up land was only asked to the 52 percent who responded that they wanted peace negotiations. Of this specific group, 52 percent responded that they wanted to give up land in negotiations, while 38 percent did not, and nine percent were unsure or refrained. This means that only approximately 27% (52% of 52%) of the total surveyed population expressed a willingness to give up land for peace. Therefore, while a majority desired peace negotiations, it's not accurate to claim a majority of all Ukrainians surveyed were willing to cede territory. The nuances of the survey questions and the specific subgroups asked are crucial to the interpretation. The fact-check also notes consistency with other surveys, like KIIS, which indicated around 38 percent are willing to give up land for a quick peace agreement, while 51 percent are not.
gemini_evaluation: Here's the verdict for the fact-check: 1. What is the claim being assessed? Marielle Leraand, leader of the Peace and Justice Party (FOR), claimed that a majority of Ukrainians want peace negotiations even if it means giving up parts of the country, based on a Gallup opinion poll. 2. What is the verdict (true/false/mixed)? Mixed. 3. What reasoning or evidence supports the conclusion?  True Part: The Gallup poll (conducted August-October 2024, published November 2024) does show that over half (52 percent) of those surveyed wanted Ukraine to enter peace negotiations as soon as possible. This represents a significant shift from previous Gallup surveys in 2022 (73% favored continuing to fight) and 2023 (63% favored continuing to fight).  False Part: It is not true that a majority of all Ukrainians surveyed said they wanted to give up land. The question about giving up land was only posed to the subgroup of respondents (52% of the total) who had already indicated a desire for peace negotiations. Of this subgroup, 52 percent did respond that they wanted to give up land in negotiations. However, 38 percent of this subgroup did not want to give up land, and 9 percent were unsure. This means that only approximately 27% (52% of the 52% who wanted negotiations) of the total surveyed population explicitly expressed a willingness to cede territory for peace.  Supporting Nuance: The fact-check also highlights that 38 percent of the total surveyed population still believed Ukraine should continue fighting until it wins. Professor Jørgen Bølstad of the University of Oslo also points out that other surveys, such as those from the Kyiv Institute of Sociology (KIIS), indicate around 38 percent are willing to give up land for a quick peace agreement, while 51 percent are not, reinforcing that the wording of questions is crucial and the desire for peace does not automatically equate to a willingness to concede territory.

headline: Is it true that over half of Ukrainians would give up land for peace?
summary: Assertion The majority of the Ukrainian population now says, according to Gallup, that they want an end to the war. They want peace negotiations, cede territories, rather than continue this war. Conclusion It is true, according to the 2024 poll, that 52 percent of the population wants peace negotiations to end the war as soon as possible. However, it is not true that half the population wants to cede territories. The survey only asked respondents who already wanted peace negotiations whether they were open to ceding territories. Here again, 52 percent answered yes.
text: This is the fact-check: During NRK's ​​Debatten on May 20, the leader of the Peace and Justice Party (FOR), Marielle Leraand, brought up an opinion poll conducted by the American analysis agency Gallup . The agency regularly conducts surveys in Ukraine as part of its World Poll .Leraand claimed that a majority of Ukrainians want peace negotiations, even if it means giving up parts of the country.We have reviewed the numbers to find out if her claim is true.It is true that over half (52 percent) of those surveyed said they wanted Ukraine to enter peace negotiations as soon as possible.However, it is not true that the majority have said they want to give up land. The survey only asked the question of whether Ukraine should give up land to those who responded that they wanted peace negotiations. Of these, 52 percent responded that they wanted to give up land in negotiations. 38 percent responded that they did not want this, and nine percent were unsure or refrained from answering.When asked first whether Ukraine should negotiate or continue fighting, 38 percent said the country should continue fighting until it wins the war. This is a decrease from Gallup's previous surveys from 2023 and 2022. In 2022, 73 percent were in favor of continuing to fight, and 63 percent said the same in 2023.Both VG and NRK have investigated several of the allegations that emerged during the Debate.The Gallup poll was conducted in August and October 2024, with the figures published in November of the same year. It is reported that the agency is unable to conduct the surveys in occupied territories due to lack of coverage by Ukrainian telecom operators. This means that approximately 10–12 percent of the population is excluded from the surveys.The agency has regularly conducted surveys in Ukraine. In an article, they explain the challenges involved in conducting surveys in a war zone .Professor at the Department of Political Science at the University of Oslo, Jørgen Bølstad, tells Faktisk.no that even though the surveys were conducted in a country at war, we can read something from them.Bølstad also explains that there is consistency between the surveys from Gallup and other surveys, including those from the Kyiv Institute of Sociology  (KIIS).– Findings from KIIS indicate that around 38 percent are willing to give up land to get a quick peace agreement, while 51 percent are not, says Bølstad.– This also illustrates that the wording of the questions is absolutely crucial. It is not surprising that a people at war can imagine peace. The big question is what kind of peace they want, and at what price. It is unlikely that many people want the West to stop sending aid.He also says that it is important to take into account that the surveys were conducted a few months ago, and that things may have changed in the meantime.– Difficult to explain all the detailsFOR leader Marielle Leraand writes in an email to Faktisk.no that the format of the Debate made it difficult to explain all the details of the survey.– The answer options in the survey were “Ukraine should continue fighting until it wins the war”. 38 percent thought this. The Norwegian public has created the impression that an overwhelming majority of Ukrainians will continue to fight.– But 52 percent thought that: “Ukraine should seek to negotiate an ending to the war as soon as possible”. That is what we in FOR think. We do not have a specific opinion about what the negotiation result should be.

headline: Claims that ski wax pollutes Oslo's drinking water
summary: Assertion:In areas where a lot of ski lubrication is used, there is extra PFAS (a type of synthetic substance). It ends up in Maridalsvannet and is not cleaned. I can guarantee you that the water you get from the tap contains a lot of crap.Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), republished by @vannrenser.no on TikTokConclusion:The drinking water in Oslo undergoes rigorous testing, is monitored weekly, and meets all requirements of the Drinking Water Regulations. It is safe to drink, and a water filter is not necessary. PFAS can occur in drinking water, but the levels are well below safe limits.
text: According to influencer and artist Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), and the company Vannrenser.no, Oslo's drinking water from Maridalen is so polluted that we are advised to purchase a water filter to purify our drinking water. TikTok user @vannrenser.no is apparently advertising the website of the same name , where you can purchase the filters. According to the website, the so-called reverse osmosis filter is supposed to remove absolutely all contaminants, which in turn can lead to increased energy levels and help us get rid of brain fog. The website Vannrenser.no mentions the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (FHI) several times on its website. Faktisk.no has obtained access to emails between Vannrenser.no and FHI, in which the latter asks the company to moderate the references on its website and remove the FHI logo. Get Faktisk.no straight to your inbox.  Click here to sign up for our weekly newsletter . This is what one of the places on the website Vannrenser.no looks like where FHI's name is used. Screenshot Vannrenser.noFollowing the email correspondence, Vannrenser.no has moderated the text somewhat and they have removed the logo and instead written FHI in capital letters - along with other logos.As Marianne Steinberg, senior advisor at FHI, sees it, the company has not complied with FHI's requirements. – In the correspondence a few months ago, FHI asked the website to remove the reference to us through the logo and previous comments on some of Vannrenser.no's professional content that FHI believes gives the wrong impression of what they inform about, says Steinberg. Steinberg clarifies above Faktisk.no what FHI's advice regarding drinking water is:  – It is not necessary to purify drinking water from a waterworks with a filter or other post-treatment. The vast majority of people get their drinking water from a waterworks, which treats the water so that it is safe to drink. But could there be something to be said for a water filter like Pimp Lotion claims in the video posted by the company? The user @vannrenser.no on TikTok uses a clip of Thomas Thrap Huse talking about water quality and water filtration. Screenshot TikTokTests weekly– The drinking water in Oslo, including from Maridalsvannet, is safe and meets all requirements in the drinking water regulations . This is what Toril Giske, functional manager for water quality at the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration, tells Faktisk.no. She explains that they conduct frequent tests to ensure that the quality of drinking water is always high.– The claims made in the podcast do not provide a balanced or fact-based picture of water quality in Oslo. The Water and Wastewater Agency relies on extensive monitoring and scientific documentation to ensure that the drinking water supplied to Oslo's population is safe and good. She adds: The Norwegian Institute of Public Health:These are PFASPFAS are a large group of man-made synthetic substances, of which there are approximately 10,000.PFAS have been used for over 50 years in a variety of products, including food packaging, non-stick coatings for pots and pans, textile impregnation agents, fire-fighting foams, cleaning products, cosmetics, paints, varnishes and some types of ski lubricants. In addition, fire-fighting foams have been found to be an important source of PFAS in the environment in Norway.PFAS are not produced in Norway. Everything that is traded is imported, either in the form of chemical-technical products or as a component in solid processed products.PFAS are widely distributed in the environment. Animals at the top of the food chain have higher amounts of a number of these substances in their bodies than animals further down the food chain.Source: NIPH and NIVA– This involves weekly sampling at the water treatment plants and in the pipeline network. This is done in accordance with the requirements set for water utility owners in the Drinking Water Regulations.– Found everywhereIn the aforementioned podcast, Thomas Thrap Huse focuses particularly on PFAS (see fact box) in drinking water as one of the main reasons why he believes it is wise to use a reverse osmosis filter. PFAS are substances that are very stable and are therefore referred to as forever chemicals. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen, who researches environmental chemicals at the Norwegian Institute for Water Research (NIVA), tells Faktisk.no. “PFAS are often added to the surface of a product and can be washed off during use and washing. Because PFAS have so many different uses, we find the substances almost everywhere, both outdoors and indoors,” says Gundersen.She points out that virtually all people have PFASs in their blood because some of these substances are found almost everywhere. We do not have thorough data on the harmful effects of all types of PFAS, but several types have been linked to harmful effects that can, among other things, disrupt the immune system, reduce the effectiveness of vaccines, inhibit fetal development and be carcinogenic. Very low levelsThe level of PFAS in drinking water has recently been investigated in Southern Norway, including in Maridalsvannet. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen has a PhD in environmental chemistry and is a researcher at the Norwegian Institute for Water Resources (NIVA). Photo: NIVA. – Not surprisingly, PFAS was found, but at low levels that are below the most stringent international drinking water limits. PFAS in drinking water from public waterworks in southern parts of Norway is low and therefore drinking water is not considered a significant source,  says Gundersen.This is also confirmed by Toril Giske from the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration. At the same time, she says that it is true that PFAS can be found in some types of ski lubricant: – We regularly monitor water quality and analyze, among other things, for PFAS, which can be found in certain types of ski lubricant. When it comes to PFAS, we analyze quarterly for 17 different compounds at both of our raw water sources, Maridalsvannet and Elvåga. According to Giske, none of these compounds were detected in samples taken at Elvåga in 2024. – In samples from Maridalsvannet, we have found a few of these (3 out of 17), but these are very low values that are well below the prescribed limit value for PFAS compounds in the new drinking water regulations. Giske tells Faktisk.no that the water quality is safe and is continuously monitored.Drinking water not the main sourceShe says that the most important source of PFAS for humans is the food we eat. This is also stated by the EU's EFSA, which carries out risk assessments on the levels of PFAS that humans can ingest. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen at NIVA therefore believes that it is generally not necessary to use a reverse osmosis filter in Norway. – To reduce exposure to PFAS, it is recommended to be aware of which products you buy and surround yourself with. Products marked with the Nordic Ecolabel guarantee to be free of PFAS, says Gundersen.The researcher believes that places where such a filter might be appropriate are at private water sources, such as a well, located near a firefighting training area or at places where PFAS has previously been produced. But Gundersen adds that the water utility is responsible for ensuring that public water supplies are of sufficiently good quality.

Conclusion: The fact-check finds the claim to be false and misleading. Oslo’s drinking water, including from Maridalsvannet, is safe, regularly tested, and meets all regulatory standards. PFAS chemicals are detected only at very low levels well below safety limits, and drinking water is not considered a significant source of PFAS exposure. The Norwegian Institute of Public Health and Water and Sewage Administration advise that no filtration is necessary for public water supplies. The company’s use of FHI’s name and logo was inappropriate and has been moderated following requests. Overall, the water quality is good, and the advertised filters are not necessary for the general population.
chatgpt_evaluation: The verdict for the fact-check is False. The claim that Oslo’s drinking water from Maridalen is so polluted that people need to buy reverse osmosis filters to purify it is not supported by evidence. The water is safe, well-regulated, and contains only very low, safe levels of contaminants like PFAS.
gemini_generation: Claim That Oslo's Drinking Water Is Polluted and Needs Filtering Is False
gemini_condensation: Assertion: Influencer Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion) and the company Vannrenser.no claim that Oslo's drinking water from Maridalen is so polluted, particularly with PFAS, that it necessitates the purchase of a reverse osmosis filter to purify it, leading to benefits like increased energy and reduced brain fog. Conclusion: The claim is false. The Norwegian Institute of Public Health (FHI) and the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration confirm that Oslo's drinking water from Maridalen is safe, meets all drinking water regulations, and does not require additional filtering. While PFAS are present in the environment and in Oslo's water, the levels are very low, well below international limits, and drinking water is not considered a significant source of PFAS exposure for humans. FHI explicitly states that it is not necessary to purify public drinking water with a filter. Vannrenser.no has also been asked by FHI to moderate its references to the institute due to misleading impressions.
gemini_evaluation: The verdict for the fact-check is False.

headline: Claims that ski wax pollutes Oslo's drinking water
summary: Assertion:In areas where a lot of ski lubrication is used, there is extra PFAS (a type of synthetic substance). It ends up in Maridalsvannet and is not cleaned. I can guarantee you that the water you get from the tap contains a lot of crap.Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), republished by @vannrenser.no on TikTokConclusion:The drinking water in Oslo undergoes rigorous testing, is monitored weekly, and meets all requirements of the Drinking Water Regulations. It is safe to drink, and a water filter is not necessary. PFAS can occur in drinking water, but the levels are well below safe limits.
text: According to influencer and artist Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), and the company Vannrenser.no, Oslo's drinking water from Maridalen is so polluted that we are advised to purchase a water filter to purify our drinking water. TikTok user @vannrenser.no is apparently advertising the website of the same name , where you can purchase the filters. According to the website, the so-called reverse osmosis filter is supposed to remove absolutely all contaminants, which in turn can lead to increased energy levels and help us get rid of brain fog. The website Vannrenser.no mentions the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (FHI) several times on its website. Faktisk.no has obtained access to emails between Vannrenser.no and FHI, in which the latter asks the company to moderate the references on its website and remove the FHI logo. Get Faktisk.no straight to your inbox.  Click here to sign up for our weekly newsletter . This is what one of the places on the website Vannrenser.no looks like where FHI's name is used. Screenshot Vannrenser.noFollowing the email correspondence, Vannrenser.no has moderated the text somewhat and they have removed the logo and instead written FHI in capital letters - along with other logos.As Marianne Steinberg, senior advisor at FHI, sees it, the company has not complied with FHI's requirements. – In the correspondence a few months ago, FHI asked the website to remove the reference to us through the logo and previous comments on some of Vannrenser.no's professional content that FHI believes gives the wrong impression of what they inform about, says Steinberg. Steinberg clarifies above Faktisk.no what FHI's advice regarding drinking water is:  – It is not necessary to purify drinking water from a waterworks with a filter or other post-treatment. The vast majority of people get their drinking water from a waterworks, which treats the water so that it is safe to drink. But could there be something to be said for a water filter like Pimp Lotion claims in the video posted by the company? The user @vannrenser.no on TikTok uses a clip of Thomas Thrap Huse talking about water quality and water filtration. Screenshot TikTokTests weekly– The drinking water in Oslo, including from Maridalsvannet, is safe and meets all requirements in the drinking water regulations . This is what Toril Giske, functional manager for water quality at the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration, tells Faktisk.no. She explains that they conduct frequent tests to ensure that the quality of drinking water is always high.– The claims made in the podcast do not provide a balanced or fact-based picture of water quality in Oslo. The Water and Wastewater Agency relies on extensive monitoring and scientific documentation to ensure that the drinking water supplied to Oslo's population is safe and good. She adds: The Norwegian Institute of Public Health:These are PFASPFAS are a large group of man-made synthetic substances, of which there are approximately 10,000.PFAS have been used for over 50 years in a variety of products, including food packaging, non-stick coatings for pots and pans, textile impregnation agents, fire-fighting foams, cleaning products, cosmetics, paints, varnishes and some types of ski lubricants. In addition, fire-fighting foams have been found to be an important source of PFAS in the environment in Norway.PFAS are not produced in Norway. Everything that is traded is imported, either in the form of chemical-technical products or as a component in solid processed products.PFAS are widely distributed in the environment. Animals at the top of the food chain have higher amounts of a number of these substances in their bodies than animals further down the food chain.Source: NIPH and NIVA– This involves weekly sampling at the water treatment plants and in the pipeline network. This is done in accordance with the requirements set for water utility owners in the Drinking Water Regulations.– Found everywhereIn the aforementioned podcast, Thomas Thrap Huse focuses particularly on PFAS (see fact box) in drinking water as one of the main reasons why he believes it is wise to use a reverse osmosis filter. PFAS are substances that are very stable and are therefore referred to as forever chemicals. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen, who researches environmental chemicals at the Norwegian Institute for Water Research (NIVA), tells Faktisk.no. “PFAS are often added to the surface of a product and can be washed off during use and washing. Because PFAS have so many different uses, we find the substances almost everywhere, both outdoors and indoors,” says Gundersen.She points out that virtually all people have PFASs in their blood because some of these substances are found almost everywhere. We do not have thorough data on the harmful effects of all types of PFAS, but several types have been linked to harmful effects that can, among other things, disrupt the immune system, reduce the effectiveness of vaccines, inhibit fetal development and be carcinogenic. Very low levelsThe level of PFAS in drinking water has recently been investigated in Southern Norway, including in Maridalsvannet. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen has a PhD in environmental chemistry and is a researcher at the Norwegian Institute for Water Resources (NIVA). Photo: NIVA. – Not surprisingly, PFAS was found, but at low levels that are below the most stringent international drinking water limits. PFAS in drinking water from public waterworks in southern parts of Norway is low and therefore drinking water is not considered a significant source,  says Gundersen.This is also confirmed by Toril Giske from the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration. At the same time, she says that it is true that PFAS can be found in some types of ski lubricant: – We regularly monitor water quality and analyze, among other things, for PFAS, which can be found in certain types of ski lubricant. When it comes to PFAS, we analyze quarterly for 17 different compounds at both of our raw water sources, Maridalsvannet and Elvåga. According to Giske, none of these compounds were detected in samples taken at Elvåga in 2024. – In samples from Maridalsvannet, we have found a few of these (3 out of 17), but these are very low values that are well below the prescribed limit value for PFAS compounds in the new drinking water regulations. Giske tells Faktisk.no that the water quality is safe and is continuously monitored.Drinking water not the main sourceShe says that the most important source of PFAS for humans is the food we eat. This is also stated by the EU's EFSA, which carries out risk assessments on the levels of PFAS that humans can ingest. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen at NIVA therefore believes that it is generally not necessary to use a reverse osmosis filter in Norway. – To reduce exposure to PFAS, it is recommended to be aware of which products you buy and surround yourself with. Products marked with the Nordic Ecolabel guarantee to be free of PFAS, says Gundersen.The researcher believes that places where such a filter might be appropriate are at private water sources, such as a well, located near a firefighting training area or at places where PFAS has previously been produced. But Gundersen adds that the water utility is responsible for ensuring that public water supplies are of sufficiently good quality.

The Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration conducts weekly tests to ensure high water quality and confirms that claims about pollution in Oslo's water are not fact-based. While PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) are present in the environment and can be found in Maridalsvannet, levels are very low and well below stringent international drinking water limits. Experts from the Norwegian Institute for Water Research (NIVA) confirm that drinking water from public waterworks is not a significant source of PFAS exposure; the primary source for humans is food. Therefore, a reverse osmosis filter is generally not necessary in Norway, especially for public water supplies. The FHI has also requested Vannrenser.no to moderate its references to the institute, as the company's content gives a misleading impression of FHI's advice.

headline: Claims that ski wax pollutes Oslo's drinking water
summary: Assertion:In areas where a lot of ski lubrication is used, there is extra PFAS (a type of synthetic substance). It ends up in Maridalsvannet and is not cleaned. I can guarantee you that the water you get from the tap contains a lot of crap.Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), republished by @vannrenser.no on TikTokConclusion:The drinking water in Oslo undergoes rigorous testing, is monitored weekly, and meets all requirements of the Drinking Water Regulations. It is safe to drink, and a water filter is not necessary. PFAS can occur in drinking water, but the levels are well below safe limits.
text: According to influencer and artist Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), and the company Vannrenser.no, Oslo's drinking water from Maridalen is so polluted that we are advised to purchase a water filter to purify our drinking water. TikTok user @vannrenser.no is apparently advertising the website of the same name , where you can purchase the filters. According to the website, the so-called reverse osmosis filter is supposed to remove absolutely all contaminants, which in turn can lead to increased energy levels and help us get rid of brain fog. The website Vannrenser.no mentions the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (FHI) several times on its website. Faktisk.no has obtained access to emails between Vannrenser.no and FHI, in which the latter asks the company to moderate the references on its website and remove the FHI logo. Get Faktisk.no straight to your inbox.  Click here to sign up for our weekly newsletter . This is what one of the places on the website Vannrenser.no looks like where FHI's name is used. Screenshot Vannrenser.noFollowing the email correspondence, Vannrenser.no has moderated the text somewhat and they have removed the logo and instead written FHI in capital letters - along with other logos.As Marianne Steinberg, senior advisor at FHI, sees it, the company has not complied with FHI's requirements. – In the correspondence a few months ago, FHI asked the website to remove the reference to us through the logo and previous comments on some of Vannrenser.no's professional content that FHI believes gives the wrong impression of what they inform about, says Steinberg. Steinberg clarifies above Faktisk.no what FHI's advice regarding drinking water is:  – It is not necessary to purify drinking water from a waterworks with a filter or other post-treatment. The vast majority of people get their drinking water from a waterworks, which treats the water so that it is safe to drink. But could there be something to be said for a water filter like Pimp Lotion claims in the video posted by the company? The user @vannrenser.no on TikTok uses a clip of Thomas Thrap Huse talking about water quality and water filtration. Screenshot TikTokTests weekly– The drinking water in Oslo, including from Maridalsvannet, is safe and meets all requirements in the drinking water regulations . This is what Toril Giske, functional manager for water quality at the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration, tells Faktisk.no. She explains that they conduct frequent tests to ensure that the quality of drinking water is always high.– The claims made in the podcast do not provide a balanced or fact-based picture of water quality in Oslo. The Water and Wastewater Agency relies on extensive monitoring and scientific documentation to ensure that the drinking water supplied to Oslo's population is safe and good. She adds: The Norwegian Institute of Public Health:These are PFASPFAS are a large group of man-made synthetic substances, of which there are approximately 10,000.PFAS have been used for over 50 years in a variety of products, including food packaging, non-stick coatings for pots and pans, textile impregnation agents, fire-fighting foams, cleaning products, cosmetics, paints, varnishes and some types of ski lubricants. In addition, fire-fighting foams have been found to be an important source of PFAS in the environment in Norway.PFAS are not produced in Norway. Everything that is traded is imported, either in the form of chemical-technical products or as a component in solid processed products.PFAS are widely distributed in the environment. Animals at the top of the food chain have higher amounts of a number of these substances in their bodies than animals further down the food chain.Source: NIPH and NIVA– This involves weekly sampling at the water treatment plants and in the pipeline network. This is done in accordance with the requirements set for water utility owners in the Drinking Water Regulations.– Found everywhereIn the aforementioned podcast, Thomas Thrap Huse focuses particularly on PFAS (see fact box) in drinking water as one of the main reasons why he believes it is wise to use a reverse osmosis filter. PFAS are substances that are very stable and are therefore referred to as forever chemicals. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen, who researches environmental chemicals at the Norwegian Institute for Water Research (NIVA), tells Faktisk.no. “PFAS are often added to the surface of a product and can be washed off during use and washing. Because PFAS have so many different uses, we find the substances almost everywhere, both outdoors and indoors,” says Gundersen.She points out that virtually all people have PFASs in their blood because some of these substances are found almost everywhere. We do not have thorough data on the harmful effects of all types of PFAS, but several types have been linked to harmful effects that can, among other things, disrupt the immune system, reduce the effectiveness of vaccines, inhibit fetal development and be carcinogenic. Very low levelsThe level of PFAS in drinking water has recently been investigated in Southern Norway, including in Maridalsvannet. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen has a PhD in environmental chemistry and is a researcher at the Norwegian Institute for Water Resources (NIVA). Photo: NIVA. – Not surprisingly, PFAS was found, but at low levels that are below the most stringent international drinking water limits. PFAS in drinking water from public waterworks in southern parts of Norway is low and therefore drinking water is not considered a significant source,  says Gundersen.This is also confirmed by Toril Giske from the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration. At the same time, she says that it is true that PFAS can be found in some types of ski lubricant: – We regularly monitor water quality and analyze, among other things, for PFAS, which can be found in certain types of ski lubricant. When it comes to PFAS, we analyze quarterly for 17 different compounds at both of our raw water sources, Maridalsvannet and Elvåga. According to Giske, none of these compounds were detected in samples taken at Elvåga in 2024. – In samples from Maridalsvannet, we have found a few of these (3 out of 17), but these are very low values that are well below the prescribed limit value for PFAS compounds in the new drinking water regulations. Giske tells Faktisk.no that the water quality is safe and is continuously monitored.Drinking water not the main sourceShe says that the most important source of PFAS for humans is the food we eat. This is also stated by the EU's EFSA, which carries out risk assessments on the levels of PFAS that humans can ingest. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen at NIVA therefore believes that it is generally not necessary to use a reverse osmosis filter in Norway. – To reduce exposure to PFAS, it is recommended to be aware of which products you buy and surround yourself with. Products marked with the Nordic Ecolabel guarantee to be free of PFAS, says Gundersen.The researcher believes that places where such a filter might be appropriate are at private water sources, such as a well, located near a firefighting training area or at places where PFAS has previously been produced. But Gundersen adds that the water utility is responsible for ensuring that public water supplies are of sufficiently good quality.

headline: Claims that ski wax pollutes Oslo's drinking water
summary: Assertion:In areas where a lot of ski lubrication is used, there is extra PFAS (a type of synthetic substance). It ends up in Maridalsvannet and is not cleaned. I can guarantee you that the water you get from the tap contains a lot of crap.Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), republished by @vannrenser.no on TikTokConclusion:The drinking water in Oslo undergoes rigorous testing, is monitored weekly, and meets all requirements of the Drinking Water Regulations. It is safe to drink, and a water filter is not necessary. PFAS can occur in drinking water, but the levels are well below safe limits.
text: According to influencer and artist Thomas Thrap Huse (Pimp Lotion), and the company Vannrenser.no, Oslo's drinking water from Maridalen is so polluted that we are advised to purchase a water filter to purify our drinking water. TikTok user @vannrenser.no is apparently advertising the website of the same name , where you can purchase the filters. According to the website, the so-called reverse osmosis filter is supposed to remove absolutely all contaminants, which in turn can lead to increased energy levels and help us get rid of brain fog. The website Vannrenser.no mentions the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (FHI) several times on its website. Faktisk.no has obtained access to emails between Vannrenser.no and FHI, in which the latter asks the company to moderate the references on its website and remove the FHI logo. Get Faktisk.no straight to your inbox.  Click here to sign up for our weekly newsletter . This is what one of the places on the website Vannrenser.no looks like where FHI's name is used. Screenshot Vannrenser.noFollowing the email correspondence, Vannrenser.no has moderated the text somewhat and they have removed the logo and instead written FHI in capital letters - along with other logos.As Marianne Steinberg, senior advisor at FHI, sees it, the company has not complied with FHI's requirements. – In the correspondence a few months ago, FHI asked the website to remove the reference to us through the logo and previous comments on some of Vannrenser.no's professional content that FHI believes gives the wrong impression of what they inform about, says Steinberg. Steinberg clarifies above Faktisk.no what FHI's advice regarding drinking water is:  – It is not necessary to purify drinking water from a waterworks with a filter or other post-treatment. The vast majority of people get their drinking water from a waterworks, which treats the water so that it is safe to drink. But could there be something to be said for a water filter like Pimp Lotion claims in the video posted by the company? The user @vannrenser.no on TikTok uses a clip of Thomas Thrap Huse talking about water quality and water filtration. Screenshot TikTokTests weekly– The drinking water in Oslo, including from Maridalsvannet, is safe and meets all requirements in the drinking water regulations . This is what Toril Giske, functional manager for water quality at the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration, tells Faktisk.no. She explains that they conduct frequent tests to ensure that the quality of drinking water is always high.– The claims made in the podcast do not provide a balanced or fact-based picture of water quality in Oslo. The Water and Wastewater Agency relies on extensive monitoring and scientific documentation to ensure that the drinking water supplied to Oslo's population is safe and good. She adds: The Norwegian Institute of Public Health:These are PFASPFAS are a large group of man-made synthetic substances, of which there are approximately 10,000.PFAS have been used for over 50 years in a variety of products, including food packaging, non-stick coatings for pots and pans, textile impregnation agents, fire-fighting foams, cleaning products, cosmetics, paints, varnishes and some types of ski lubricants. In addition, fire-fighting foams have been found to be an important source of PFAS in the environment in Norway.PFAS are not produced in Norway. Everything that is traded is imported, either in the form of chemical-technical products or as a component in solid processed products.PFAS are widely distributed in the environment. Animals at the top of the food chain have higher amounts of a number of these substances in their bodies than animals further down the food chain.Source: NIPH and NIVA– This involves weekly sampling at the water treatment plants and in the pipeline network. This is done in accordance with the requirements set for water utility owners in the Drinking Water Regulations.– Found everywhereIn the aforementioned podcast, Thomas Thrap Huse focuses particularly on PFAS (see fact box) in drinking water as one of the main reasons why he believes it is wise to use a reverse osmosis filter. PFAS are substances that are very stable and are therefore referred to as forever chemicals. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen, who researches environmental chemicals at the Norwegian Institute for Water Research (NIVA), tells Faktisk.no. “PFAS are often added to the surface of a product and can be washed off during use and washing. Because PFAS have so many different uses, we find the substances almost everywhere, both outdoors and indoors,” says Gundersen.She points out that virtually all people have PFASs in their blood because some of these substances are found almost everywhere. We do not have thorough data on the harmful effects of all types of PFAS, but several types have been linked to harmful effects that can, among other things, disrupt the immune system, reduce the effectiveness of vaccines, inhibit fetal development and be carcinogenic. Very low levelsThe level of PFAS in drinking water has recently been investigated in Southern Norway, including in Maridalsvannet. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen has a PhD in environmental chemistry and is a researcher at the Norwegian Institute for Water Resources (NIVA). Photo: NIVA. – Not surprisingly, PFAS was found, but at low levels that are below the most stringent international drinking water limits. PFAS in drinking water from public waterworks in southern parts of Norway is low and therefore drinking water is not considered a significant source,  says Gundersen.This is also confirmed by Toril Giske from the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration. At the same time, she says that it is true that PFAS can be found in some types of ski lubricant: – We regularly monitor water quality and analyze, among other things, for PFAS, which can be found in certain types of ski lubricant. When it comes to PFAS, we analyze quarterly for 17 different compounds at both of our raw water sources, Maridalsvannet and Elvåga. According to Giske, none of these compounds were detected in samples taken at Elvåga in 2024. – In samples from Maridalsvannet, we have found a few of these (3 out of 17), but these are very low values that are well below the prescribed limit value for PFAS compounds in the new drinking water regulations. Giske tells Faktisk.no that the water quality is safe and is continuously monitored.Drinking water not the main sourceShe says that the most important source of PFAS for humans is the food we eat. This is also stated by the EU's EFSA, which carries out risk assessments on the levels of PFAS that humans can ingest. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen at NIVA therefore believes that it is generally not necessary to use a reverse osmosis filter in Norway. – To reduce exposure to PFAS, it is recommended to be aware of which products you buy and surround yourself with. Products marked with the Nordic Ecolabel guarantee to be free of PFAS, says Gundersen.The researcher believes that places where such a filter might be appropriate are at private water sources, such as a well, located near a firefighting training area or at places where PFAS has previously been produced. But Gundersen adds that the water utility is responsible for ensuring that public water supplies are of sufficiently good quality.

Screenshot Vannrenser.noFollowing the email correspondence, Vannrenser.no has moderated the text somewhat and they have removed the logo and instead written FHI in capital letters - along with other logos.As Marianne Steinberg, senior advisor at FHI, sees it, the company has not complied with FHI's requirements. – In the correspondence a few months ago, FHI asked the website to remove the reference to us through the logo and previous comments on some of Vannrenser.no's professional content that FHI believes gives the wrong impression of what they inform about, says Steinberg. Steinberg clarifies above Faktisk.no what FHI's advice regarding drinking water is:  – It is not necessary to purify drinking water from a waterworks with a filter or other post-treatment. The vast majority of people get their drinking water from a waterworks, which treats the water so that it is safe to drink. But could there be something to be said for a water filter like Pimp Lotion claims in the video posted by the company? The user @vannrenser.no on TikTok uses a clip of Thomas Thrap Huse talking about water quality and water filtration. Screenshot TikTokTests weekly– The drinking water in Oslo, including from Maridalsvannet, is safe and meets all requirements in the drinking water regulations . This is what Toril Giske, functional manager for water quality at the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration, tells Faktisk.no. She explains that they conduct frequent tests to ensure that the quality of drinking water is always high.– The claims made in the podcast do not provide a balanced or fact-based picture of water quality in Oslo. The Water and Wastewater Agency relies on extensive monitoring and scientific documentation to ensure that the drinking water supplied to Oslo's population is safe and good. She adds: The Norwegian Institute of Public Health:These are PFASPFAS are a large group of man-made synthetic substances, of which there are approximately 10,000.PFAS have been used for over 50 years in a variety of products, including food packaging, non-stick coatings for pots and pans, textile impregnation agents, fire-fighting foams, cleaning products, cosmetics, paints, varnishes and some types of ski lubricants. In addition, fire-fighting foams have been found to be an important source of PFAS in the environment in Norway.PFAS are not produced in Norway. Everything that is traded is imported, either in the form of chemical-technical products or as a component in solid processed products.PFAS are widely distributed in the environment. Animals at the top of the food chain have higher amounts of a number of these substances in their bodies than animals further down the food chain.Source: NIPH and NIVA– This involves weekly sampling at the water treatment plants and in the pipeline network. This is done in accordance with the requirements set for water utility owners in the Drinking Water Regulations.– Found everywhereIn the aforementioned podcast, Thomas Thrap Huse focuses particularly on PFAS (see fact box) in drinking water as one of the main reasons why he believes it is wise to use a reverse osmosis filter. PFAS are substances that are very stable and are therefore referred to as forever chemicals. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen, who researches environmental chemicals at the Norwegian Institute for Water Research (NIVA), tells Faktisk.no. “PFAS are often added to the surface of a product and can be washed off during use and washing. Because PFAS have so many different uses, we find the substances almost everywhere, both outdoors and indoors,” says Gundersen.She points out that virtually all people have PFASs in their blood because some of these substances are found almost everywhere. We do not have thorough data on the harmful effects of all types of PFAS, but several types have been linked to harmful effects that can, among other things, disrupt the immune system, reduce the effectiveness of vaccines, inhibit fetal development and be carcinogenic. Very low levelsThe level of PFAS in drinking water has recently been investigated in Southern Norway, including in Maridalsvannet. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen has a PhD in environmental chemistry and is a researcher at the Norwegian Institute for Water Resources (NIVA). Photo: NIVA. – Not surprisingly, PFAS was found, but at low levels that are below the most stringent international drinking water limits. PFAS in drinking water from public waterworks in southern parts of Norway is low and therefore drinking water is not considered a significant source,  says Gundersen.This is also confirmed by Toril Giske from the Norwegian Water and Sewage Administration. At the same time, she says that it is true that PFAS can be found in some types of ski lubricant: – We regularly monitor water quality and analyze, among other things, for PFAS, which can be found in certain types of ski lubricant. When it comes to PFAS, we analyze quarterly for 17 different compounds at both of our raw water sources, Maridalsvannet and Elvåga. According to Giske, none of these compounds were detected in samples taken at Elvåga in 2024. – In samples from Maridalsvannet, we have found a few of these (3 out of 17), but these are very low values that are well below the prescribed limit value for PFAS compounds in the new drinking water regulations. Giske tells Faktisk.no that the water quality is safe and is continuously monitored.Drinking water not the main sourceShe says that the most important source of PFAS for humans is the food we eat. This is also stated by the EU's EFSA, which carries out risk assessments on the levels of PFAS that humans can ingest. Cathrine Brecke Gundersen at NIVA therefore believes that it is generally not necessary to use a reverse osmosis filter in Norway. – To reduce exposure to PFAS, it is recommended to be aware of which products you buy and surround yourself with. Products marked with the Nordic Ecolabel guarantee to be free of PFAS, says Gundersen.The researcher believes that places where such a filter might be appropriate are at private water sources, such as a well, located near a firefighting training area or at places where PFAS has previously been produced. But Gundersen adds that the water utility is responsible for ensuring that public water supplies are of sufficiently good quality.

headline: These videos are going viral – but they don't show what you think
summary: Old videos are being spread on social media in the wake of the attacks between Iran and Israel.
text: This is the fact-check :On the night of Sunday, June 22, the United States bombed the three Iranian nuclear facilities of Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan.While the United States claims the attacks have put Iran's nuclear program out of action , Iranian authorities deny that the damage is serious.At the same time, social media is flooded with dramatic videos purporting to show the attacks.But many of these clips turn out to be from completely different times and events.A widely shared video purports to show the US attack on the Fordow facility over the weekend. View the archived version here .On TikTok, one of the posts has received 1.5 million views and over 40,000 likes.This video does not show US attacks on Iran. Screenshot: TikTok.But the video probably shows a Ukrainian attack on a Russian ammunition depot in September 2024.We found this out using a reverse image search on Google.The attack took place in the city of Toropets in the Tver region, western Russia, and was so powerful that it  affected seismometers in Norway .The video was first shared on social media, and has not been verified, according to  Reuters .Both international and Norwegian media used the video in connection with the Ukrainian attack, including  NRK ,  TV2 ,  The Guardian  and  CNN .We also made a TikTok video about this fact check. Watch it here .Another video also purports to show the Fordow attack, according to several on social media.This video has received many views on TikTok, but does not show what is claimed. Screenshot: TikTok.But a reverse image search shows that the video has been shared several times in December 2024, including by Belgian EU MP  Marc Botenga on X.It allegedly shows an Israeli attack on the Syrian coastal city of Tartus, in the wake of the fall of the Assad regime.Several media outlets, including  the Daily Mail , used the video in their coverage of the Israeli attack.Another video that is being shared frequently is claimed to show Iranian attacks against Israel.Several on social media claim that this video shows Iranian attacks against Israel. Screenshot: TikTok.Using reverse image search, we find the video on YouTube with an Arabic title.The translated title shows that the video is from the celebration of the Algerian football club Mouloudia Club's 103rd anniversary.A simple Google search for the club's name and 103 years yields several hits on posts with the same video from the celebration.
chatgpt_generation: Viral Videos Falsely Claim to Show U.S. Airstrikes on Iranian Nuclear Sites
chatgpt_condensation: Viral videos claiming to show recent U.S. airstrikes on Iranian nuclear sites are misleading, as they actually depict unrelated events from other countries and time periods.
chatgpt_evaluation: Verdict: False. The videos circulating on social media do not show U.S. airstrikes on Iranian nuclear sites; they are misattributed footage from unrelated events in other countries.

gemini_condensation: Social media videos claiming to show U.S. attacks on Iranian nuclear facilities and Iranian attacks on Israel are false, with footage actually depicting a Ukrainian attack on a Russian ammunition depot, an Israeli attack in Syria, and a football club celebration in Algeria.
gemini_evaluation: The verdict for the fact-check is False. The claims that the circulating videos show US attacks on Iranian nuclear facilities or Iranian attacks against Israel are demonstrably false, as the videos are identified as footage from entirely different events.

headline: The Swedish Diabetes Association is being exploited to sell fraudulent anti-obesity drugs
summary: The Swedish Diabetes Association is being used in scam ads where the scammers claim to have a miracle cure for weight loss. “Total fake,” says Fredrik Nyström, professor of internal medicine at Linköping University.
text: This is the fact-check :A Facebook page claiming to be the Swedish Diabetes Association has posted a before and after photo along with a sad story about two sisters.In the first photo, they are sitting on a sofa with a friend and smiling at the camera. In the second photo, one of the sisters has been replaced by a photo. She has died, only 52 years old.According to the story, the sisters have struggled with their weight for a long time.Kajsa and I have always been the big girls. Even in school we knew how to pose to look slimmer - to hold our shirts in front of our stomachs.People said: You have such a beautiful face.And we pretended not to hear.I remember when Kajsa was tying her shoes at Target, and could barely breathe when she got up.She laughed it off: I'm just old.I laughed along, but something inside me froze.Then the call came. I was in the grocery store buying toilet paper.Diana called. Kajsa fainted. Heart attack. She passed out.But, writes the Diabetesf�rbundet, with the help of a dietary supplement, the remaining sister managed to lose weight and in the after picture she really does look slimmer.The post has received over 1,200 likes in two weeks.For anyone who clicks on “Diabetesf�rbundet” and examines the Facebook page, it superficially looks like it could belong to the real Swedish Diabetes Association.There are Swedish address and contact details and the link leads to the real association's website . However, the scammers have only made a copy. Their Facebook page has just over 900 followers and if you search Facebook's search function for Diabetesförbundet you will find the real organization, with 16,000 followers.The Swedish Diabetes Association neither recommends, certifies nor endorses products, services or medicines, writes Bjørn Ehlin, chairman of the real interest organization, to the Source Criticism Agency:In 2025, we have seen an increase in the number of advertisements on social media where advertisers use the names and logos of various organizations and authorities without permission, including the Swedish Diabetes Association and the Swedish Medical Products Agency.We take seriously the creation of accounts and pages on social media with our name and logo, as well as websites

Claim being verified: A Facebook page claiming to be the Swedish Diabetes Association posted a story about two sisters, asserting that one sister died due to weight-related issues, while the other achieved significant weight loss using a specific dietary supplement, which is then offered for sale. 2. Final verdict: False. 3. Evidence and reasoning:  Fake Organization: The Facebook page is a copycat of the real Swedish Diabetes Association. The real Swedish Diabetes Association explicitly states they do not recommend, certify, or endorse products, services, or medicines.  Scam Link: The link provided on the fake page leads to a site mimicking the Swedish Diabetes Association's branding, offering the dietary supplement for 700 kronor with a promise of 60 kilos weight loss – a claim deemed a total fake by medical experts. Fake Testimonials: The comments section is filled with fake profiles using stolen before and after photos from legitimate weight loss success stories on platforms like Reddit. Page History: The scammers' Facebook page was created in 2023 as The KING Photography and only changed its name to Diabetesförbundet in April 2025, indicating a deceptive rebranding. Expert Testimony:  Fredrik Nyström, professor researching risk factors for cardiovascular disease, obesity, and diabetes at Linköping University: States there are no dietary supplements that have these effects, it is a total fake. Åke Lernmark, senior professor in experimental diabetes at Lund University: Confirms that dietary supplements such as pills do not lead to weight loss.
